user_review: I came here twice, the first time for sit-in dining and the second for take out pizza. The foie gras poutine is delicious, but very rich and decadent, but a must try.The canned duck was a very unique experience where you pour the duck out of the can. The sauce was again unctuous and rich, but very fitting for the theme of the restaurant. Jarret de porc for two was the last piece, and we were really stuffed at the end. During the pandemic, we tried their take-out pizza. It was a very satisfying pizza, we tried two pizzas, the Charcuterie and the boudin. Both were heavily topped with a variety of ingredients, when paired together made the perfect bites. Highly recommend.

What a memorable meal! I had Au Pied de Cochon on my list the first time I came to Montreal years ago but my friend and I were unable to go. So on this trip with my husband, we made reservations for date night. The atmosphere is very relaxed and almost casual, like a neighborhood bistro. But the food was top notch! Of course we ordered foie gras to start with and it was heavenly! For our entrée we shared the canard en conserve (duck in a can). Highly intriguing, extremely satisfying. It's a bit of a puzzle how they cook this thing but it was extremely delicious and I highly recommend it. I enjoyed a natural wine from Quebec with my dinner while my husband had one of their fantastic cocktails. For dessert we had both the flan and the maple syrup tart. My gosh! Talk about indulgence! That tart was so incredible I immediately looked up a recipe so I can recreate it at home. We left incredibly full and immensely satisfied. Definitely a must visit if you're in Montreal.

This was one of the top restaurants we were looking forward to trying on our trip to Montreal in January. What we enjoyed:- foie gras nigiri - everyone thought this was a great fusion dish! Rich, buttery and melts in your mouth! One thing about this dish is the slices of foie gras are inconsistent, some smaller than the others. - blood sausage - comes with mashed potatoes and bread to spread on, great flavours and great to share. It is a little bit on the heavy side. - duck in a can - this was the star of the dish! Moist, rich and flavourful. What I can skip out on next time:- blue cheese salad - if you really like blue cheese, this is for you. However, it came out strong for us - melting pot - this dish has a good mix of everything to try, but I would choose duck in a can over this dish.Dimly lit atmosphere, a bit on the louder end but we had a great time! Excellent service as well. This place is on the pricier side, but definitely a place to try foie gras dishes.

Unfortunately underwhelming (February 2020)- the wait for the duck seemed rushed;20 minutes only (in comparison to other reviewers saying it took 30-1 hour) and when we ate the canned duck was chewy and not tender at all/hard to into - the sauce tasted also tasted overwhelmingly thick and burnt. The bread appetizer was delicious, and started off our night. The French onion soup was also extremely salty :/ The waitress also recommended the foie gras bites, which burst in your mouth, but also it wasn't anything special Overall- it was not really worth it in my opinion, but try it out if you'd like. Maybe I came at a wrong time, or had high expectations (my friend recommended this restaurant to me)

For our first date of 2020, we finally decided to go to the Au Pied du Cochon on Duluth, and boy were we impressed! Au Pied du Cochon prides itself on sourcing quality ingredients, which they then incorporate in original and tasty dishes - you're pretty much sure to eat something you've hardly, if ever, eaten before, and that is its greatest strength. We started with some beautifully umami foie gras croquettes, tiny single bites that were unlike anything I've ever tasted (and I come from foie gras country!). My husband had a deer and pork gratin in which the scalloped potatoes had been slowly cooked, lending a rich and meaty quality to the dish. The portion was very generous and he was even struggling to finish his meal. I had an astonishingly fresh duck carpaccio with thinly sliced mushrooms, cheddar and cucumbers, a soy-infused egg yolk, and an additional dashi soup with fried tofu on the side. This made for a gorgeous Asian/Québec fusion sort of dish and definitely an experience in and of itself. We then finished our meal on the sweet note that is the "pouding chômeur", an ubiquitous bread and maple pudding that is quintessentially Québec.Their wine selection is decent - as always in North America, dessert wines, which are a fixture in any menu of my native France, are scarce, but it's easily forgiven. I had a lovely Riesling and my husband a red Côtes-du-Rhône. The staff was obviously bilingual, as is the norm in most of Montréal, and helpful, taking the time to explain all the dishes and what ingredients they were composed of. One last thing tho - it is a bit on the pricey side. Main dishes are $30 on average, so you'll definitely be looking at a three-digit bill. But the price is entirely justified: it is just that good!

Not much to say that hasn't already been said... this place serves its niche as a sophisticated meaty restaurant very very well. So much exploratory options to choose from, but gotta use some self control. This is Important (with a capital I) since everything on the menu (as many warned) is extremely heavy and hearty. A solid set for our party of 6:- Complimentary bread (even the crust was good soft)- Tomato Tart (if pizza and quiche had a perfect baby)- Mushroom pasta (creamy with graceful bacon bits)- Duck in a can (27min of high cooking to soak in all the duck parts and veggie flavors together in one brilliant blend)- Shepherds Pie (with crazyass flavorful kick)- AND THATS IT YOU SHOULD STOP RIGHT HERE YOU CANT EAT MORE EVEN IF YOU THINK YOU CAN ITS JUST PHYSICS.Place is crowded (and temperature was set a bit too warm). And yes you need reservations. Definitely a recommended experience.

So naturally, doing what real Yelp'ers do, I researched a few places to eat before actually visiting! This place came up on 2 different TV shows featured on The Travel Channel because of their infamous "Duck In A Can". More to come on that.Atmosphere/Appearance: Set right off of the vintage cobblestone roads of downtown Montreal is this gem. There's a lovely amount of outdoor seating, a bit a bar seating and a fair amount of traditional dining seating. This restaurant gives me the feel that the owner didn't know how popular this place was going to become because of its size. Reservations are highly recommended. We tried coming to this place just out the blue one day and boy were we wrong. Lol. I had to make reservations 3 weeks out because of how booked they were, but it was worth it. So we chose to sit near the back and it was quite cozy. The atmosphere was very busy with a lot of the staff running around, but very efficiently. The lights were dim and quite romantic with a wall of mirrors giving the illusion of a bigger space.Service: Tom was our actual server, but we weren't the most pleased. There was a big party of maybe 8 to 10 at the very back of the restaurant that seemed to take all of his attention. He was very "quick" with us to get back to his party table to where it seems he was having a lot more fun. We didn't appreciate it and we let him know, but then he tried to come out of his shell. Nah fam. Too late. Skander and Osser were other servers that delivered our food as well as refilled out waters. We REALLY liked them and wish one of them had been our server from jump because they paid us a lot more attention than Tom did.Food: So I'm here for "Duck In A Can" and nothing else. Lol. It's such a cool and niche dish for sure. From my travels in Montreal I've learned that duck is a BIG deal and I totally understand it. So, the duck in a can contains bacon, seared foie gras, duck breast, the fat from the duck breast and a bunch of other ingredients. It's all packed into a can then cooked in water for 28 minutes. They come to the table, open the can and do an incredible presentation. I loved it. It was incredible flavored, a good portion and totally unique. I don't think I'd ever get anything else here.Value: All priced are in $CAD. This place is NOT cheap. I picked up a bottle of red wine and one of the cheapest they had was $51.00. Yikes. It was certainly tasty though. My Duck In A Can was $44.00, but absolutely worth it. From the good service Osser and Skander gave us to the quality, to the portions as well as the overall experience, it was worth it.In conclusion, I will be making my way back here whenever I get back to Montreal. It's so worth it.

As a lover of all things foie gras (and watching Anthony Bourdain sweat over the amount of food consumed), this was a must-do when visiting Montreal over the past weekend. Reservations are hard to come by on the weekend, so we managed to squeeze in a 10:00 p.m. slot. The restaurant moves as a frantic, fast-paced, yet well-oiled machine, with part of the kitchen open-concept and up front so you can catch the action. We decided to keep it simple, and we ordered the foie gras poutine, foie gras terrine with maple butter, the infamous "duck-in-a-can," and the maple pudding. The restaurant also offered some specialty cocktails, so my plus one ordered a maple gin cocktail, followed by a cucumber and cilantro mojito. Drinks - I managed to steal some sips of both cocktails - refreshing, fruity, and deliciousFoie Gras Poutine - this was absurd, over-indulgent and delicious. French fries covered in gravy, squeaky cheese curds, and warm foie gras. Need I say more? Foie Gras Terrine - The terrine was smooth, rich, and paired perfectly with the sweet maple butter on toasted points. My only complaint was that there was probably not enough bread to supplement the terrine, and just as a warning, this dish is best split with 4 diners. Duck-in-a-can - It's duck breast, foie gras, seasonal vegetables all cooked in a can for 27 minutes and served tableside. The rich sauce that the dish was cooked in was flavorful. The duck breast portion was pretty large, but I felt that the meat was just a little bit too tough for my liking. Maple pudding - We were incredibly full by the time we ordered dessert, but we decided to try the maple pudding. It's a warm bread pudding, almost like a cobbler, over a sticky sweet sauce. Maybe I'm not a huge maple syrup fan, but this was way too sweet. Overall, this was a delight to experience and worth the visit.

Very memorable meal here. For starters, we got their blue cheese salad thinking it would be a nice light way to prepare us for our meal. It was the richest thing we ate that night, and it was absolutely incredible. All the sausages were delicious, and the service was wonderful.

APC is very much one of my favourite culinary experiences this year in 2019 in Montreal. I've been to the APC sugar shack which I believe tries to replicate the vibe and feel of this quaint, small special restaurant (but in a sugar shack kind of way). However APC is unique. The restaurant is small, packed to the gills and they excel in service, presentation and candor out high quality super rich food in a dizzying delivery. I say this as there must be 30+ people working in this tiny restaurant. To watch the service is akin to shaking up a beehive and watching the bees go in and out in cacophonous harmony. The food I sampled on the evening was the following:1) bleu salad- with fennel, crushed walnuts (I believe) in a creamy sauce. One of the most flavour filled amazing salads I've had in a while. Complex, blue cheese creamy and filling.2) poutine- unbelievable. Two or three kinds of rich creme and gravy sauce over crispy potatoes with chunks of foie gras. If I ever had a last meal on earth this could be a finalist request for that. 3) PDC farci foie gras- a bottom leg (pork trotter I believe) stuffed topped with foie gras. This was not enjoyed at all. Sure the stuffing was good but the meat was minimal and it was filled with fat, skin, collagen and other non pleasing fatty substances. I eat innards and organ meat but this was a miss ordered item on our part. Overall would I return on despite of not liking #3? Of course as everything else we observed  come out of the kitchen looked creative, rich and decadent. Definitely a pleasure to experience and enjoy to the fullest. It's a rich dinner. Possibly your fat and cholesterol limits for a full year but this is the reason people come and seek out these decadent delights.

If you want to experience some of the best French Canadian fine dining that Montreal has to offer, you absolutely need to visit Au Pied de Cochon. The ambiance was inviting and vaguely reminiscent of Europe - the street in which the restaurant was situated had cobblestones and it wasn't too crowded. Everything from the service to the FOOD was perfect! We were very well taken care of. The foie gras poutine was the best poutine that I've had. There. I've said it. I thought the best poutine that I've had was at La Banquise...but I was wrong. The foie gras poutine at Au Pied De Cochon is the best!! The poutine itself looked like it could be too rich but it wasn't. The fries, cheese curds, gravy and foie gras were in the perfect harmony with one another. The Duck In A Can was quite a demonstration. The duck was poured directly from the can (which was opened right in front of us and kudos to the one of the servers for not touching the contents in the can) onto the plate. Then it was time to dig in. And wow - the duck was succulent and was unlike anything that I've tasted before. It was the perfect main after the foie gras poutine too! Since we came in on my boyfriend's birthday, the staff were kind enough to get us complimentary maple crème brûlée (with sparklers!) and some champagne to celebrate. They have definitely gone above and beyond when it came to service. Definitely give Au Pied De Cochon a visit if you can. You will not be disappointed!

Our group of 8 didn't know what to order.  So we got waitress to recommend dishes to share at 70pp.  What we got in dishes was both exceeding expectations in terms of taste and portion. Some highlights to recommend: 1) Foie gras nigiri - melt in your mouth texture accented by ponzu sauce.  2) Foie gras pountine - great for sharing.  Otherwise would be bit heavy. 3) Plogue a champlain - pancake, potato, cheese, fried egg, bacon and foie gras in maple syrup reduction.  It's like tasting an elaborate breakfast sandwich with foie gras.  Last thought, Duck in a Can dish takes long time to cook so be prepared to wait.  Also, would suggest to reduce the salt level for this dish.Overall, heavy dishes with large portions great for sharing.

Superb service, exemplary staff, and wonderful dishes. First time coming here and we sought out recommendations from the staff. They recommended the plogue a Champlain, a buckwheat pancake bottom topped with cheese, bacon, foie bras, and topped with maple syrup. This was easily my favorite dish to start with as the combination of flavors complemented each other well. Next up as our main, we shared the melting pot, essentially a mish mash of all things pork related (pork sausage, blood sausage, pork belly, pork loin, onions, and various other veggies with a bottom layer of mashed potatoes and cheese. My taste buds were exploding with flavor, it was so delicious! We finished with the maple pudding chomeur which I can only describe as their version of bread pudding slathered in Carmel sauce. It was a bit too decadent for our taste, so we left a lot of the Carmel sauce but devoured the bread part!During our entire meal, our glasses were constantly topped off and we were never left unattended so I must say, service was superb. Our reservation was at 10 pm but they were still taking orders around 11pm! Would definitely recommend anyone to come here if they have time.

My absolute favourite place on earth! I have been here many times while living in Montreal. I heard of this place after watching Anthony Bourdaine come here.   They serve fresh warm bread at the beginning, which is always perfect. I ordered the Plogue a Champlain and I promise you it is the best thing you will ever taste. Everything on the menu is fantastic and a little fois gras on top never hurt anyone ;) My arteries feel like they're going to clog after I eat here, but damn it tastes so good! I strongly recommend making a reservation a few days in advance as it is pretty hard to just walk in without waiting a while. If you are in Montreal, you MUST try this place, no exceptions!

Rarely does a resto live up to its hype as well as Au Pied de Cochon did. It's an unassuming little place on Duluth, easy to miss walking or driving past it which can lead to you miss quite a dining experience! Don't bother just walking in, it's quite unlikely you'll find a seat so book online weeks/months ahead. It's effortless.We opted to sit at the bar and got a first row view of the kitchen team work in an "organized chaos" during the entire dining experience. I sat there transfixed for 2 hours as they worked non-stop serving great looking dishes one after another.For starters I went with an Amaretto Sour and it was absolutely on-point. Delish! For apps we went with the Fois Gras Poutine and Blue Cheese salad. I won't go into details on the salad as it wasn't intended for me (not a huge fan of Blue cheese) but the couple of bites I took were quite decent. The poutine on the other hand was downright shockingly good! Doesn't look great visually and the actual expiration of the plate is less than 5 minutes but the richness of the gravy and fois gras truly deserves it's legendary Montreal status. Absolutely divine!!!! On a scale to 5, I'll say it's one of the few plates I've ever eaten that breaks the scale and is a 6. SIMPLY. AMAZING.They serve the best warm bread too - soft on the inside and crispy on the outside, butter easy to spread. ME LIKEY.As a main we went with the stuffed PDC with fois gras and it was underwhelming. It was quite fatty and frankly it was mostly fat and stuffing. Wouldn't have it again and I guess that decision is on us. When I'll come back (and I will), I'll definitely try one of the many other things on the menu they have. For dessert, I saved a little space for a little poor man's pudding with maple syrup. Served in an unassuming small bowl it doesn't look too aesthetically pleasing but the warm pudding suddenly made me realize I wasn't full just yet.... GODSMACKINGLY GOOD.What a food coma I had later. ZZzzzzzz!!! Price-tag is $$$$, expect to pay around $100 if you go for a few drinks, an app, a main and a dessert but it's entirely worth treating yourself to the PDC experience.

Foie gras overload -- in a great way! Love love love the food here. Everything is a tad rich though so you may end up feeling full/heavy despite not having a crazy amount of food. The duck in a can was sinful. The duck inside comes with a hunk of fat, and it's soo delicious. Also enjoyed the foie gras nigiri and poutine. The desserts was a tad too sweet -- but for someone who loves their sweets, it may not be a problem. Mainly talking about their chomeur pudding!

First meal when visiting Montreal! Very small but very accommodating for our 8 month old! We got the Cheung Fan Foie Gras, the Tripes and Tomatoes, and the Pork Chop! Pork chop was deliciousssss - moist and cooked just right. The tripes were ok - as an Asian-American they tasted a little weird since I'm used to having it in my pho. I also think they may have been cooked a bit funky because I had stomach issues right after eating it and then my husband finished the left overs a day later and had the same issues. Would highly recommend the foie gras though!Wine selection was amazing! Definitely would try other food options next time we are he

I made a reservation well in advance because I knew this was one of the places I for sure wanted to try in Montreal! There were only early dinner or late dinner times available, so we chose a 5:30pm slot.We were able to sit at the counter and watch the chefs in the open kitchen prepare the food.I only really came for the duck in a can, but the bf also wanted the sea whelks appetizer. Let me tell you. This food is BUTTERY, SAVORY, AND RICH. All good things of course. But prepare your stomachThey start you off with this delicious warm crispy bread. I could eat that every day- Sea whelks: a lot for what you pay for! Similar to escargot. They were bathed in butter and garlic yummm.  A little overcooked though- Duck in a can: plz get this if you come here. Seriously one of a kind dish!! but way too rich to share between only two people. We finished it, but felt a little gross after. They make the can in house, and it's filled with duck meat/fat, foie gras, onions and I'm not quite sure what else.. but they basically all bathe and cook together so the flavors combine and come out perfectly. The can is opened table-side and contents dumped onto a plate of toasted bread. I'm glad we were able to try something like this, but I think once is enough for me!

We finally had the chance to try this restaurant. We were a group of 9 and were here to celebrate various birthdays in the group. What an amazing dinner!  Everything was soooooo good and so fresh. Our server was excellent and very friendly and helpful.  As we were a large party, we had a reservation. It is a very busy place so it is recommended that a reservation be made. We also got a picture with the owner Martin Picard!This restaurant is known for its duck, pork and foie gras dishes. We decided to order a number of dishes and shared between the group. We ordered the Plogue a Champlain and it was sooo good that we ordered another one. This dish was a combination of sliced potatoes with bacon and a large piece of foie gras in a maple sauce. We also had the Cheong Fun filled with foie gras. The Cheong Fun texture was so thin and not sticky and was better than some Chinese restaurants and the foie gras just melted in your mouth.  The foie gras poutine has large pieces of foie gras and was very decadent. The foie gras nigiri was amazing and was my favourite dish. The soy sauce vinaigrette was the perfect match with the rice and foie gras. This totally melted in your mouth. This was so good that we ordered another one. We also had the picked pork tongue which was very good as well. For the main course, we ordered the Duck in a Can and the Stuffed PDC and Foie Gras. The Duck in. Can literally comes in a can which the server opens at the table into a bowl and has duck and foie gras. The Stuffed PDC is a deboned pork hock stuffed with meats with a large piece of foie gras on top with braised vegetables. These dishes were all excellent. We ended the dinner with a sugar pie, pecan pie and maple pudding chomeur (bread pudding). The desserts were really good and very sweet, especially the maple pudding. My favourite was the sugar pie. It was an awesome dinner and so glad that I had the chance to try it. Definitely worth a try if you like foie gras. I will definitely come back.

We came here after reading several recommendations and it was well worth it. The food is super rich so definitely share, we had a lot left over . There were 3 of us and we got the chicken liver mousse, the champvallon, and the duck in a can. All the flavors were so explosive and unique, it was truly amazing . I'm not a fan of food gras, but apparently this is the place to get it. Lastly we got the maple pudding which was so delicious. Definitely worth going to

Au Pied de Cochon is arguably a top 3 eating experience in North America. We started with the ham, which was the best ham we have had since returning from Spain. The duck in a can is everything you ever dreamed it would be. My wife had a scallop quinelle that rivaled a everything we had at a recent dinner at Le Bernadin.It was all that good, and in a vibrant casual atmosphere.

If you are in Montreal and you're not vegan/vegetarian, you absolutely must try Au Pied de Cochon. ...And be prepared to eat liver.Our favorites of the night:- Foie Cromequis - 2 bites of heaven, deep fried croquette of ooey gooey foie. - Foie Nigiri - with peanut butter sauce over sushi rice, it was definitely good and decadent. - Chicken Liver Mousse - amazing with the general drizzle of maple syrup. The charred bread & fresh butter was tastySkip:- Duck Carpaccio - This one was a Japanese shabu shabu style duck carpaccio with a Yeti thermal of dashi broth. The shaved duck was ice frozen and just a little weird. Although it tasted alright, it was not my favorite- Fries - they were a tad burnt. Perhaps if it was covered in gravy? No one would notice.4-4.5ish stars, but rounded up because it was easily the most memorable meal of our Montreal trip**It's a bit difficult to get a hold of them through the phone, so I emailed the restaurant directly for reservations and got a response.

I've always praised the food culture in Montreal - its one of the best place to go if you're a foodie. Of course, I've heard all about the reputation of Au pied de cochon - It's an establishment in Montreal. So when my meat-lover boyfriend came visit, we simply had to go.Everything from the service to the food was perfect. We had a reservation at 11:30 on a Saturday night, and even if the restaurant was packed (as usual), the staff was very attentive. We joked about how we couldn't tell who was our main server since the whole staff was taking care of us! The vibe is friendly and unpretentious, and you get such a great dining experience. One thing you should try at APC is foie gras - its on everything on their menu anyway! We shared the foie gras Poutine to have the whole French Canadian food experience. My boyfriend still dream about it! The foie gras just melts in your mouth and is so rich in flavour - trust me, it's definitely a must try! The cook even came to our table to serve the dish himself and explained how he made it. Like, wow. Such an experience. We then shared the squid ink risotto - my personal fav. Since the whole dish is black, you can't really tell what you're having until you taste it. But the freshness of the squid, mussels and scallops gives so much flavour to the dish, it's one of the best thing I've had in my life.If you're ever in Montreal or just want to have a dining experience you'll never forget - Au Pied de Cochon is definitely the place to go.

I can and will eat anything and everything, as long as it tastes good. Should I? Probably not, but if I could eat everything on the menu here, I definitely would. Their menu changes quite frequently, but they have fan favourites here on a steady basis (for the record, I've eaten here twice, once 11 years ago, and most recently, today lol): the foie gras poutine, plogue a champlain, PDC stuffed with foie, and duck in a can. I don't remember what I ate 11 years ago, but I do remember missing out on the duck in a can and I came back for it today.Five stars all around. Don't take any vegetarian or vegan friends here because it's not that kind of a restaurant (seriously, the name is literally "foot of the pig" so...) Meat heavy, very Canadian and Quebecois, and unapologetically rich-- this place is best shared amongst friends who will appreciate all the FOOD! (Seriously, there is an entire section dedicated just to foie gras.) This time around, my partner and I dined on (together and separately):- Plogue a champlain- Foie gras nigiri- Duck in a can- Veal Blanquette- Maple creme brulee- Maple pudding chomeurThe foie gras nigiri sounds blasphemous, but it is well-balanced. Foie gras on top of rice with a peanut sauce, and you are able to add small drops of ponzu along with it. I recommend it with the ponzu, as it adds a little salt and acidity along with the fat from the foie and the sweetness of the peanut sauce. This was recommended by the waiter, and I would definitely get it again. The plogue a champlain was the star, though. You'll read about it, but just get it. Trust me. Sweet and savory and RICH. Yum. I have been waiting 11 years to come back for the duck in a can and I wasn't disappointed. It is 1/2 a duck with foie gras, mixed with veggies and some bacon I think, cooked in a can-- similar to cooking it sous vide, for precisely 27 minutes. They open the can right in front of you and dump it on a plate. It is delicious and by far shareable. You should share it, seriously. I ate it by myself and honestly, it made me full af. My boyfriend's main was the veal blanquette and it was classically prepared-- he enjoyed it very much, but was full! While you're not coming here for the desserts, they do have a variety and the pudding chomeur was excellent. I would recommend it. It is sort of like bread pudding (with the maple cream syrup) meets shortcake. I would highly recommend it.I will be coming back to Montreal and definitely stopping at APC.

In this review I will cover 1. the heavenly food; 2. the incomparable experience; 3. the lingering desire to return.We made a reservation close to midnight, so we may have had some dinner beforehand (sue us, but we were hungry and Montreal has so many good restaurants). I don't follow the "food scene," but I felt as though we were suddenly at "where it all happens." We were seated and attended by a small army of waiters, servers, busboys. Everyone was constantly in a rush, but never hurrying. The kitchen was open-concept, meaning you could see the masters at work- mixing this and flipping that with absolute ease and style. The brass of the happy diners, the servers' woodwinds, the percussion of the kitchen, combined with the strings of my beautiful date completed a perfect evening with the orchestra. Which brings me to the food- the sweetest symphony you've ever heard. Beethoven's 9th.The complimentary bread was good, but we knew to stay away. We ordered the Foie Gras Poutine and Squid Ink Seafood Risotto. The poutine came first, and it was unlike anything I've tasted before. I love poutine, and this was among the best poutine I've ever tasted. The addition of foie gras (which pops in your mouth) shoots it into the mesosphere, and I was holding on for dear life. While my date apparently didn't like foie gras, even she couldn't help herself. 10/10.She had wine and I had beer. Complimented all the food very well.The seafood risotto came next. Creamy, rich, fresh, flavorful. Salty, but not too salty (disclaimer: I have a salt tooth). The ink turned our plate into an abyss. Our fork could not discriminate and so we had to rely on our senses to differentiate the different types of seafood: scallops, squid,  mussels. We couldn't finish the plate because we were so full, and when we reheated the risotto in the microwave the next day, it tasted even better. 11/10We absolutely regret eating before this meal. This food will ruin you for weeks; we still think about it two months later. The experience was invigorating.

Amazing food for any meat eater. Such richness will blow you away, come on an empty stomach. I can usually eat a lot of food but the sheer richness of each plate left me almost nauseous (in the best of ways)I had the French onion soup which was perfection. They also had some excellent bread, which I wiped up with the soup of course. We had foie gras poutine and the melting pot. The melting pot was a bowl of mashed potatoes with all kinds of beef on top: sausage, blood sausage, pork, beef, stuff I couldn't even identify. It was super filling and I felt like I had to crawl out.Another table had huge beef or pork piece brought out on a cart and cut tableside with special maple sauce. Looked amazing!I did not have desert but many passed our table and it looked just as good. Milkshake XXX would've been my pick.Service was so friendly and fast. Beautiful place. Prices are a bit steep, but, the quality is amazing. Fully recommend.

We were recommended this place while visiting Montreal and were glad we tried it. We made a reservation for a Saturday evening (recommended!) and the place was packed. The biggest mistake we made was ordering way too many foie gras-packed items on the menu - everything was very rich and heavy and we were stuffed after just a few dishes! I would highly recommend the foie gras nigiri and the duck in the can for two, and maybe the croquettes as well. The chicken liver pate was delicious but just way too much. And I would have skipped the cheong fun altogether.

Ever since I saw Anthony Bourdain literally eat the entire menu from Au Pied de Cochon, I knew I had to go to this restaurant. This place definitely has a wonderful vibe. Despite coming in on a Thursday night at 10:30 pm this place was buzzing. Great energy from the staff and fellow diners. The server was great and pretty much explained most of the dishes to us as it was our first time. We ended up getting the tartare temaki, the garlic foie gras, ploque au Champlain, and the pork chop.Tartare temaki - unique presentation, topped with a quail egg, order comes with 2 cones, amazing flavour, and a great starter, light in comparison to all the other dishesGarlic foie gras - roasted garlic, garlic croutons, garlic veloute, and of course the foie was melt-in your mouth amazingPloque au Champlain - my boyfriend loved this. He really enjoyed the sweetness of the maple syrup and the potatoes. Of course, topped with a heap of foie gras.Pork Chop - BEST chop I've ever had. It was cooked to absolute perfection. The portions were huge and great for sharing. But honestly, what made this dish special were the amazing button mushrooms. Not sure how it was prepared, but they were unbelievable.Prepare to nap hard after a meal here. It's heavy, creamy, fatty, and absolutely incredible. A must-do if you're ever in Montreal!

After over a decade of dining in this Iconic Montreal restaurant I thought it time to start fresh and rewrite a much overdue review of APDC.   Recommendations:Get a early reservation: this menu is heavy on the proteins and  rich sauces so you'll need time to work it off on a muchneeded stroll down St Denis with it's many cool shops and cafes. Reservations at prime time{6:30 to 8:30} are usually booked months in advance, get a 5:30pm res to maximize your chances of scoring a table and ask for a seat near the bar.... the energy is amazing!Take your time: Tables turn typically every 2 to 3 hours, so relax....get a good bottle, look around, make friends, savor your bread and butters, chat up the staff, ask questions....APDC is one of the happiest, friendliest and most accommodating Montreal restaurants around. Go for the specials. The standard menu is pared down to the bare essentials and long time favorites {Duck in a can and the Pied de Cochon is still on there even if my favorite melting pot is now history} The specials are very seasonal and a great value especially with all the Sugar Shack themed dishes {try the APDC ham from the shack with the fried pancakes with the APDC maple syrup.....It isn't prosciutto Folks but it's Picard's best and that's just as good if not better}.Please have the Onion Soup....It's life changing!APDC does not offer classic Francophile service. The tables have no white tablecloths and service is casual, friendly and efficientThis is a unapologetically loud, boisterous and frantic restaurant so get into the scene and eat with your fingers, drink and eat too much, laugh out aloud and feed your dinner companion...It's all good and part of the timeless charm of APDC.Au Pied De Cochon has become our benchmark when it comes to Quebecois cuisine and hospitality and in all the years we've dined there have yet to disappoint. I have always left APDC well fed with a great love for Montreal and it's people, culinary culture, love of life and just a bit tipsy.Go......You'll see what I mean.

This is my second draft. I first wrote a very detailed review but who wants to read all that?!? Below is the bullet points of my experience at the restaurant-finally booked a table for 10:30pm after 4 tries through out the year. I do not live in Montreal-asked to wait upon arrival to check if our table is ready. There were 4-5 empty and clean tables around-sat at our table and waited 10 mins for our server-drinks came one at a time. We ordered tea, teabag delivered, hot water took another 10 mins-appetizer, foie Gras Nigiri arrived. Wasn't informed there would be peanuts on it. -entree arrived. Mine was sitting on the counter for quite sometime. The sauce had already thickened on top. -we ordered a side of vegetables and it didn't come. Halfway through our entree, we tried to cancel the vegetables and our server said, it's coming in one minute. It took another 10 minutes. -Side order of vegetables was my favorite dish! I really really wanted to like this place, but everything went south. I travel to Montreal a lot for fun and the food and I was disappointed.

Anthony Bourdain visited Au Pied de Cochon in 2006 to shoot an episode of No Reservations. For this show the famed Chef Martin Picard told his cooks to "keep feeding him, and stop when he dies." I watched that episode and knew I had to visit this place some day.Au Pied de Cochon is Chef Picard's ode to gluttony, excess, and all things duck, pig, and cow. A richer more decadent meal cannot be found, an ironic fact in a city that regularly feasts on giant plates of poutine.You need to show up famished to the point of predatory, as the portions are not only large but the food is fortifying. Rare is the dish that doesn't include if not center around foie gras. You'll notice upon arriving that the decor is classic and charming, unassuming in its simplicity. It's a long, narrow space with lots of wood paneling and homey accents, including artwork from the staff. There's a mirror on one wall which makes the space look bigger and is also used for writing that day's food specials.A must here is the legendary Duck in a Can. It begins with a plate of toast and celery root puree accompanied by a branded Canard en Conserve can that has been sealed and boiled for exactly 27 minutes. Said can is opened at your table revealing a delectable combination of medium-rare duck breast, foie gras, carrots, braised cabbage, roasted garlic, sprigs of thyme, and balsamic demi-glace. In many dishes the vegetables would play second fiddle to the hearty protein and fatty goodness, but here they are essential toward creating a concoction that's tangy, rich, and sweet all at once. I prepared for this greatness with a small appetizer consisting of tuna belly and--wait for it--foie gras. The appetizer arrived on two mini-tree trunks held together by seaweed and skewers, with the intention being to wrap each piece individually and eat it like temaki. For dessert I went the non-foie gras route with a classic creme brûlée. I'm fairly certain that this was the 'healthiest' part of the meal, but by this point, who gives a f*ck.The service in Montreal's restaurants, including Au Pied de Cochon, is a marvel to behold. Watching our servers was like witnessing a graceful pas de deux. One person is responsible for your order and handles check-ins and questions while the other does the meal service and replenishes drinks and bread. Everything is timed perfectly among the two of them and the kitchen so you're never pressured to start or end a course before you're ready. Chef Picard himself was running around plating and serving dishes in between knocking back drinks, as one does.If you feel like you're going to die after eating here, that's all part of the intended experience. I would urge any visitor to the city to try Au Pied de Cochon at least once in their life, or many times if you're lucky.

This was one of the best meals I've ever had in my life. This place definitely lives up to the hype and my only regret is not having a big enough stomach to eat everything on the menu.My boyfriend and I got the duck temaki appetizer, duck in can, and crime brûlée. The temaki appetizer was so delicious! Duck tartar should definitely be more common in sushi. Great flavors and sauces mixed in with it.Let's talk about the main event though....DUCK IN A CAN. You would not believe the amount of flavor and quality they pack into this can. It's duck breast, foie gras, bacon, cabbage, and carrots. This is one of the most decadent meals I've ever had, but every bite was just pure bliss. The duck is perfectly cooked, the fat from the foie gras add great flavor, and balsamic mixes so well with every ingredient.The creme brûlée did not disappoint. It was a great texture and not overly sweet. The ambiance of the restaurant, presentation of the food, and quality of the food made it was of the best dining experiences I've ever had.
5 stars , best dining experience of 2019 for me ,I ordered the pdc pig platter with foie gras. Simply amazing

I have made two trips to Au Pied De Cochon. The first visit (Summer 2018) was memorable and the best Quebec food I have had. Even though there was a glitch and they didn't have my reservation on their books they seated me at the bar which was good enough. The atmosphere was jovial , couples and large families all happily enjoying the great food. The server had a lot of personality in the sense he declined to order everything I wanted to order as that would have been too much food. He also suggested the best options as this was my first visit. Also brought in an appetizer that was not on the menu. After that visit this had become my favorite restaurant.Next visit : Summer 2019. The atmosphere had changed. The restaurant looked empty and felt low energy. Just a few couples dragging on with their dates. The food was nothing to sing about. Me and my family were surprised that the quality of food was so average and below par for it's name.

If you do anything when you're in Montreal and your budget allows, visiting Au Pied de Cochon is a must. It is a perfect example of how wonderful Montreal is - the service is stellar and friendly, the food is great, and the vibe is the most chill.I had to get the foie gras poutine. Warning: this is one heavy freaking plate. So rich and decadent, this plate is loaded with cheese curds, hot gravy, perfectly browned french fries, and big fat pieces of foie gras. For less than $30, it's well worth the price. I paired with a nice glass of Riesling but they have a fully stocked bar and can make you just about anything. This is a great place for a slightly fancier meal and a completely empty stomach.

I made sure to grab a reservation in advance just to avoid any crazy lineups.I have to say, you really should come here if you want to try foie gras since their menu is primarily composed of dishes containing foie gras. We ordered the foie gras poutine and the duck in a can. While we waited for our dishes to arrive, the server brought us a plate of warm bread with butter. I really love restaurants that do this since I'm not a fan of waiting for dishes to arrive. I very much enjoyed the complimentary appetizer. Our poutine was served first. It was essentially the classic plate of poutine topped with slabs of foie gras. This was honestly the BEST poutine I have ever eaten. It was so rich and the gravy was very smooth. The foie gras was very rich and creamy. I had to stop myself from licking the plate as we were in a public dining area. Afterwards, we were brought the "Duck in a Can." The server opened the can at our table which in itself was a nice little show as he carefully constructed the dish using the contents in the can. The dish had what seemed like stewed vegetables, roasted garlic, duck, foie gras, and bread. It was such a beautifully presented dish that also brought a huge pack of flavour. I absolutely loved the richness of the dish. Coming here was such a special treat! I thoroughly enjoyed the food and service of the restaurant.

If you consider yourself a foodie and a Montrealer, and you've never been here, then you are missing the boat on THE culinary experience. There's nowhere like PDC in the world and it is truly a taste of Quebec's finest cuisine terroir. Unpretentious atmosphere and always superb service accompanies dishes that are all to die for. From the foie-gras cromesquis, duck in a can, foie-gras and boudin tarte, bison ribs to their rotating selection of super original and delicious appetizers, you can't go wrong. Do yourself a favour and go...NOW! Actually you can't. You'll need to reserve a couple of weeks in advance to get a table.Update: hadn't been for over a year and was craving some PDC goodness. Went last night and I have to say, and I didn't think it was possible, but my meal was thoroughly disappointing. Everything was  lacklustre including the service. Every dish we had was not  even close to as good as all of my experiences in the past. I left feeling rather dissatisfied. I truly hope this was just an off night, because I wouldn't accept another performance liKe that.

When visiting Montréal, we always make Au Pied de Cochon a dining destination. I remember first watching Anthony Bourdain's No Reservations years ago and saw all the rich and interesting food they offer. Now years later I've dined here several times and have many delicious meals offered up by these talented chefs. Anyone going here knows that they are big on the foie gras. So much that there is a separate section in the menu for foie gras entrees. I usually start my meal with the foie gras cromesquis. These a little bites of rich liquid where the foie gras are cut into cubes and then quickly fried. My husband who is usually a picky eater even liked it. Of course the restaurant is known for the PDC cut and the famous duck in a can meals. The PDC cut is a huge cut of the shoulder that is cooked with mushrooms and cabbage in a savory sauce. This is easily shared between two people. The duck in the can is one of my favorites. Not just because of the cool theatrics and presentation of the duck and foie gras being opened from the can and poured on the mash and veggies, but the richness of the flavors.The staff is always very friendly here and happy to make suggestions or answer any questions. If you decide to make this place a dining destination, it's best to make reservations because they are quite busy and it's rare to be able just to get a table walking in. It has been easier now to make a reservation since they now have an online system to place one. This is super helpful living outside of Canada. Can't wait to return again.

I generally do not expect places like this to live up to the hype, but this one did. We started with the foie gras terrine as a starter and was the best terrine I've ever eaten. The terrine was smooth, with the right temperature and consistency. There was a strong savory foie gras flavor to it and the presentation was smart. There was a thick sweet sauce that accompanied it, which I can best describe it as a maple-flavored dulce de leche, was smooth and rich. The duck breast with mushrooms and potatoes was excellent, as the duck as cooked nicely. The fat was generally rendered off so it wasn't too greasy, and the mushrooms added more savory flavor.The infamous duck-in-a-can was surprisingly good, as the flavors melded together without much trouble. The combination of juicy duck breast and foie gras made for an indulgent combination. I thought the duck would be overcooked but it was pink in the middle. The cabbage and bacon was okay too, but mostly filler.Service was patient and warm, despite the fact that my French is quite rudimentary. They actually complimented it, to which I was shocked. (RIP, Anthony Bourdain)

Pied de cochon is one of the most representative restaurants of Quebec culture. This was our third time here and it was our best experience yet. Although we had a reservation they didn't have a table free but they were working hard to get us one. We were seated about 30 minutes later on the terrace.  We were not upset at all about the delay but they insisted on making up for it by bringing us a complimentary bottle of beer as an appératif, fried zucchini flowers stuffed with ricotta and fried foie gras cubes! Absolutely unnecessary but they insisted. We ordered so many incredible dishes to share and had such a good time. We were 5 people and they suggested that 3 appetizers, 3 mains and 3 desserts would be sufficient. We appreciated their honesty because we were going to order much more. Appetizers: The homemade burratta dish was my favourite  but the tomato tart and plogue Champlain (seared foie gras with melted cheese and a maple syrup sauce) were also excellent. Mains: the tarte boudin was very unique and the trout was really delicious. It was served with a Boston lettuce salad and the two together were delicious.Desserts: there were too many great choices but we went with pouding chômeur, the begnets and homemade ice cream. Their ice cream is just exceptionable! It is a soft serve and its the perfect end to a rich meal. If it wasn't unreasonable, I would have ordered 3 ice creams!We love PDC, if you are passing through Montreal this is the place you need to eat at!

Excellent is an understatement. During our trip we dined here as well as Joe Beef. Hands down, this was our favorite meal. My husband ordered the duck in a can, which lived up to the hype. I ordered the melting pot and the house made kielbasa was unlike any other I've had. Incredibly flavorful.We had a special appetizer with four Gras, pork, cheese and maple syrup. I can't even describe it except to say it was perfect.Shared the maplewood syrup pie for dessert and couldn't finish it, despite trying.  Highly recommend the maple gin cocktail as well. We'll be back the next time we return to Montreal.

Great service + great food!Earliest seating at 5pm at this famous restaurant. Ordered Maple Old Fashion and Maple Gin & Champagne cocktails to start #maplecocktails They served us this house made bread delivered from their own sugar shack daily #bestbreadeverDuck tartare temaki, toasted stuffed pork foot with mushroom cream sauce cheese-curd mash potato & seared foie gras, maple bread pudding. We had to book our return meal on Friday as our last meal in Montreal right away after tasting these.The epitome of #montrealfood ....#ducktartare #pieddecochon #chomeur

Ok, let's get one thing straight... you don't go to Pied De Cochon for healthy food. Not even healthy-ish. So this is why I was never gonna go here knowing that yes it will be really good but it will probably kill me.... But the morning of Anthony Bourdain passing, reading the news got me thinking it'd be nice to pay homage so I made a reservation.I love the unpretentious way of this place. It was very easy-going. The staff is friendly & helpful. The menu is foie gras dominant. We took a Plogue de Champlain, a Tarte de Boudin & Foie Gras, butter & herbs snails and a roasted veggies dish (yes, to balance it out, it was necessary) Everything was delicious. I don't really know what else to say because I cannot defend the fat side of things and I expected it. Sometimes u just gotta sit back and enjoy it for what it is. Like Anthony Bourdain said: "Your body is not a temple, it's an amusement park. Enjoy the ride"I can't say that I would come back here again volunterily, for the sake of my artery. I would go again though, with others who want to taste this food. If you haven't been, I definitely recommend it :)

this is a montreal institution and a must go if you are ever in town. they are closed mondays and tuesdays, so make sure to make your reservations and plan accordingly. i highly recommend sitting at the open kitchen bar where you can watch the talented kitchen in action. if you're looking for a light meal, look elsewhere. the food at this place is RICH. i ordered the foie gras comequis, which were small hors d'ouvres croquettes filled with a foie gras puree. you may want to devour in one bite as if you bite half, the foie gras filling will come squirting out. my curiosity got the better of me and this is exactly what happened. delicious though. their table bread and butter were pretty good as well. the charcuterie from the shack was thinly sliced ham, think prosciutto, and was accompanied by delicious pancakes that were fried in duck fat. delicious. did i mention this place was rich?finally, my main course, which i couldn't resist, the duck in a can was served. the waitress presented it as best food cooked in a can could be as it was magnificently (kinda grossly) plopped onto my plate. nothing gross about this dish though as it was a great, rich balance of duck breast and foie gras. this is exactly what i came to au pied de cochon for. delicious and perfectly cooked. the staff was equally friendly in both english and french. the martinis were well crafted, and i enjoyed myself as a solo diner here. highly recommend APDC as one of the highlights of the bright montreal food scene. must go!hope to be back sooner than later.

I was super excited to come here after hearing about all of the good reviews, and I was definitely not disappointed!Food: 5The quality of each of the unique dishes was visible in presentation. The portions were sizeable as well!The duck platter came out of the can fresh and PERFECTLY cooked.The fries were extremely crispy, chewy, and juicy!Service: 5The servers are bi-lingual and speak English fluently. It was very helpful for us to hear in detail about each of the dishes they had to offer. Lovely and friendly people!Ambiance: 3Very busy and loud, as well as a bit cramped for space.Overall lovely visit but it was definitely a bit pricey. Expect to pay a pretty penny for the good food!
We enjoyed our time at Au Pied de Cochon.  Sit inside or out in a casual atmosphere.The food, wine, and cocktails are quality ingredients and presentation of food was above average.

I wasn't so so excited about a "foie gras" restaurant when my fiancé first mentioned it to me...he's the big meat/foie gras lover while I enjoy small bits of it here and there but find a chunk of seared foie gras to be just too much for me.BUT, Au Pied de Cochon really won me over and I ended up being the one to push for us to go back a 2nd time on our 4 day visit in Montreal!We went first on Friday night after arriving into the city...it was crowded and loud even at 1130pm but everything was delicious and great with the exception of a small hiccup where we waited 45 min between dishes and the waitress never came by to update us nor apologize etc despite us trying to get her attention a few times...The second visit was Sunday night after having JUST finished eating at Maison Boulud...YES, we ate a full dinner (as in ordering over 12 dishes there) not 30 min before arriving to Au Pied de Cochon around 1130pm!Our server (I'm horrible with names but a jolly happy guy with a mustache?) was AMAZING and so so friendly and nice...he even made a bowl of rice happen cos we LOVE their Mapo Tofu dish with foie gras pieces in it...it sounds very crazy...cos being Chinese and having traveled extensively and eaten everywhere from hole in the wall to Michelin star Chinese restaurants all over the world...Au Pied's mapo tofu was HANDS DOWN ONE OF THE BEST MAPO TOFUS I've ever had in my life! And for me, it wasn't even because of the foie gras chunks in there, but the sauce and seasoning was just perfect balance of heat/spice and flavor!And the Ploque a Champlain was so so good thanks to the wonderful mix of maple syrup with foie gras and yummy bread...so so sweet and so so good!We're not usually so into "lively/loud/hipster" places but we really found the vibe to be warm and family like at Au Pied and esp on the second night, our server was so engaging and nice, he really made it that much more special of a memory for us.Please also open a branch in LA!

Finally got to have the foie gras poutine! It was a little pricey but worth every penny! It was as delicious as everyone said! It literally melted in your mouth. There were so many delicious items on the menu that it was hard to decide. I almost took their papardelle but our waitress highly recommended the poutine when I asked her which one I should chose between the two. I definitely want to go back to try the onion soup and a few other item.

Au Pied de Cochon (the pigs feet) is one of Montreal's signature eating establishments alongside Joe Beef.  With a heavy emphasis on meat products, especially foie gras, it's popular with locals and tourists alike.  Reservations are recommended, which we did, but they were extremely accommodating when we stopped by very early and decided to change our original much later reservation. Walking by the street, I almost missed the restaurant as there's only a menu posted outside and not much signage, but go where everyone is dining and you'll be at the right shop.  The interior is modern and clean with friendly wait staff and a nice bar area with seating as well. The ambiance is noisy with conversations while quick food service keeps the mood fun and enjoyable.  The menu is straightforward with appetizers, main entrees, and dessert listed on a single page with an entire section devoted to foie Gras.  Everything sounds delicious and the waiter was happy to explain anything we didn't know as well as the handful of daily specials.  Our order:Maple Foie Gras Comesquis - $8.  What a great start with these bite sized appetizers of deep fried dough around molten foie Gras. Served quite hot, you simply pop them into your mouth and enjoy the explosion of richness and flavor.  Mmmmm.Onion Soup - $15.  I'd been craving a excellent rendition of this French classic and Au Pied delivered.  It's covered with melted cheese but has plentiful rich and savory broth that includes onions but also another unique spin with delicious pieces of aged ham that add both flavor and meatiness to this great soup.  So good and perfect for sharing.  Carpaccio - $16.  You see this dish at many places but the uniqueness here is that the meat of choice is duck meat.  Rare pieces of thinly sliced duck meat are served on a generous platter with thin slices of cheese and a single perfectly poached egg yolk that you break and spread over the carpaccio.  Delicious and a nice contrast to the richer items on the menu. Tartare Tataki - $15. I almost didn't order this but am so glad I did.  It's literally a hand roll served with their choice of Tartare and a quail egg that you pour on top.  Our evening it was horse Tartare and you're either in or out when it comes to horse meat (and most Montreal residents are in) and after my delicious horse entree at Joe Beef, I was in.  It was delicious with a beefy Tartare that is as good as any hand roll I've had.  Delicious. Plogue a Champlain - $31.  Alongside the foie Gras Poutine, this is one of Au Pied de Cochon's signature foie gras dishes.  Since I was all "poutines out", this dish was a perfect choice for us.  It's a pancake, covered in pig lard, and topped with a huge piece of cooked foie Gras and maple syrup.  The French description admittedly sounds more appetizing than the description but it's a delicious mix of savory and sweet with rich and starchy.  After a few bites, I quickly began to feel satiated. Duck In a Can - $44. After so many delicious starters, ordering an entree clearly put us over the top but how could we come without ordering this signature dish.  The dish is exactly as described.  A duck leg combined with foie gras, bacon, cabbage and spices is literally canned and heated in the can to be dumped on top of a plate of puréed butternut squash and two baguette slices.  The amazing thing is that you'd expect something to be either overcooked or undercooked but everything, and I mean everything, comes out perfectly.  The duck was medium rare and well flavored.  The foie Gras was cooked and soft as nicely as the other Plogue dish.  The cabbage and bacon were hearty and mixed well with all the juices from both.  This dish is great for sharing and even-so is pure gluttony.  Very unique, very good and very memorable. Overall, I'm so happy to have stopped by Au Pied De Cochon.  I left ecstatic and satiated on the buzz of the great cocktails but also the richness of the food.  All the dishes were so unique yet consistent and well done.  I'm not sure I'll eat foie Gras again this year but I'm happy to have spent my yearly (lifetime?) quota here.  Thank you Au Pied de Cochon, especially for accommodating our earlier dinner time.  I slept very well. Au Pied de Cochon accepts credit cards including Amex.

Filling, decadent, tasty meal.We stopped by as a party of three at 9 PM on a Friday evening and still had to wait around 20 minutes to get seated, which was a bit of a mess since the entryway is small (it's also where people exit), and there was a long line of people waiting. The service or reservation system seems like it could be improved as there were plenty of people waiting for this seating and no one visibly worried that there was a long line of people at this hour, but the service was overall okay once we were seated.For our meal, we had the beef tongue, poutine, and duck in a can, all of which were quite tasty. The foie gras goes surprisingly well in the poutine, which is a heavier dish already, and the duck was very well prepared and is sauced deliciously. It's definitely worth checking out if in the area.

Definitely been waiting for the opportunity to try this restaurant for a long time, and so glad I did! We went with a party of four and was seated promptly with our reservation. The staff was very accommodating of the fact that a couple of us came later than the others. The food was absolutely excellent. We started with the salmon temaki and the duck temaki which were excellent, followed by two other appetizers. We then shared the meat pie and the duck in a can as well. This was an abundance of food for four; the food as others mention is extremely rich and heavy but still very delicious and flavorful. The stand out dish of the night was the duck in a can; it simply is a must try and a staple dish of the restaurant. It's a bit strange watching the waiter open the can with a can opener in front of us and empty its contents onto the plate, but the end result is excellent. The mixture of flavors is an exquisite balance of sweet and savory combined with the duck cooked to perfection.  Definitely recommend this restaurant highly for those interested in a fine taste of québécois food!

I had one of the best dining experiences of my life here for my anniversary. Not only was the food amazing, the staff was so kind and fun and made us feel special and well attended to. We ordered the pigs foot because how could you not. As well as a side and an amazing bottle of wine. I can't wait to go back! I recommend this place to everyone that visits.

We chose this spot as the first meal we had in Montreal because I had read it was an essential Québécois restaurant. I struggle with this 4 star rating because the food was very delicious but the service was not. We waited long to get seated (with a reservation), we waited almost 20 min to have a waiter come to us, we waited long for just about everything. The only thing that was prompt  and attentive was the refilling of our waters.BUT and it's a big BUT, the food was very good. And at the end of the day you come to a restaurant to eat! So... we got the Poutine and some Foie Gras dish I forgot the name of. Both very good and rich as you would imagine. I got the Duck in a Can for the entree which was a very impressive signature dish. They crack the can open and pour out the unctuous contents inside revealing a perfectly cooked duck breast and foie gras, braised with other ingredients like carrots. Since it's not pan-seared like most duck dishes I've eaten there was a massive layer of duck fat that I couldn't eat, which felt wasteful cause duck fat is liquid gold! My friends got The Melting Pot which was a dish of a variety of sausages and meats atop a bed of velvety mashed potatoes. I tried the blood sausage from it and it was melt-in-your mouth good. Everything was super rich but that's just the nature of the cuisine. So don't expect some "balanced" dish with a side salad to offset the richness. You come here to fill yourself with stick-to-your-rib Québécois food and feel warm inside. They know what food they want to serve and they do it very well.

World class service , they gave our table a round of maple liquor on the house!  The blood sausage was out of this world. The foie gras poutine was decadent . This place caters to the savory and I'd come back to Canada just to eat here .

Really incredible and unpretentious dining experience. The service was wonderful and we loved trying the variations of foie gras. My favorite dishes were the venison hand rolls and the PDC! The PDC is a great big serving, perfect for sharing for 2 maybe 3 people. The cocktails were also bomb! The venison handroll was crazy, original, amazing. It came with a quail egg so that you could poor the yolk into the handroll. Completely to die for. My only regret coming here is that I wish my appetite was larger because I would have liked to try everything else on the menu as well.Such a welcoming and warm restaurant to visit after being in the cold. The cocktails were also inventive and tasty.

I ordered a few appetizers (duck carpaccio, tartare temaki and an onion soup). The waiter told me it would be more than enough food because their appetizers run on the larger side.  Then, the guy sitting next to me orders the poutine and it smells un-freaking-believable. I lean over.  "Hey, bud, how is it?"The guy looks at me and says,"It's the best poutine I've ever had. "Sold. I flag a server down and put in my order.  YOLO, right? Meanwhile,  my food starts trickling in. The duck carpaccio is what dreams are made of.  I cant sing enough praises over how mouth- wateringly delicious each slice of duck heaven was. The tartare temaki was not really what I was expecting; it's a sushi cone with tartare in the middle. Very filling due to the rice,  but so good.  The little quail egg yolk was a nice touch.  At this point, I'm thinking to myself,"Oh crap, I'm going to be too full for that poutine." The guy next to me is complaining about how full he is.  (while the poutine is advertised as a "side", my friends,  I assure you this is more like a dish and a half.  It's a full plate of fries and gravy goodness.) Next to arrive was the onion soup.  Sadly,  I was not a fan of the onion soup. It was loaded with lots of chunks of bread that tasted burnt. I prefer my onion soup to be loaded with cheese instead.  The broth itself had a nice taste to it,  and there was quite a bit of onions in the soup. The poutine arrives while I'm eating my soup. I look at it. There's no way in hell I'll be finishing this.  I mean, I'm so full,  I'm almost at the point where the mere sight of food makes me nauseous.  Anyway,  I feel obligated to eat a little of it while it's fresh.  Nothing special.  The guy next to me lied. The popular poutine shop nearby is just as good,  if not better. The fries are crisp, but the cheese just sits in the gravy unmelted, which lost points with me.  Gravy not bad, a smidge on the salty side.  I liked the flavor of the gravy at the other shop. Small cozy space.  Reservations are a must. Tables are close together,  as are the seats at the bar.  So in summary,  food isn't bad, but not consistent in their delivery.  Service sucks; they're too busy to be very attentive, they just take your order and clear your table.  Took me 10 minutes to flag someone down for the bill.

Overall - great place to go if you love or would like to try québécois dishes. I also was impressed by the variety of  foie gras dishes to choose from. While it was fun trying the regional cuisine, flavor wise it was very heavy across the board and there were a few misses. I would still recommend this place to anyone trying to explore and learn the regional foods. Just make sure to make reservations in advance but if you can't make it, I'm sure there are many other alternatives around.Pros - the cromesquis was a perfect starter to the meal. One bite size of warm foie-gras infused gravy delight trapped in soft and pillowy donut-like bread. It really got our appetites going and we looked forward to the rest of the meal.The Foie gras poutine was very delicious and contrary to our concern of it being too heavy (gravy + cheese + fries + Foie gras = rich rich rich), the buttery Foie gras added a nice smooth finish as well as the Foie gras aroma without overpowering the dish.The charcuterie was a good balance of flavors - the cake was too sweet buy itself and the ham was too savory by itself. Combined together, it was a great counteract against each other and created a very enjoyable experience.Cons - the duck carpaccio just didn't work for us. It had smoked duck with pickled cucumbers, chives, raw mushroom, raw duck egg on top that was supposed to be eaten together with a warm bouillon. On paper, it should be hitting all of the flavor profiles but it just didn't come together. Everything tasted separately instead of tasting like a cohesive dish and i would not recommend this dish. The bouillon tasted just like any normal tempura dipping sauce so that was a big disappointment.And lastly just a personal taste, but the terrine has a very famed/livery finish and it could be a hit for someone who love lovers but not for me.

Pork and foie gras and blood sausage, oh my!! Went two nights while in Montreal.  Best poutine (with foie gras) we had in Montreal.  Ate far too much both trips, but with so many wonderful things to try, worth the pain after.  Excellent service, and lucky enough to have the same waiter both nights.  I had not eaten blood sausage previous to this and promptly fell in love with the texture and the spiced flavor; had it in the can with foie gras and in the melting pot dish. Highly recommend the melting pot dish as you get a little bit of all the meats they serve including boudin.  One of my other favorites here was the foie gras tacos, an interesting take! Also ate the duck in the can with foie gras and the PDC cut; these were both very heavy dishes, and I was over stuffed!  If you want to have a mouth'gasm and enjoy rich and fatty foods, a definite must.

tl;drA Montreal institution. Foie heaven.---Every single visit to Montreal for us begins at APC. Every. single. visit. This is a restaurant where you either get it or you don't. It is foie and meat heaven to the max, so if you don't like meat, "heavy" food, or only eat salads, I'm not sure what you will be able to eat here. However, if you're able to indulge in the goodness of hearty meats done exceedingly well in the Quebecois tradition, then there's really no restaurant quite like it.We've been coming here since 2014 and it's amazing how their basic menu has stayed almost exactly the same -- a testament that they are proud of what they do and they know they do it well.They always have a rotating menu of specials which we have found increasingly more and more intriguing each time we return, so we almost always get something from the specials menu and those recommendations have been excellent. If this is your first time, all the foie dishes are good and get their namesake dish just to see what it's like (warning: it's big enough for 4 essentially if you want to eat other things, but you can always pack it to go! My favorite memory here was when we sat next to someone who came in, ordered the PDC for herself, ate about half of it, and then packed the rest for her flight back to the US (is that allowed? lol)). Their frites fried in duck fat is out of this world -- almost the best duck fries I've ever had (interestingly enough #1 is from a random sandwich place in Cincinnati). As an aside, they actually have amazing baguettes that they'll keep bringing you (with decadent butter!) throughout the meal! If only I had like three stomachs so I can eat a whole stick of it...X___XSometimes I think of APC as an institution heralding the beginning of the nouveau celebrity chef movement. When APC was founded in 2001, Anthony Bourdain has not started hosting shows yet (his featuring of the restaurant on the show in 2006 helped introduce APC to international audiences) and Michelin guides did not exist in the Americas yet (2005). Many of the prominent celebrity chefs now were still establishing their footing or in varying stages of training during that time (almost 20 years ago!). APC has truly withstood the test of time.ps. Since they implemented an online reservation system it has been a lot easier to secure seats compared to the days of old when you had to show up first thing when they open in the hopes of finagling a table for later on in the evening (you can still do that now -- they save at least a 1/4 of the restaurant it seems for walk-ins, but the spots go quickly!)

Very unique restaurant specializing in Pork.  The flavors are incredible.  Must try an appetizer called Charcuterie from the Shack...basically donuts & salted ham drenched with Canadian maple syrup...Yum!For entree we shared the Melting Pot with an incredibly delicious side of Green Beans Almandine (of course in maple syrup!).

It was my SO birthday so we decided to come here to celebrate. We made reservations about a month in advance to make sure we could get seated (suggestions from his friend as this place gets booked). We had the foie gras poutine, chicken liver pate, and duck in a can. Everything was extremely rich and filling so it was hard to get through the entire meal (in a good way). To start, we had fresh bread and butter that did not stop coming. I guess that didn't help with the fullness that I felt during the meal...I'm a sucker for bread. The foie gras poutine was amazing and I don't even like foie gras. I don't think you could compare this poutine to that of La Banquise. Just get it, you won't regret it. Duck in a can seemed to be a fan favorite. The duck was decadent and tender. The vegetables were perfectly cooked, infused with the duck fat and juices. I would definitely go again but maybe fast the day before.

Amazing food and amazing customer service. Poutine was great. After ordering our entree we realized that we had waited a long time before it arrived. After asking the server for the wait time, he told us that we were next to be served. Soon after, the manager came over to apologize for the wait and told us that our order had been mixed up, thus why the wait time was longer than usual. HE WENT EVEN FURTHER to tell us that the entree would be on the house.. not to mention that they gave us an amazing plate of pasta (with oxtail), small appetizer of molten foie gras and dessert too. They went above and beyond to correct the wait time, which was phenomenal!I wish I had tipped more (please contact me if possible!! @aupieddecochon). I would go back 10/10. Be sure to make a reservation first.

Came here with a party of three on a Thursday evening and the server was kind enough to squeeze us in and seat us right away. Wine was great. Food was just alright considering the price. Ordered the charcuterie, onion soup and melting pot. Overall the food is very rich and was a bit too salty for our taste so we couldn't finish some of the plates.

It is hard to come to Au Pied de Cochon if you don't like foie gras (goose liver) because literally 80% of the dishes have foie gras in some capacity. If you are visiting Montréal and want to check two items off your Canada bucket list in one go, get the Foie Gras Poutine. It will be a stark difference from the poutines you may have had before and will have after that day due to the sheer perfection of the ingredients and the best gravy you will ever have. They have some daily specials, each one of which could compete to get on the daily menu easily. The cannelloni entrée was absolutely perfect. So much was going on in that dish that bewildered my palate and, like everything else on the menu, so heavy it was that it was hard to finish on my own. The sweetness of the sauce meshed absolutely perfect with the saltiness of the pork and duck.Finally, the dessert. Despite what its name suggests, the Maple Poudding Chômeur is no poor man's pudding. This amazing dessert is heavy and sugary and just so bad for you, yet you want to eat it anyway. The cake is shaped like an island and is covered by a sea of maple butter. The sugariness of the gooey maple will make the blood rush to your head, yet every bite will keep you interested. The service was superb. It is not everyday I go to fancy restaurants like this and I neither looked like the wealthiest nor the classiest customer, but the waiting staff made me feel welcome and took an absolute care in handling all my plates. Our bilingual waitress explained each dish to us carefully and offered her helpful advice in picking the dishes, which we heeded. This restaurant has been a bucket list item for me for over 2 years and I am glad to have finally checked it off my list. You should too.

This is the best meal we have had in Montreal. We lucked out at getting a table with no reservation on a Wednesday night at 6:00 pm. We saw they make their own gin. Asked them to make a drink with the gin. It was great with ginger beer, mint, lime. Started with the Plogue a Champlain that had foie gras, bacon and maple syrup. Loved the sweet salty combo. My favorite dish. Next appetizer with beef tongue. So tender. And then the duck (not the one if the can). It was so much food for two people!  So tender, tasty and lean. The mix with the caramelized onions was so good. This place was a gem. Can understand the high ratings. A must eat when in Montreal.

What an exceptional evening. We were in town for the F1 GP. This was a priority stop for us. We made reservations 3 months in advance.  The food is everything that everyone says. Exceptional! What made our evening so special was the attentive and personal service we received. Our server was exceptional! I only wish I could remember her name! At the end of the evening we were thanking her for such a wonderful experience and that's when she revealed that it was only her second shift as a server.That you for making our evening so special

In Montreal for work and was told this was the spot to visit. I made my reservation, got there early, and was seated at the bar promptly. And then I waited. And waited some more. Finally I got some water. And then some more. And then even more. Then a beer. And you get the point. I get it, they were busy. But the one guy could've just taken my order, I already knew what I wanted. But he seemed more concerned about getting the larger tables than cater to the solo dude at the bar. It wasn't until finally, the girl helping behind the bar came over and took my order. Once she took my order, things went pretty smoothly. The bread they give is divine. It's soft in the inside and crunchy on the outside. I don't even like bread but it went so well with their butter. This was followed by their bone marrow and caviar. The waitress made it sound like it was two little sticks. It was not. Holy meat butter goodness. The foie burger took awhile to assemble and I could see the whole thing happening since they have an open kitchen. This place is pure controlled chaos. It's amazing how everyone knows what to do with so much going at once. I probably lost 10 years of my life eating this burger but it did not disappoint. It's a better burger than both Minetta's and 4 Charles. I'll come to Canada just for that damn burger.

The menu at Au Pied de Cochon is very unique and centers around pork dishes. The menu currently had lots of Foie Gras options for those who enjoy it.
