The Foie Gras poutine was actually really good and so was the Cormesquis.  I ordered the Squid Ink Rissotto; if you're a seafood lover you will enjoy this... me, just wanted tp try something out of my comfort zone, didn't love it. I've included pics of my friends meals.  Prices were on the higher side but considering this restaurant has such a high rating, the prices match up.
I've been here several times and always leave stuffed.  The food is rich and the flavors are bold.  It's a bit pricy, but you get what you pay for.  The service is excellent.  MAKE RESERVATIONS....

This was my least favorite meal in Montreal which is really disappointing since it was the only reservation I made (3 mos in advance) and came highly recommended. I booked it prior to learning I was pregnant so obviously came for all of their great menu items, but figured I'd still be able to find a pasta and eat the duck in a can or other.Just as an FYI for pregnant women avoiding rare meat, raw egg, mayo, etc - pickings are slim but I was able to find some items. The PDC mashed potatoes were the best I've ever had. Overall, however, dishes were ok. We ordered halibut fish and chips (decent but huge portion), squid ink risotto (salty), almond green beans (ok), and maple creme brûlée (super good). I was so disappointed to learn I couldn't order the duck in a can since it was served rare. Also, the menu seems to change and they only have what's on there. Our reservation was for Sunday at 7:30pm, a few dishes were already gone and I overheard a lot of items I would've wanted to eat were gone by around 9pm so would recommend aiming for an earlier slot if there's something in particular youRegardless of how the food was, which I would've given a 4, my review is heavily focused on our waiter. Which was a shame because everyone else was extremely nice. It seemed if you didn't jive with his rapport of being loud and obnoxious, he didn't give you the time of day. When we spoke to him, he didn't even care to pay attention or give us eye contact and would talk over our table to talk to the tables drinking that he was schmoozing to check in on them. I don't care for being checked in on during a meal, but compared to tables around us, we got a fraction of the service and it was really obvious. He even forgot to put in our dessert order.Like I said, pretty shocked since this restaurant was hyped. Our waiter was definitely a buzz kill to our last night in Montreal.

I suppose this place is either racist, classist or incompetent. We walked in and asked for a table for two around 6:30pm, but were told they were full and nothing was available. We asked if we could make a reservation and come back later but were told no. The whole response from the hostess was so unconvincing that we decided to check online if we could reserve a table and viola! We were able to book a table for that same evening at 10pm. We returned and asked if the reservation was valid: yes it was. We were told that it is because they don't normally accept walk-ins, which really sounded insincere to us. My partner and I are tourists hoping for a memorable time, but instead felt like we were discriminated against. The hostess offered no options whatsoever and was simply disappointing. We ended up walking a few blocks down to L'Express where the host was more accommodating, he was able to look up the next available reservation and happily offered it to us.We understand that this is a popular restaurant and it may be difficult to get reservations. But in this day in age, I do not believe we should have been treated the way we were.

We had heard so much about this place, we had to try it for ourselves! Was absolutely delicious. The Shepard's pie was by far our favorite. The foie gras nigiri was also delicious. Good vibes, cosy atmosphere. Book early!

Never have I ever been to a restaurant that was so proud of the fat content in their food before I came here. Each dish was more decadent than the last. Everything was outstanding and I left knowing that I indulged in the right place. We made our reservation about a month or so in advance and I definitely recommend you do the same as it is a rather small place and was crazy busy on a Tuesday night. The restaurant itself is modest and charming. It's a long, narrow room with a bar in the front and a wine cellar in the back. We sat in the back so it was a little cozier and not as bustling. We had to ask our waiter for a thorough run down on the menu and his recommendations on everything from dishes to how much to order. He was so helpful, spent a good amount of time with us and was very sweet. This place is famous for their Duck in a Can. We didn't order it but nearly every table around us did. It looked delicious pouring out of the can (they open it at the table). There was just too much else on the menu that I wanted to try and it had the feel of something more novelty and theatrical than just down right tasty,. Maybe I'm wrong, though. But on to food that I actually ate. We started with just classic foie gras which came with toasted french bread. I couldn't believe how much I loved it. You are going to have a lot of heavy, creamy dishes here. I liked starting with something tasty but simple. We also got the Ploque de Champlain, layers of potato slices, Canadian bacon, foie gras, pancake, and maple glaze... oh my god. Easily the best thing I ate that night. We had a few other appetizers and shared an entree and it was plenty. I can't recall the names of the other dishes. We ended this insane meal with pouding chômeur à l'érable - a cake kind of biscuit with house made maple syrup. Believe it or not, I really didn't love it. It just tasted like a biscuit or scone sitting in a very sweet sugar sauce. I would and hopefully will definitely return one day. It will be so hard to order other appetizers and entrees but I know I want to see the rest of this impressive menu. And I can't wait to try a different dessert because I am sure I'll love nearly everything else.

Always an epic meal. I returned 4 months after I first tried the ham from the shack appetizer. It's still a great dish, but they have cut some corners which unfortunately downgrades it from my previous review where I thought it was the dish of the year. Last summer they would bring an entire cured pig's leg tableside and crudely carve the prosciutto-like strips in front of you. This gave you nice uneven chewy pieces with a good distribution and ratio of meat to fat. You could see the knife marks on the meat and every bite was absolutely mesmerizing. This time, the carving was done away from the table. From the way the meat was all uniformly sliced, it seems they used a deli slicer on the thinnest setting. I find there is less flavour this way. It's still a great dish, but they would have to revert back to the old way of preparing it table side for this dish to reclaim its former greatness. In other news, I tried their onion soup which after Gibby's, is certainly one of the best in this city. Extremely rich, and drowning in french cheese, this soup is done right. My wife's burrata was also modified since the last time we visited. Last summer it came with delicious cherry tomatoes and blueberries. This time, it was accompanied by a tomato toasted piece of bread and more of the same sugar shack ham of which we already had an abundant supply at the table. It would have been nice if they told us that the same ingredient was being repeated in two appetizers. We would have ordered differently. Nevertheless, it was still delicious.Finally, despite my intention of having the duck in a can or the plogue a Champlain, I noticed they had a tartiflette on the menu. I've been hunting down this dish ever since I first heard of it on a cooking show years ago. Basically, it's supposed to be a scalloped potato casserole filled with cream and bacon in a pool of melted french cheese. PDC's version had the whole thing backed into a pie crust. It was exceptionally rich and delicious even though it had less cheese than I expected. At 38$, it is served in a huge portion and so I opted to have it as my main course, even though I feel it is better suited as a side dish. I would have like to see it offered in a smaller portion at 18$ so that it could reasonably accompany another main course. The problem is that PDC has too many good dishes! It's a good problem to have. For dessert, we shared one of the most epic apple pies I have ever tasted. The apples had been given some very loving treatment in which ever ounce of sweetness and richness was coaxed out of them. The crust stood on its own in all its flaky glory as all decent crusts must do. Topped with their maple ice cream, this was the final straw in the food coma that is inevitable with a visit to PDC.One gripe which I noticed last time is that their wine and champagne menu is absolutely off the charts in terms of price. We had been pre-drinking some prosecco at home and wanted to continue down that road. The most inexpensive bottle of anything with bubbles is in the neighbourhood of 130$. That's their bargain basement. The prices explode into the stratosphere from there. I'm not a wine expert and therefore, this sort of investment is not only ridiculously overpriced, it goes largely unappreciated. The champagne was great, but at nearly 175$, certainly not 10 times more enjoyable than the 17 dollar bottle I had earlier in the evening at home. I looked around the restaurant and noticed quite a few people drinking beer. I suspect, it's not because they really wanted to pair beer with this already heavy food, but rather, it's the only reasonably priced adult beverage served. It won't stop me from coming back though. As I've mentioned before, your best bet at this restaurant is to pre-drink and then take it easy during the meal. The food is so heavy that alcohol cannot compete with the duck, foie gras, pig, butter and other animal fats and oils with which your body must contend.

Fuck you guys... now I have to book multiple trips to Montreal every year so I can watch Michael Picard, Antoine, and that team of cooks, cleaners rip throw dish after dish of the crackalicious magic that I was served. My waiter, Edward, was fantastic both nights (I went back to back) and one of the wait staff (Asian lady) was super kind and took a moment out of dinner rush hour to take a few photos for me.Highlight was everything... got the Duck in a can, Duck Tartar (incredible!), the sushi rolls (with Venison not horse) was ridiculous and yeah... I'm coming back with a least a few more people as backup - there's just too much here that you must try and a ton of rubbernecking every time something comes out of the kitchen.Did I mention the staff, everyone, was amazing. Thank you so much!!
Soo good. You must get the ham and the fois gras. I wouldn't order the duck in a can again though.

I have wanted to come here ever since I watched Anthony Bourdain (RIP) get force fed nonstop fois gras dishes by the owner Martin Picard back in 2006. I remember sitting there drooling over the dishes thinking I have to go to Montreal just to try out this place. 12 years later, I finally had the opportunity to come here and experience it on my own. I have no idea how he managed to eat so many dishes cause I was stuffed just with the few plates we shared. This is a popular place so a making reservations a week before arriving landed us with a 9:30pm reservation on a Sunday night. We definitely had to plan our day and evening accordingly know we were going to eat a heavy meal late at night.I love the hustling and bustling feel of the place. Everyone is so excited to eat the food and the waiters are happy to serve the delicious plates. Our waiter however wasn't very helpful with food or drink suggestions. He basically shrugged and told us it depended on what we liked. That didn't dampen our spirits. We took a look around and decided to order what most people were eating. Can't go wrong with that. Tartare Temake - Tuna hand cone with a quail egg and spicy mayo served in a slab of wood. Great presentation, tasty and unique. The seaweed however could have been crispier though and it would have been nice to have a few more pieces for the price. 4/5 Fois gras poutine - lots of fois gras and squeaky curds on lightly fried fries; it was perfectly balanced where you almost had fois gras, cheese, gravy and fries with every bite. It's awesome that they are so generous with their fois gras. 4.5/5 because it was a little salty for me Duck in a Can - This was very special. They can the meal themselves in the morning, cook them fresh and serve the meal from the can at your table! It's a large portion of perfectly cooked medium rare duck and a piece of fois gras served on a squash puree.  5/5 We were stuffed so we didn't order any dessert and went for a long walk before returning home. We will have to make another trip to Montreal to try the other dishes for sure. If you can bring friends so you can share more dishes.

Ducky, foie gras-y deliciousness. I went in afraid to eat too much the whole day because I was afraid I wouldn't have enough room to eat all this place had to offer. But the food was super good and rich without being sickeningly so. We started with the little fried foie balls. I could've eaten about 10 of these. Next we had the foie gras terrine and the foie gras nigiri. Phenomenal. The duck in the can lived up to the hype. Only wish the skin was seared crispy but o guess it's hard to do in a can. Go here and order as much as possible!

What an experience! I learned of this place through Anthony Bourdain (R.I.P.) and Parts Unknown. This place is everything pork and foie gras! As you can see by the picture of the roasted pig head stuffed with a whole lobster, cauliflower, set on a spread of foie gras. It was amazing to witness. I was lucky to sit at the chefs table where I loved the duck carpaccio and the pasta with morels were amazing. A great experience with delicious food. A must visit in Montreal.

When we found out we were going to Montreal for a conference we asked a friend who travels a lot where they might recommend. He sent back the link to the restaurant with "my favorite restaurant in the world."We agree. Service was great. Honestly maybe the food took a while, but it was an experience. It is now our favorite in  the world.

From service to food, this spot is a 5. We went in with high expectations and were not disappointed. We both ordered the specials, one a pork shank and one a meatloaf mix of veal and beef(I think). My dish was a little salty but honesty it was SO good, I didn't care.We also had 2 desserts, one sugar pie with maple ice cream and 1 milkshake with these sugar croutons inside. WOW.Go here now!

Au Pied is more than a temple to gluttony (though it is that), it's an inviting experience and the rare restaurant that sweeps you into its arms and makes the world disappear for two hours. The specials always deliver while the menu consists of certified classics - the pied de cochon is a showstopper of a dish, the foie gras pancakes a worthy foray into the foie offerings.

We had our last night in Montreal and my boyfriend and i decided to go to this restaurant.  I recommend getting a reservation though, i made that mistake because they were fully committed. As my boyfriend and I were leaving. This hostess literally ran out and said there was a table available. I was just shocked and jubilant after that. I had the foie gras poutine and my boyfriend had the conserve de canard. I was just pawing at my poutine, best to have b4 leaving Canada. The presentation and flavors of the conserve de canard was bliss. My boyfriend said it was a bit more fat then he thought. And poding chomeur was addictive. But the atmosphere of the street was calm and warming to this establishment. But i want to give a big thank you to the team who make up this restaurant. What a memorable last night.

Lucky to have a seat. Restaurant was packed, but servants clearly aware of what they are doing.Foie gras poutine is probably the best bang for the buck you can try for a foie gras dish anywhere.I would give the servants 5-stars since they are some of the most attentive servants in Montreal. Water was always topped of before you notice and your request will be done in a few seconds.Kitchen staff worked their a** off for all customers. Not to say food was not worth that money, but for a highly praised restaurant there were definitely some detailing improvements one can made, like just seasoning the dish at the perfect amount.  I would say if the kitchen was even a bit larger for 1-2 additional helpers, then the cooking quality will be spetacular.Cochon dish was pleasant, but I must say it was indeed heavy and not hugely creative.One more thing, for this kind of restaurant you can still manage to have a decent meal for well under $40 with drink. A good pork dish with beer will make you satisfy quick.

Certainly a surprise but extremely happy with this spot. You can feel the love passion and energy of the team as soon as you walk in. It was our first tripto Montreal this was by far my favorite meal. It was a last minute reservation for 9pm a little later per our usual but nevertheless busy as ever. Service was great attentive and helpful, I'm always asking for recommendations, specials, favorites and the server was very accommodating. When we sat down, the table next to us was having a table show. Their server was torching a block of cheese and tossing their pasta in it. I thought I was sold but then we heard the specials which were all a share. We ordered the meatloaf (I make a killer meatloaf) wrapped in bacon and a side of poutine. Excellent beyond words, the influence of the food is pretty eclectic. Our meal seemed very German but the flavor of the sauce was more BBQ which was completely unexpected. Also the house bread was basically the bottom of great pizza crusty chewy Heaven-totally recommend this place.

Atmostphere: tight, cozy, fast-movingService: very friendly. We had about 4-5 different servers continuously check in on us. Food: incredible. Had the charcuterie board to start which was pretty standard (always good). I got the Duck in a Can as my main, and that meal itself was 4/5. The duck and the foie gras were really good right away. Incredibly tender and flavourful. Everything else in the can reminded me of Thanksgiving stuffing, which I love, but did not anticipate.  Really good meal, not quite worth the price on the menu!

First off, this was without a doubt one of the best meals I've had in my life. I went there with a few friends on Friday, and I ordered the fois gras with berries, and it was exquisite. We also ordered an appetizer with bison tartare and caviar on fresh oyster...also, wow! The service was exceptional. But there are a few reasons why I am giving it 4 stars not 5: 1) Cleaning the vents above the tables during service hours was just weird. They explained to us that they had to do this because otherwise the vents would drip water. But when they were cleaning it, little bits of dust / dirt were falling into our food, and this was definitely not okay. 2) At $13 and up for a small glass, the wine is just too pricey (thankfully, beer is only about $6/glass).3) My friend ordered the blood pasta. It took a while to get to our table -- she was fine with that. But when it did come, it was ...well, I don't know what blood pasta is "supposed" to taste like (who would? lol) but it did NOT taste good. I would not recommend this dish! I felt bad for her who had to wait but then didn't even like the food. I think they comped her a beer, but she did not get offered another type of dish or anything like that to make up for the wait and generally bad flavour. TIP: If you are going for the first time, describe to the server what types of flavours you like, what types of food you want to try, etc. They are extremely knowledgeable and should be able to help you find something you love. After reading the other reviews, it seems that there are a few things on the menu that were a "miss" with other customers too...so it's definitely worthwhile to be selective and ask a lot of questions as you order!

What a special place!  This was one of my top dining experiences of all times.  The reason...personal service.The Owner/GM, Flo (sp?), stop by our table and welcomed us.  He told us what his top 6-7 favorite dishes.  We ordered all 6 plates to share between the 4 of us.  My favorites were:Foie Gras Nigiri - Mind Blowing.  One of the best bites I've ever taken.Charcuterie from the Shack - Thinly sliced, restaurant raised, cured ham served with pancake dumplings covered in maple syrup.  Quebec at its best.Stuffed PDC with Foie Gras - Pork trotter up to the knee.  Braised, seared and stuffed with goodness.  Very rich. Very savory.  Incredible.Dessert was an off menu Foie creation.  Because the wait staff noticed that our table was drawn to Foie Gras, they recommended we take a chance on the 'secret' dessert item.  Pound cake covered with a soft cheese and foie gras, coated with a caramel type syrup.  Super simple and inventive.  Sweet and salty, not the most attractive, but boy, was it tasty.Throughout the night, Flo stopped by our table checking in with us.  He shared shots of cognac with us at a few different times.  I can't remember ever getting such special treatment from a restaurant's Owner...oh, and BTW, they were full and busy the 3+ hours we were there.If you are in Montreal, this is a must try!  It will be memorable.

What can I really say about Au Pied de Cochon that hasn't already been said countless times in any of the 988 (!) other reviews on this page? Their food is breathtaking, astounding, exquisite, and indelible, and you'll remember your meal for weeks, months, and years afterwards.I had reserved well over a month in advance and we received a nice table near the front of the restaurant, which was bright and sunny and didn't feel nearly as crowded and cramped as it could've.We were initially presented with complimentary bread and butter, and it was clear even at this stage that we were in for an above-average dinner. The crusty, fresh bread was delicious, but it was the butter that was the real winner. It tasted so much creamier and flavorful that normal butter, somehow. It was just so rich. Why isn't all butter like this?For our appetizer, we decided to go with the Foie Gras Cromesquis. I had read a few reviews with recommendations of this and it seemed like a simple, not-too-filling way to start our meal. A server brought over two dice-shaped concoctions and advised us to wait a full 60 seconds before popping the whole thing into our mouths. I'm not entirely sure what was in this thing, but it was glorious. As soon as you bite in, this sauce or gravy oozes into your mouth and it tastes amazing. I could've eaten a whole bowl of these things.For our main, we decided to share a couple of big-ticket items. First, we got the Foie Gras Poutine. I mean, would it surprise you to learn that this was amazing? The fries are perfectly cooked, the cheese curds are squeaky, the gravy is sublime, and the pieces of foie gras are spectacular and so, so tasty.From there, we arrived at the piece de resistance of the entire outing: the infamous Duck in a Can. There's a great deal of showmanship that goes along with this dish, as the can is opened at the table by a server and the contents are poured onto a waiting plate. (And yes, we kept the can.) But oh my god is this thing amazing. Everything in this concoction is next-level in terms of flavors and textures, with the perfectly-cooked duck and rich gravy nothing short of delectable. This is one of the best things I've eaten in my entire life, hands down.Our dessert was the Maple Poudding Chômeur and it is, of course, delicious. It's basically cake sitting in a syrupy liquid, and it's addictive. I wouldn't have minded some ice cream in there to kind of cut through the intense sweetness, but this is an extremely minor complaint.So why, you must be asking yourself, am I giving what was clearly a stellar meal four stars instead of five? The service. While I have nothing but praise for the incredibly friendly folks who brought us our food, our waitress was horrible. She took our order and we didn't see her again until it was time for the bill. This is not an exaggeration. I initially ordered a beer and probably would've had two or three more, but nobody asked if I wanted another. Like I said, other folks in the restaurant did stellar work and made sure our water was always topped up, but there really is no excuse for such ambivalent service from a waitress in a joint like this.
The beef shank with risotto special was amazing. Beef was falling off the bone, and so tender! Make sure you get a reservation!

Amazing! So good. Sit by the bar if you're just there with a friend or two. The open kitchen's kind of cool. The staff also doesn't stare at you as you eat. They act and joke around as if you're not there-- it's great! Food was amazing. Wish I was more hungry when I arrived because I could not finish it even though I really wanted to!! They also have fun decor and merch for sale.

This place is a MUST when visiting Montréal. It's a meat lovers fantasy. You have to try the foie gras here - it's the best in Quebec! We didn't make reservations but we were in the neighborhood when it opened for dinner time and we were able to get a seat at the bar. This place is always packed so make sure to make reservations. We started off with the tartare temaki and we both thought it was very tasty! We also got the foie gras poutine (which you have to get poutine when you're in Canada right???) The foie gras was so smooth, rich, and full of flavor. This was one of our favorite places during our Canada trip and we are already looking forward to coming back.

A very unique, classic modern Quebec dining experience. I've wanted to eat here ever since I saw Anthony Bourdain eat here on TV but I could never get reservations or the right people to join me. As I booked 5 friends for the Jazz Fest this year I made the reservation months in advance. The decor is nice, and I heard there was an electric Japanese toilet in the bathroom though I forgot to check it out. We had the absolute best table in the house as it was a massive heatwave in Montreal and we sat right in the back where the air conditioning was strongest. Service was excellent the entire evening and they patiently explained everything to us.We shared:- Masssive, and I mean massive, snails. They were huge, meaty garlic buttery goodness and we destroyed 2 orders- Poutine - Standard goodness- Foie gras - amazing, tasty, rich- Duck in a can - it's a half duck with other ingredients literally canned and then boiled for 27 minutes and opened table side onto a plate of potatoes. Texture was unreal- Stuff PDC (Stuffed pig's foot) with foie gras. Decadent, rich, fatty- Pasta made in a wheel of cheese table side - they toss it around which melts the cheese and coats the pasta. DeliciousOverall an amazing experience. Very rich food so don't plan on doing much after.

A weekend spent in Montreal with friends led us to this restaurant - in recommendation from a few people who had been before. We made reservations for dinner at 10:30pm (all that was available) and made sure to get in our steps before coming in. We were seated promptly when we arrived and we found the host - who was also acting Sommelier that evening - to be very warm and pleasant (and he made some pretty darn tasty wine recommendations)As a group of 4 we ordered the following, to eat family style, I would say that overall this was a reasonable amount of food for 4 very hungry people, but we didn't quite make it through all of the mains and left very very full (but not so stuffed that I wanted to unbutton my high waisted jeans for whatever that's worth):     AppsWhite Ham - really pretty delicate ham, not too fatty, not what you think of from your local deli, served thinly sliced with thin slices of cheese, they apparently raise the animals they use themselves, and I will say that this was an nice example of why quality of protein mattersFoie Gras Poutine - rich! Came with 2 different types of sauce, I preferred the foie sauce, but found the foie gras medallions on top to be over kill.  I'm glad we shared this plate 4 ways, and glad we tried it, but I wouldn't get it again, and opt instead for poutine elsewhere     MainsDuck in a Can - Yum! My favorite of the things we ordered. Other reviewers have pretty accurately summed up the cooking process so I won't get into that again, but I will say that it came out perfectly done and while rich, it made me want to keep going back to it, something about the tanginess of the vegetables was really nice. I would get this again, but I wish that texturally there was something to crunch this up. Stuffed PDC - the is basically a pig leg that's been scooped, turned into a terrine, re-stuffed and cooked. I didn't really care for this dish, and I normally love terrine. I think that the fact that it was warm might have partially turned me off, but I also just felt like the dish was one dimensional.      Desserts Maple Creme brûlée - it's crewmen brûlée made with maple. Sweet, creamy, delicious, but not mind-blowingMaple pudding chômeur - think bread pudding, but different. It was really tasty hot, but as it cooled then texture changed. I would eat this again, but won't crave it. Overall this was a really nice meal, service was friendly and appropriately attentive (though we were served primarily by the Somm, not a waitress). I understand why this place gets recommended, and I'm glad we went, but all 4 of us agreed that we won't be returning on our next trip to Montreal just because there are sooooo many other wonderful places to try. I would recommend having this experience at least once (come hungry and plan for a walk afterwards) but don't assume that this is all Montreal cuisine has to offer.

I've had good meals, and great meals. But here -- at Au Pied de Cochon --  I had a truly special meal. First off, our waiter Sam was amazing. The fantastic rapport we had with him elevated everything from just another good meal into an experience worth ranting over. We started with a fantastic bottle of local Riesling which he recommended based on our love of high mineral content wines. It was the perfect complement for the meal to come. The cromequis were the perfect amuse bouche, which we ate one bite. After we swallowed Sam rapped the dish on the table and we were welcomed to Au Pied de Cochon. After that point I knew we were in for a treat. The nigiri -- which came next -- was a highlight. An inventive use of foie gras that used the spoon it was served on as a vessel to have the rice absorb the homemade sauce we sent down the handle into the bowl. Next came a foie gras ma po tofu and an amazing tart. The ma po tofu was the right amount of Sichuan ma and just a hint of la spiciness that  accented but did not overwhelm the rest of the specialness of the ingredients. The tart sported a delicate béchamel sauce and flaky crust that played well with the blood sausage and foie gras that sat atop. The entire time as we ate Sam would check in with us, refilling our wine glasses, and pausing to explain each dish and what made each one special. Then, dessert. Dessert started with the three of us taking a shot of amaro to drill a hole through what was an exquisitely rich meal. We looked at the menu and saw several things that looked good, but Sam asked us if we trusted him. At this point I would have followed him to Mordor and back. We did and he went out and ordered an off menu dessert for us. What came back was simply decadent. I won't say what it was. Just go to this place, put your trust in the staff and they won't steer you wrong.

I accidentally checked into the food truck, but I did eat at the restaurant. I would ordinarily never eat at a place like this since everyone knows that a) pork tastes just like human flesh and b) pigs are smarter than dogs. However, I was with a group and my objections were overruled. I planned on enjoying the wine and getting a slice of pizza later, but as it turned out, there is more to this place than pork and foie gras!They have an emphasis here on fresh and made to order, so unfortunately, a few of the items that I thought I could stomach, such as the garlic whelks, were unavailable. Also, they insist on defiling many of the vegetables with cheddar, the most offensive of the cheeses, and charcuterie. But as luck would have it (for me, at least), the night before our visit, a hapless, 200-pound tuna enjoying a swim in the brisk waters off the coast of Nova Scotia was ensnared by Au Pied's supplier's nets, so there was a great deal of tuna available on the menu. The server advised that our food would take about an hour to arrive and encouraged us to order an appetizer, so we started with the coppa pizza. The wonderful cheese pie (NOT cheddar, thankfully!) was crowned with a salad of arugula, nutty Parmesan and easily removable charcuterie. Just to up the ante, the server poured a mix of hot and spiced oils to dress the salad. The food arrived - a variety of pork products topped with foie gras for the others; two obscenely large tuna steaks for moi - and we dug in. The tuna was quite simply the best I have ever had. Perfectly seared and simply seasoned with cracked pepper, the briny taste of the Atlantic was allowed to take center stage. The tuna rested atop a bed of what I sincerely hope was a pork-free polenta and was garnished with some cheddar-less asparagus. Divine!The restaurant thought ahead and considered the richness of their food in designing their bathrooms, which are equipped with fancy Japanese toilets with fountains, blowers and heated seats. Then hand dryer was out of order and I considered using the toilet to dry my hands, but reconsidered. We were too full to contemplate dessert, but the dessert menu does feature a great deal of confections incorporating maple. There is also a park about 2 blocks away and I suggest doing as we did and taking a stroll after your meal to aid in digestion.A final note; the wait staff is wonderful. Everyone was friendly and welcoming, and our server was attentive and extremely knowledgeable about the menu - both wine and food. Top notch!

As a restaurant rated as one of Canada's Top 100, I had high hopes for the experience.  Upon entering the restaurant, we were seated promptly in a section where it appears the tables were spaced out as thinly as possible to maximize seating.  There was a moment where the server had to squeeze between my table and the next table to get to another row of tables, and in the process elbowed me in the shoulder.  The server apologized and I was not hurt but that was how packed the seating was.We ordered sparkling water and the first glass was poured to us.  However, throughout the night, the server did not pour any additional water for us.We started with the bourgots (sea snail) in garlic.  This dish was done well and tasted great.  The bourgots were plump and soft and the juices and flavours were on point.  The only complaint is that they were a bit too salty; however that could have been a result of the sea water.For mains, we ordered the foie gras with boudin tarte and the duck in a can.  The duck in a can is exactly that.  They bring you a plate with toasted bread, some seasoning and mustard, and then they proceed to open a can and dump the contents onto your plate.The duck in a can dish is tasty and tastes better than other restaurants where I've had the same dish.  The duck is juicy and soft, and the duck liver is flavourful.  The cabbage and balsamic vinegar enhanced the flavours of the dish.The foie gras with boudin tarte was an interesting dish, albeit a bit too heavy.  The foie gras and the blood sausages that it comes with are a bit salty and you can only have so much before the dish becomes too overwhelming.Our biggest complaint was the service.  Our server did not check up on us throughout the night and appeared to be overwhelmed with the amount of tables she had to wait.  The entire service staff members also appeared that way and it was evident they were short staffed.  Nothing against our server but the management should try and ensure that either have enough staff on hand or they don't maximize the seating arrangements the way they did.What really made the rest of the night weird was the fact that our server apologized to us that they give our bill to the wrong table and asked us to pay their bill.  That was confusing but it appeared that they wanted us to pay our bill on the other bill so they would be able to close out that bill.  I don't think it was necessary to explain that to us, and they should just tell us what we needed to pay.  The bill they brought us was wrong and did not contain any of the items we ordered so they came back with the corrected bill.  Further complicating the payment process was that a dish that we ordered, but were told was sold out, still appeared on the bill.  The restaurant manager came and apologized stating that errors had been made and they would attempt to rectify the problems in the future.The food was good but I would not come back again unless they fix their service.  I feel for the staff that work there as they appear to be overworked and understaffed.

Amazing food and service; could not have asked for a better dining experience. Everyone and everything at Au Pied was perfect. The only bad part of the whole experience was that I didn't have room for dessert...MUST ORDER: Charcuterie from Sugar Shack. It really doesn't get any better or fresher than this. The meats are sliced table side, drizzled with olive oil and served with a maple fritter. MUST TRY: Stuffed Pork Shank w/ Foie Gras and Mashed Potatoes. Super rich, fatty dish that will put you over the top and in a coma. A tad on the salty side but still very tasty. Definitely not for the faint of heart. I recommend this dish if you have 3+ people to share with. Highly recommend snacking or dining here!
There's nothing better in Montreal.  If you love the smell of pig fat, wait until you walk into this restaurant.

Come here for all things foie gras and that really is end of the story. The restaurant is not fancy by any means, so you can definitely come casually. And don't over order because everything is so rich. For dinner for 2 girls, we shared 2 dishes that was more than enough.FOIE GRAS POUTINE: Nice and crisp fries, very rich and delicious gravy, big chunks of foie gras. I'm not a huge fan of cheese curds, so we essentially didn't eat that part, but I'm sure it's good as well. We were literally full on the poutine already...DUCK IN A CAN: Another must order here. That day's version was cooked with sweet potatoe puree on the bottom. A thick slice of duck breast attached to a large piece of fat, with a very generous hunk of foie gras sandwiched in between. Umami bomb would be an accurate description. The duck was very tender and well rendered. We unfortunately couldn't finish the whole thing, but I made sure to polish off the foie though!Everything was delicious. Really the only reason I didn't give full 5 stars was because it's a meal that doesn't make you feel good afterwards. We ingested probably 5000 calories. Beside a side salad on the menu, there wasn't anything to balance things out a little.

What a wonderful dinner!! If you want foie gras, go to Pied au Cochon. We ordered the foie gras nigiri (sushi). A well sliced foie gras on top of sushi rice with a taste peanuts butter vinegar matching with sake soya sauce. What a perfect match. Then we added foie gras burger and pork shoulder ribs. The ribs are so tasty, with sauce sweet and spicy sauce. Just by typing my mouth is watering already!!

I went here expecting it to be more of a gimmick or hype but was very impressed at how delicious everything was! We ordered their featured cantaloupe and prosciutto which was amazing - this was a nice lighter choice to start off the meal). Followed by their garlic foie gras that was recommended to us by our server which was also delicious. It was served with fresh roasted garlic and the foie gras tasted very fresh and creamy. Last but not least, we got their infamous 'Duck in a Can'. Two thumbs up! I recommend stopping by this restaurant in Montreal. The ambience is fun for larger groups to celebrate an occasion and it can also be intimate for couples or smaller groups.

I have been meaning to check out PDC since we moved to Montreal about  a year ago.  We finally made  it a couple of nights ago. It was a relatively cold night (~-10) and as soon as we got in we were struck by the amazing smell of food and the warm cozy atmosphere and the buzz of tables and the  waiters running around. Walking in, the most striking feature is the brick oven in the kitchen at the heart of the restaurant. Luckily, we sat right next to the kitchen, best spot IMO for 1st visit, and got to watch all the dishes coming out of the kitchen.  Before i ramble about the food, i should point out that the service was excellent: i saw about 6 servers working together in an  impressively cohesive manner. Everyone was kind and friendly and they answered all our questions patiently with a pleasant dose of humor.Sadly, all daily specials were suitable for groups of 3 or more (or 2 really really hungry people who don't care too much about dessert). For this reason and generally the generous size of the dishes, i think the restaurant is experienced more fully by groups of 4 or more.We got foie gras poutine, tarragon tongue, duck in a can, maple creme brulee and maple pudding chomeur. The poutine was the best I've had in Montreal. The froie gras totally melted in my mouth and the gravy was rich, tasteful and satisfying. The tarragon tongue included about 5 thin pieaces of tongue, sitting in a hearty sauce garnished with a few small pieces of carrots and pickles.  The tongue pieces were tender and juicy, and the sauce was the kind of flavor you wanted to taste as slowly as possible so that maybe you'll get to know it better  :D it was rich, smooth and sophisticated.  I think duck in a can is a classic at this place. Half a duck, foie gras, cabbage and garlic  have been sitting together in a can until they are boiled for about half an hour and served on a piece of crunchy bread and sweet potato puree. Sure, the duck is rare and tasty, but the rest, the mixture of cabbage and garlic marinated in duck fat and broth in a can with a bit of crunch bread is the kind of homey flavor that might be worth dying for, gastronomically speaking!I'm not a fan of maple pudding chomeur and i have to admit PDC didn't change my mind: it is just bland, pointlessly sweet and without a texture at all. Creme brulee was nice but not the best I've had: the custard was ok  but half the caramel was burnt black. It's very sad when a meal doesn't end on high noteSo, yes i want to go back soon, ideally before summer starts and with a group of fun friends to share more dishes with :)
Everything I tasted was decadent and ridiculously good. Martin Picard is a maniac. Going here is an out of this world culinary experience.I can't comment on the service cause all I remember is food.

The food was excellent and lived up to all of our standards after hearing many people rave about this place! Delicious sustainable in house meats and a unique menu. Only disappointing thing was our server seemed a little off and kept "pushing" more drinks on us from the first 5 seconds we were seated. I understand it's a fast paced place  The rest of the staff was great and the other servers who interacted with us were great.

I recently tried out this famous resto located on Duluth street and loved it!! The resto is small and you must reserve way in advance. It's a warm ambiance and service is super friendly. The max  group they take is 10.  This resto is perfect for birthday celebrations, date night or friends night out. Most importantly you must go with others who are not picky eaters and enjoy pork and foie gras. The menu is on the pricey side but the food quality and presentation is worth every penny!  Worth it to try out at least once! Their menu is also seasonal and changes. The food was absolutely delicious and beautiful presentations!  We had the foie gras cubes which were mouth-watering and amazing!  I then tried the duck in a can which was awesome!   It lived up to expectations! Every single bite was yummy!  Lastly we had dessert, pecan pie for sharing topped with maple ice cream!  So heavenly tasting!! Sweet lovers delight! It is expensive but so worth to try at least once..a real foodie experience!!

[LOCATION] - 5/5This place is located at Rue Saint-Denis and Rue Rachel E. Free street parking was available when we went there on Sunday night at approx. 9PM. [SERVICE] - 5/5Our server was very friendly and personable. She helped us out with the menu and recommended several of their signature items. [DÉCOR] - 4/5 Traditional and iconic Montreal vibes. At one point, the place got very warm and smoky because of the oven(s). [QUALITY] - 5/5The food was the pinnacle of fine dining in Montreal with high-quality ingredients and complex flavours in each dish. [ORDER] - 4/5- Plogue a Champlain - $29.00: buckwheat pancake topped with cheese, potatoes, bacon, and fois grois. The dish was both sweet and savoury. Fois grois melted in my mouth. Portion was small so I had to savour each bite.  - Duck in a Can - $44.00: came with an actual can and is heated with boiling water. The duck was very fatty and tender, and accompanied with cabbage. - Pig's Head - $120.00: the star of our meal! Our server informed us that this would take quite a while to prepare (approx. 45 mins) which is why she recommended we enjoyed other dishes in the meantime. Every single part of the head was edible (except the bones and teeth). The skin was crispy, and every bite of meat was a melt-in-my-mouth experience. The head was stuffed with the most tender octopus tentacles, bison meat, and came with a side of squid ink risotto and spinach. [OVERALL] - 4/5 All the dishes were very rich, fatty, and delicious. This type of food is a great treat once in a while, but I wouldn't eat this every day because I felt like all the fat was going to clog my arteries! Overall, I was glad I dined at one of the best traditional restaurants in Québec.

Came here for a nice dinner. It's a French restaurant known for their duck in a can dish. To be honest, I wasn't a fan. The taste wasn't for me but my boyfriend loved it. I was a big fan of the duck tartar wraps and the foie gras sashimi. I would definitely go back for those dishes and to try more! Nice service. However do not sit at the tables by the mirror wall. Water kept dripping on me and they had to keep mopping the ceiling which was less than ideal when trying to have a nice dinner.

It was my first time at Au Pied de Cochon. It is a staple in Mtl that you have to try once. I came with two people for late night dinner and we shared the quenelle and the duck in a can. The quenelle was very sweet and there were three small pieces of lobster and no mussels. The sweetness was overwhelming. The duck in a can was good but there was a big piece of duck fat. Since we shared this dish, we each had a small piece of duck meat. The duck meat itself was very tasty and perfectly cooked. The sweetness of the other dish overpowered everything so it made it hard to enjoy anything else.The service - the waiter did not come to see us aside from taking our order. It was an ok experience overall.

Not to say it wasn't good...just to good enough for 2 weeks ahead reservation and steep price!I went there a few years ago and remembered that I wasn't wowed by the food...but going there last weekend for a friend's birthday confirmed that it definitely wasn't worth it.When you pay $36 for a tuna belly entree, you would expect that they put more than 4 slices as thin as paper around rice...I mean at least get the rice part right. If you are not a sushi restaurant, then don't serve Japanese dishes if you can't get the basics right!There wasn't one single dish that was memorable as they most likely tasted very similar.The dishes are very filling as they are heavy so you need to share your dish...I would say order 2 mains for 3 people.I have also been to their sugar shack many times and only the first time was good...Take my word for it...you won't be blown away so spend your money elsewhere...unless money is no issue and you want to try it since it is so well known.

Great experience, very rich food. For 2, we ordered the bluefin tuna tartare, apple and foie gras, and the duck in a can (2 apps, 1 main). It was all delicious, great flavour, and a lot of the food is sourced from their farm. The menu is a bit simple, but our waitress was great with explaining how each dish was prepared, and was very friendly and attentive. The cream base for the tartare was a bit strong for my liking, especially for the delicate and delicious tuna. Our favourite dish was the apple and foie gras - ham stuffed apple, seared foie gras and boudin (dark pig blood sausage), on a bed of picked cabbage and mashed potatoes. It was the perfect combination for the breezy end of summer meal with the apple and pork. The duck in a can was surprisingly moist, but very oily. Not sure if we would order it again because there wasn't a lot of variety of texture or flavour, but it was still tasty.

I came to this place because of the Anthony Bourdain episode, Uber driver recommendation, and trip advisor forum post saying this place has this place has a decadent foie gras menu.What I got was plate after plate of oil and grease with nothing to make the food edible. I even asked waiter if there were something light and he basically drew a blank.  Lightest thing they got was just a whole roast duck but meh.  Not what we came here for and that's not really light fare anyway. Foie gras nigiri (sushi) was just a slice of foie gras on rice on spoons. They used some kind of sesame oil/paste instead of wasabi and served it with ponzu sauce.  Yes, it was as uninspired and greasy sweet as it sounds.  It's not awful if you happened to like the condiments but the subtle foie gras sweetness was all gone.  It just wasn't very tasty.The carpaccio just had way too much oil. I thought it was just greasy and bland and my wife found it inedible until she put it on the bread. Even then she thought she might as well just dipped the bread in olive oil.The bread was served hot and tasted okay, once you get rid of the crust that was just too thick.The PDC with foie gras was just gross.  It's a big pig feet with a block of foie gras on top. It was blandly seasoned so the fat from the pig foot itself was just sickly, which was made only worse by the foie gras.  The crispy skin on the pig foot was so thick we couldn't cut it with a butcher carving knife.  It was basically carbonized and mostly inedible. It was basically a horrible rendition of Ecuadorian (or some other Latin America country) roast pork that was over roasted and under seasoned.I almost rated the place 1 star but I usually reserve 1 star for restaurants with basically no redeeming value. The foie gras nigiri wasn't great but it was pleasant for me since I liked the condiments and foie gras to begin with. The bread was warm and tasted fine with butter, once you removed some of the crust.  The entire PDC pig foot did have small bits of good meat (like 10% of it). The service was friendly and prompt.But still, the food was uninspired and poorly executed. If you travel, just don't come here. If you don't, well, maybe this is the only place this indulgent in all of Montreal.

Honestly I want to give this place 4 stars but the service was pretty terrible. The food was so good but the terrible dining experience we had really ruined it for us. I'm not one to complain about a waiter. I get it. It's a busy job and you have to wait on so many different tables it can get crazy. Out waiter was pretty rude. He treated us like we were stupid. He would spend 2 second at our table, giving not much help with the menu and didn't come back for 20 mins at a time. Our entire dinner lasted almost 3 hours and a lot of that was waiting. He was very short with us and always seemed to be in a rush. I thought initially maybe "it's busy and he's like this with everyone."No. He spent 25 minutes, I am NOT exaggerating, talking to the couple next to us when giving them their bill. Talking about everything under the sun. We had gotten to the restaurant 20 mins before this couple and he checked in with them constantly. They were not from the area so I don't think he knew them prior. We were obviously waiting for our bill and he didn't even move. After our entree another waiter actually had to take over for him and I thought he left! Nope. Still there. Being rude. He didn't wait on us one time after we ordered our entree but he had enough time to talk to the table next to us for 25 minutes? After we were seated far before them? Ok. I felt brushed to the side and forgotten. Terrible dining experience. Not to mention he was taking shots with them at the end like ok. You have enough time to take a shot with customers but can't even bring us our bill? K. Other than that. Food is phenomenal. Duck in a can. Get it. Very unique and complex in flavor. 10/10I wish we had a different waiter because this experience would have been much more enjoyable but the food was worth it.

This place is very busy. We could only book a spot at the bar for 7pm. We came a bit early to try our luck, turns out we got a table at the patio. It's so beautiful. My husband kept saying is a dinner under the tree. We had duck carpaccio and stuffed PDC with foie gras. The duck carpaccio is amazing. The raw egg with cheese, mushroom  and two types of dressing mixed together gives a perfect harmony in taste and texture. It felt sad when we had the last bite. The PDC is good, stuffed pig foot is not my most fav. My hubby enjoys it a lot though.

Rarely (ever?) does a restaurant ever live up to this much hype.  It's gotta be a gimmick, right?  Nope.  Almost everything on the menu is either fried, smothered in a rich mushroom sauce, or stuffed with copious amounts of foie gras (and if you order correctly...all 3.)We stuck to the staples: The Foie Gras Cromesquis, Foie Gras Poutine, Duck in A Can, Stuffed Pied de Cochon.  All were excellent, but the Cromesquis were life changing.Is it decadent?..sure.  Over the top?...maybe.  But you only live once.  And there's always Lipitor.

Walked in as a single and got a good seat at the bar.  Excellent service and fun to watch the cooks and staff at work.  The gin persecco touch of maple syrup cocktail was.a.good beginning.  The veal ribs special was delicious with the house made barbecue sauce. The broccoli rab with just the right hint of garlic and oil a very nice pairing atop the mash potatoes. How I wish I'd had room for dessert and one of their milkshakes.  The fare is on the heavy side....

I learned about Au Pied de Cochon years ago, from a comic book about Martin Picard's life before the creation of the restaurant. It was a beautiful book, and although it didn't showcase much of the food, the story made me curious. After I moved to Montreal, I had the chance to eat there. A visiting friend from New York had reserved a table for her last night in town. It was one of the first times I ate at an "expensive" restaurant, but it almost didn't feel like it. I was certainly younger than most patrons, and was quite intimidated upon entrance. But after a few minutes, the welcoming and warm atmosphere of the place made me feel at ease.The wooden interiors of the place reminds of a cozy, fancy cottage. The buzzing sound of conversations and laughter was cheerful and vibrant. The staff was cordial and professional. It felt great to be surrounded by a friendly crowd and about to have a mighty good meal. I ordered the famous Foie Gras poutine. My friend had the Duck in a Can. Both dishes were impressive, but also quite overwhelming toward the end. It was the first time I had foie gras and I loved it! It's easy to see why Au Pied de Cochon has achieved such renown in Montreal and worldwide. It is not only authentic to its birthplace, but to itself as well.Anecdote: As I was taking a picture of my friend, I noticed a middle aged man pointing at my camera - the strap was dipping in my olive oil dish - I promptly moved it away and smiled to the guy to thank him. That's when I realised he was Chef Picard! :o

I was excited to bring my family here tonight - my last visit was solo in 2008. What I recall about my original experience was decadent lobster and foie and poutine. My decade-plus in waiting; needless to say I was pretty excited. The hostess was very sweet and kindly sat us without reservation at 5pm. Sadly, this would be the last good thing we would experience tonight.  The menu was generally unappetizing but I wasn't concerned as I knew the specials was where it was at. Meet the waiter who is a total dick. He resented that we didn't speak menu French and would therefore require his help, which I naively assumed my 20% would cover. One vignette- I asked him what kids typically like to eat here. Waiter responds snootily "it really depends on how adventurous your kids are" to which I clarified "let's say our kids aren't very adventurous, what then would your recommend?" To which he circled back to "it really depends" as if blaming me for taking us into this idiotic loop. When I then asked for the specials, I was reprimanded with "we stopped serving specials years ago"Started with poutine and a couple French onion soups. Poutine - fries were pretty excellent, gravy and curd just average. Onto the soup- I would have been real happy with just French bistro style French onion soup but this was a deeply ham hocked soup that just tasted like ham- no chicken stock or beef stock, no slow roasted carmelized onion just pork. Gross. But at this point we were still quite hungry. So we would have eaten anything and paid anything for that anything. We were a hungry and forgiving audience and totally extended APC the benefit of the doubt. Main courses -Duck in a can - innovative preparation and presentation where they unload this prepared meal from a can onto a plated grilled bread and celery root purée. The duck had the consistency more of organ meat than confit duck. The foie was limp, with the consistency of flan. And the craziest thing about this dish was this prominently plated one inch thick flap of yellowish fat that had encircled the meat whilst cooking and should have been discarded when served. This is typical APC- they show an almost macho bravado for offal and fat and massive calorie bombs regardless of how poor the food actually turns out. I was reminded of the Will Ferrell and Tina Fey sketch on SNL where they eat hunks of wild game in a jacuzzi while alluding to lovemaking. Maybe this restaurant is satire to cool montrealers but cruel punishment to those tourist outsiders like me who aren't in on the joke? My wife ordered the tagine of pork. We had good experiences with Moroccan tagines and thought this a safe choice given the absence of offal, just "braised pork". Forty five (!) minutes elapsed after the onion soup's arrival as two waiters came by with a massive clay tagine pot that they tilted and literally dumped out onto the plate flops of dried stewed pork. We didn't know what to make of this yet as the presentation was so disorienting - this gargantuan quantity of dried meat with absolutely no attempt at plating or variation in color, accoutrement, vegetable anything at all. We tentatively hacked off our first (and last) bites - all three of us shocked by how salty and oddly flavored this pork was. Not much execution here at all - it tastes like pure salt and cumin. That's it. No depth, subtlety anything to offer at all.  Keep in mind that our three bites constituted perhaps one fiftieth of the total meat on the plate. We were just stunned, spending the next day fifteen minutes discussing how confusing this dish was....How could a restaurant as exalted and celebrated and impossible-to-get-into serve this food? Our waiter came by and didn't care to notice we had barely touched our main course nor did we show any signs of revisiting given I asked for the desert menu. No "how was everything" or any probing at all. Maybe desert could redeem this experience. We ordered the pecan pie with maple ice cream. It was absolutely delicious. The flakiest and most delicious crust, infused with their namesake shack maple syrup and allowed us to end on a slightly better note. And we enjoyed two bottles of nice wine, mostly because we had nothing else to do in the nearly hour between courses. I was deeply disappointed by this place.

You have to like fois gras because this restaurant specializes in it. If you don't, pick something else. I personally am not a fan of fatty liver but my husband loves it so we had to come here. We didn't have reservations but we were able to score two seats at the bar and ended up having a blast. The other customers who sat beside us were so much fun and that elevated our experience. The bartender was also friendly and offered us free drinks as well. We ended up with duck in a can, and the poutine. My husband loved the duck in a can, not only because it was fun to eat but also it was really tasty. I had a small bite and it was pretty good and I don't even like fois gras. My poutine was pretty delicious as well. I couldn't finish all my foir gras so I just left it. I also got to sample some of my neighbour's appetizers and they were great as well. I think the overall atmosphere of this restaurant is just great and the servers were all really friendly. But I think I'm done with fois gras for the next few years. Too. Much. Fatty. Liverrrrr........

Au Pied de Cochon was absolutely everything we hoped it would be and more. On a recent trip to Montreal, 3 girlfriends and I tried the restaurant. We made a reservation 2 weeks prior. It's cozy and warm when you walk in - perfect for a cold winters night. The menu plays to traditional Montreal flavors and dishes - complete with fois gras, rich gravies and maple syrup. Each dish was unique and incredible. The service was fantastic and we became quick friends with our server and one of the GM's who checked on us throughout the meal and gave us a list of suggestions of places to try throughout our visit. We thought the prices were reasonable for the quality and service we received. Au Pied de Cochon was truly one of the highlights during our trip to the great city of Montreal. Highly recommend it to anyone. I cannot wait to go back to this restaurant again!! THANK YOU!

I loved: - foie gras poutineI liked: - maple creme bruleeJust ok: - Duck in a can. After eating duck and foie gras for 3 nights, I found this to be underwhelming. It was a small portion of duck (Joe Beef wins on portion size), and the winner in terms of taste would go to Le Quartier Général.Expect dinner to take up 2 hours because service in Montreal is slow everywhere.

Went here to celebrate our birthdays and between the four of us we had the trout, scallops and pithivier. It was out of this world and tasted amazing! I'm 33 years old and during my time here on earth I can honestly say I have never ate anything so beautiful and magnificent, I really enjoyed the atmosphere and the staff was very friendly in assisting us with any questions we may have had. I'll let the photos do the rest of the talking for me, if I could give more then 5 stars I would. The place is expensive as hell but it's worth it to visit a place like this at least once in your life, you won't be disappointed.

Au PIed de Cochon, ah!  Little piggy come here and let me kiss your delicious feet.This was hands down our best meal in Montreal.  We came early without a reservation and were treated so beautifully by the host when mentioning how much we hoped to eat here, and swept right into a small three top.Bliss began when our food arrived.  Every dish was remarkable in some way, the best being the house pork chop covered in foie and served with soft potatoes.  I say this as someone who has never been properly impressed by a pork chop.  It was completely lush, rich and decadent. That pork chop was so delicious, its hard to do it justice with words.  Also terrific were their other dishes, from the fiddleheads, to the clever foie nigiri with peanut sauce (easier to drizzle than to dip), to the calamari pasta, to the crab salad with milk dressing (again, remarkably good), to the duck fat fries.  I am getting hungry again just thinking about our meal.The best part is that the service here is warm and professional and completely up to the terrific food. This place is really special.  I think they had about ten foie dishes, which is pretty awesome right off the bat, let alone that everything they put in front of us was very, very tasty. The service and atmosphere here are delightful. This little piggy can run all the way home, and into my mouth anytime.

If you want to come for an Experience, come with a group of 6ish and you might be able to take advantage of the tasting menu (they'll basically choose dishes for you). We saw another table with a foie gras cake dessert/appetizer which was said to be perfect if you're an absolute lover of foie gras!Our meal started with a deep fried foie gras appetizer which can only be described as a foie gras explosion. It was phenomenal - and it was only the beginning! Next app was the foie gras poutine (a MUST try if you love foie gras and poutine), then a seared foie gras on top of a potato 'pancake' with a honey maple syrup (omg so good) and then an app of skewers with rabbit kidney and foie gras.Our mains included the duck in a can, shank with parmesan risotto, and maple ham. I'm usually not a ham person, but DAMN was it a good ham. The maple glaze was outstanding and if you happen to like sweet bbq sauces I definitely recommend it. Everyone loved every dish though so it's really up to you!BTW it will probably be the fattiest meal of your life, but you'll be glad to try this place at least once.

It took me a long time to visit Au Pied De Cochon. As a lapsed vegetarian who grew up surrounded by the heavy French-derived foods of North-Eastern Ontario and Quebec I was never in a great hurry to visit. This was a mistake. This room is a classic for a reason.The restaurant is a temple of decadence. There are a lot of hits on this menu, and it is worth bringing friends so that you can extend your coverage. A standout of our meal was the maple ham, which arrives tableside in its own pot, before being ceremoniously lowered onto the cutting board where prodigious slabs are carved off and placed steaming on your plate. Afterwards, it is doused in an unbelievable maple-foie-gras sauce ("It's a keeper", our server said). The foie gras poutine, French onion soup and Melting Pot (half a dozen pork products adorning a mess of cheese-laden potatoes) are all also worth sampling.However impossible it may seem, save room for dessert. Maple is as much a theme here as pig or foie-gras, and the maple-toffee covered ice cream is a perfect finish to the meal.

Duck in a can. What else needs to be said? The hype is real here people. Let's get down into the weeds though: Service - friendly and helpful staff that can easily accommodate English only groups like mine. The knowledge of the dishes and the wine pairings helped us navigate our way to a beautiful combination. Ambiance - it was likely just where we were sat but this is where I felt the experience could have been better. The weather was gorgeous on the evening we went, so if we had sat closer to the open storefront there would have been less crowding and a little more tolerable music volume (of which was a tad too high for conversation).Food - the foie gras poutine and the Duck in a can stand out big time on this menu. We ordered a few more delicious things here and there really were no duds, but my god the foie gras poutine.... so dang delicious. Everything is unapologetically fatty and simply delectable.

Duck in the can is a must! I love the warm fresh bread too! They have specials so ask. I had fresh snow crab! The pork chop is probably the next best but we try the pot something. You skip it unless you like sausages and pork blood. The dessert is mostly maple flavor varieties so I skipped since I'm cutting back on sugar. Must try place but need to book or walk in early to see if you are lucky. Enjoy!

I want to live here.In the restaurant of course. I absolutely love this place. We came here for a pre party stag dinner. It was insane.  Drinks and wine were wonderful. Food was out of this world.Foie Gras paradise. We had everything Foie Gras. From the night, to the burger, to the pigs leg stuffed with foie. It was rich, heavy, buttery, seasoned perfection. Insane experience. You are getting what you pay for and that is always a great feeling. I would absolutely recommended. Try it all and ask about specials that's where the magic is.

I visited Au Pied de Cochon with a group of friends and had a wonderful experience. I started with the Foie Gras Poutine. This was some of the best poutine I have ever tried. The French fries were soft with a little crispiness and topped with rich gravy, creamy cheese curds and a generous portion of melt in your mouth Foie Gras. For the entrée I had the Duck in a Can. The duck was tender and stuffed with a slab of creamy Foie Gras and braised in a flavorful rich sauce. Overall, Au Pied de Cochon is a great choice for a nice dinner.

This is one of those must visit restaurants when visiting Montreal. I love anything foie gras, and PDC does it justice in a variety of forms. Reservations are difficult to get so plan ahead. I managed to get a 10pm seating 2 weeks in advance. I had visited Paris this year, and the food here reminded me of Parisian cuisine, except better! I still have dreams of the foie gras nigiri. This might be one of the top 3 things I've ever eaten. Sushi rice prepared the right way topped with a perfectly cooked, generous slice of foie gras served on an Asian soup spoon. A soy yuzu sauce is drizzled on the handle of the spoon to accentuate all the rich, delicious flavors. The duck in a can was fun and entertaining to watch as it's opened table side and your whole meal slides out of a tin can. I'd love to come back again to try their other menu foie items and of course get a foie nigiri order all to myself. Until then, I can only reminisce about the heavenly nigiri.

Ah this place makes me want to live in Montreal so that I could try everything on their menu. First off, amazing staff. Everyone is friendly and patient!! The latter is important when trying to figure out which dish to select since there are no explanations on the menu. The menu itself is a foise gras lovers dream. Great selection of their take on foise gras. The naked selection was our favorite. Ordered the bison tartar and WOW. Out of this world. The tiny little quail egg for drizzling is just perfect. We wanted to order ten more! And for the main event. Pig shank with risotto. Wish we grew another stomach. Huge portion. Falls off the bone and melts in your mouth. Must experience this place when in Montreal!!!

Came here on the recommendation of our server from another restaurant. This place is Foie Gras heaven, Foie Gras extraordinaire!! I mean, if you like Foie Gras, definitely come here and taste their many different variations of it...and that we did.We started off with their sashimi appetizer on top of this rock salt thing and also their poutine with..you guessed it, Foie Gras! Delicioso!!!  They also paired it with a yummy red wine!Unfortunately for our main course, we had this meat plate that didn't live up to our expectations. It was all boiled meats that was chicken, bone marrow, sausage and maybe even duck. It's ok though, we wanted something a little risqué, but it didn't hit the mark.Service was still awesome as they accommodated everything we wanted to try. They constantly checked in on us and gave us recommendations for the next time and even other places to try in the area. Staff is definitely amazing and would come again and try some other stuff.

Came here for dinner to celebrate my husband's birthday and our anniversary. Arrived early and was seated which was a bonus as the place was packed. Lots of bodies buzzing around - it's loud, but we loved the vibe. Service was attentive - plates cleared immediately, water glasses filled, bread and butter refilled as well - and friendly - we were looked after by three amazing staff. We ordered the blue cheese salad (loved the walnuts with the endive), foie gras poutine (the best gravy I've ever had - used the amazing bread to mop up every last drop), and the pork shank with risotto which was one of the specials that night. Omg so much food and so very good. We were so full that we didn't order dessert, so sad :(. Can't wait to go back next time we are in Montreal.

Came here on a Saturday evening and this place did not disappoint. Came with my husband, brother and sister in law and we decided to order a bunch of dishes to share. We tried the tartar temaki, French onion soup, plogue a Champlain, duck in a can, poutine and cured foie grad & boudin tart. My two favourite dishes were the tartar temaki and plogue a champlain. The temaki was so fresh with the crispy seaweed and creamy from the quail egg on top. Everything about this hand roll was delish! The plogue a champlain was a buckwheat pancake with potato, bacon, cheese and foie gras drizzeled with what I think was a maple syrup of some sort. The flavours of everything mingled so well together. The bacon was to die for and obviously the foie gras was delicious. I would come here and order this again. The infamous duck in a can to me was a little overwhelming. About two bites in and I couldn't eat a whole lot more. Don't get me wrong, it was delicious, but oh so heavy. This is definitely something I would recommend to share amongst at least 4 people. The plate started with a crouton and some purée and then the can was emptied on top. Inside the can they had cooked foie gras, a slice of duck, a giant slab of fat and a bunch of cabbage and veggies in a gravy. It was an explosion of flavours, but a bit too high in cholesterol for me. I wasn't impressed with the French onion soup, poutine or the tart, but my sister in law loved it. To me the flavours of each were too rich and heavy, but not in a good way. The service was excellent and the atmosphere was pretty casual. I would definitely be back to try some other foie gras dishes.

The day of my dinner reservation at APDC was not unlike the day of your first date with the guy you have been crushing on for months: stomach full of butterflies, palms sweaty from anticipation, expectations rampant, near delirium from starving yourself all day...I arrived fifteen minutes before my reservation and was seated at the bar - the only available seat in the house on a busy weekend night.  It was prime real estate directly across the open kitchen with all its glorious chaos - young, black-clad cooks darting from one end to the other, waving hot pans and plates, yelling orders in French.  It was such a great sight. And then the food came and it was time to get serious. First up was a crab and cucumber salad - a special for the day.  The presentation was simple but nice: a bed of shaved cucumber bathed in a creamy dressing (that looked a bit like Hollandaise sauce), topped with a generous layer of crab meat, topped with a green garnish of some sort.  The crunchiness of the cucumbers worked well with the tenderness of the crab meat, and as I bit into the salad, I was surprised to find fresh mint buried between the crab and cucumbers.  Great layers of textures and tastes in this one.  My second dish was the tart with cured foie gras.  This one was interesting.  A tart the size of a personal pizza, topped with a sharp cheese that had been toasted and left to harden a bit.  Beneath the hardened cheese oozed a drizzle of reduced balsamic vinaigrette.  And on top of it all, four slices of foie gras. Biting into the tart, there was the nice crunch from the flaky crust, the sharpness of the cheese, the tanginess of the balsamic vinaigrette, and the sweetness of the foie gras.  Again, a weird blend of flavors but somehow it worked!  This was delicious and really rich.For my third dish (and this was me absolutely indulging), I went for the homemade boudin. This was actually my favorite: light, fluffy mashed potatoes topped with fat pieces of boudin, garnished with cooked apples and sauteed cabbage and onions.  The boudin melts in your mouth and there's some kind of magic that happens when you add the tender apples and the sweet cabbage and onions.  Amazing.  I would have liked to have gone for dessert, but I literally could not fit another bite of anything in my mouth.  I didn't even finish the boudin (I took it home of course).  This was a one-of-a-kind dining experience and an absolute must-do in Montreal.  The service was also excellent.  So yes, make a reservation and indulge!

What can I say? This is my all-time favourite restaurant in Montreal and I have been here countless times with different people who all grow to love it as well. If you love foie gras and meat, this is the place for you. They have so many foie gras options, it's insane. The naked foie gras is a classic pan seared foie gras in a red wine sauce. I love that they have very original options too such as the foie gras nigiri, foie gras cheung fun - if you're Chinese, it's exactly as it sounds with the rice noodle wrapped around foie gras with a soy sauce... super light tasting, very amazing. The foie gras poutine is mind-blowing and you must try it. Every time you visit they will have specials that are based on fresh seasonal ingredients. Can't recommend this place enough!

Fantastic. This was my second trip to PDC and both have been really enjoyable dining experiences. The staff are really pleasant and work hard to create a memorable meal for the diners. I had the foie gras burger, poutine, and maple pie. The burger was incredible. Between the foie gras, the cheese, the bacon, and beef there was a lot of fat here, this is a compliment. Definitely worth the $$ there isnt really another burger out there like it. The poutine had a really nice pepper gravy with excellent curds. Very happy with my choice but I also tried the duck in a can and the hot chicken. Both were equally as amazing, I just can't pass up foie gras on a burger. Finally, the maple pie was awesome. Really nice buttery, flaky crust with a rich maple filling. Summary: there is a reason why this restaurant is so popular, it's really good.

Definitely lived up to the hype.  I have visited Montreal many times for work, but never made it here.  This time I was in town for a girls trip and we ordered fabulously and excessively!  The duck in a can was probably the best thing I've eaten in years.  The fois gras poutine and duck Shepherds pie were also standouts.  Oh, and there was this incredible tomato tart app -- very simple but outstanding.  If my heart can take it (literally and figuratively), I will be back!

Au Pied de Cochon is out of control. The dishes are delicious and the portions tend to be overwhelming. In short, this place the manifestation of gluttony.
