Their menu includes a sizable number of greatest hits, but make sure to check out the specials. On the last visit this included a lobster served with obscene amounts of house made caviar. (WHO FARMS THEIR OWN CAVIAR?!)The wine list is fairly deep and pretty interesting. The sommelier definitely had some great choices available, despite him being unnecessarily full of himself when questioned on the lack of sauternes in a restaraunt that probably serves metric tonnes of foie gras.Worth going out of your way to visit.Make sure you book your reservation a ways out, this place stays full.

Apps were great but entrees were really salty. I really regret not ordering the French Onion Soup because it looked delicious. We had a front row seat at the bar facing the kitchen, so we were able to see the chefs cook and all the food coming out. It was a great experience however after a 6 Hour drive from New York, I would've preferred a table. However, this was not the restaurant that I intended to go to for dinner so I did not make a reservation thinking that it would not be too crowded at 5:45 PM. Boy was I wrong, all tables were reserved so we took seats at the bar and by the time we left the line was out the door.Food was good, the tartare was phenomenal and the service was excellent but I really don't see the hype. But then again, I should've found out what boudin was before ordering it. I saw a tart, saw foie, and I was sold. I didn't realize it was a tart made up of blood sausage. I don't like blood sausage and the tart itself was way too salty. The pork shank was way too salty as well, however the risotto was perfectly cooked. I would give this place another try if I had opportunity, I feel I ordered all the wrong dishes. The duck in a can looked really interesting and the hen stuffed with offal and foie sounded pretty amazing, but since we're only in Montreal for 3 days, not going to happen.

Dining here is an experience. Dinner service took almost three hours for us, so don't make plans to be anywhere after. Service was very friendly and attentive. The food. Our table was right next to the ovens where the fresh-baked bread was coming out--to die for. They kept refilling it and we kept eating it, which we would regret later. The foie gras poutine was the best poutine I've had. I was worried it would be too rich based on the reviews but it was just right. Delectable. The portion is adequate for two people but I would come back and order it just for myself. The maple creme brulee was also wonderful.Now onto the just OK food: the duck carpaccio was very tasty but I could barely taste the duck with all the dressings. We still enjoyed it though. The pigs head: an experience more than anything else. I'd recommend this for a large group of 4-6 to share but not as an entree for two because it's so rich and fatty. My husband enjoyed his tapioca pudding and their teas are delightful.I would come back here if I'm ever in Montreal but I'd stay away from the heavier/greasier options like the pig's head. We were so full that we didn't want to eat the next day, practically until dinner.Would definitely come back here.

Sorry I'm late for this review. First, I want to say how lucky and extremely grateful I was to receive this reservation the DAY OF because there was a last minute cancellation. I have heard through word of mouth that people can wait weeks to months for a spot. The service from beginning until end was A1, accommodating and helpful when it came to the order. We loved everything from oysters, to their famous decadent "fois gras" and pork. This is an absolute artisanal Montreal restaurant experience. Lastly, they also have a sugar shack that my boyfriend attended for a business meeting and said "it was hands down succulent and explosive in flavour". If you are a meat lover, particularly with pork and "fatty" textures, and enjoy the combination of sweet maple... You must must come here.Ambiance is also very classy with wood inside to imitate the look of a sugar shack.
Foie Gras Nigiri and tamaki tataki were bursting with flavor. It was hard to taste it as it melted in your mouth. So rich so powerful, it's a must try.

I found this restaurant by a simple internet search of "best foie gras in Montrea.l"  Immediately this place popped up.  Intrigued, I went to the website, found the email for reservations (because I was too afraid to call, I don't speak French!).  Juliette was so accommodating in reserving a table for us.  I called 2 weeks in advance and only the 5:30pm and 9pm were available - this to me just showed I made the right choice for Saturday night dinner in Montreal.  Upon arrival, it can be a little hard to find, there isn't really a sign.  If it wasn't pointed out to me by a nearby patron I probably would have walked right passed it.  We were greeted nicely by one of the waiters and were seated right away.  At 5:30pm (mind you, they open at 5pm)  the restaurant was already poppin'!  Workers were delivery food, the smell of delicious pork, duck, beef filled the air, I couldn't wait to order.  The (3) of us decided to share plates so we could try everything.  My only regret ( if I had any) was that I wish we got dessert...everything sounded so delicious!  Here is what we got:French Onion Soup - we were advised to share because it was hearty.  The waiter (who was THE BEST, so entertaining, informative and just wanted us to have the best dining experience, like, ever) said that Pied de Cochon meant "rich and heavy" umm yes please.  He advised between the 3 of us we share one soup.  He. Was. Right.  The soup, which had all the traditional components of beef stock, onions, crouton and deliciously melted cheese had a little kick of meat which made it more filling than normal.  I would recommend this dish when you visit!Beef Tongue with Tarragon - sounds different... I'm a big fan of beef tongue but I'll have to be honest and say that I've only really had it during hot pot or korean bbq.  The Tarragon sauce was delicious, the beef was so soft and it practically melted in your mouth.  If you're one of those "not sure about tongue" this dish is definitely a great way to try it for the first time!Fg Poutine - delicious! delicious! Gravy was delicious and there were good pieces of foie gras throughout.  The fries are also fried in duck fat (yes please!)Fg Plogue à Champlain - Suggested to us by our waiter.  Imagine, a light pancake, light mashed potato, top with melted cheese and then the whole thing is topped in foie gras and drizzled with the most delicious syrup.... we were all fighting for the last piece.Wine/Cocktailes - great selection of wine and they had 2 special cocktails that night.  We opted for a french wine and it accompanied our meal throughout.This was our favorite restaurant when visiting Montreal.  The service was excellent, and the service team were so cohesive, they really worked together in such a tight space with a big crowd of people.  The food ,even better, I dream about fg to this day.  I highly recommend a visit when coming to Montreal just don't hesitate to make a reservation - the line was out the door and it was freezing!

The short of it:- Delicious, decadent food- Menu features fois gras, pork, duck- Service was excellent, although food can come out slow- Favs: fois gras terrine, cured ham from the Shack, duck magret, stuffed pdcThe long of it:Wow just wow. I love this place! If you are a fan of fois gras and decadent food you must visit this place! You definitely need to make reservations far in advance. This place gets booked up quickly. I recently went here on my first visit to Montreal and it made for the perfect last meal in this city. The menu changes so you might not always see some items on there and another issue is that the menu is not very descriptive at all. I suggest browsing on yelp to get more in depth descriptions of the food or just ask your server and they can give you a run down if you have any questions about anything. On this visit, we ordered the fois gras terrine, cured ham from the Shack, duck magret, and stuffed PDC with fois gras. The fois gras terrine came with a few pieces of toasted bread and some maple syrup. This was one of the best terrines I've had. It was very smooth, had a delicious taste that was rich but not overpowering. I slathered the terrine over my bread and drizzled a little syrup on top (delish!). Next up was the cured ham from the Shack. I would say this is more like prosciutto than ham, but they aren't able to call this prosciutto since its not from Italy (or that's what the server said). They bring this beautiful leg of ham to your table and carve it right in front of you. I thought this dish would just be the ham (again menu is not descriptive enough), but it actually comes with a plate of these warm fluffy round pancakes (similar to a beignet) that have a maple syrup glaze over them. You pair the cured ham with the pancakes and the sweet and savory combination makes you do a little happy dance in your chair. So so good. I love the saltiness of the ham and it goes so well with these pancakes. Next dish was the duck magret, which is duck breast with potatoes, mushrooms and a delicious sauce. Order this if you love duck! The piece de resistance of our meal was the stuffed PDC with fois gras. By this time we were already stuffed from our previous dishes, but we miraculously still managed to eat. The stuffed PDC is a pigs foot on a bed of mashed potatoes and topped with fois gras. Gluttony at its finest. This dish was very indulgent and could have been the only dish we ordered since it was massive, but hey when in Montreal, right? Overall, the meal we had was exceptional and although food came out slower than I expected it gave us a good buffer between the courses. Everything I ate here is a fav in my book and definitely a memory I'll always have of Montreal! Thanks for the fantastic meal Au Pied de Cochon!

One of the best meals we have had.We drove into Montreal late in the evening, not even bothering to stop first at our AirBnB hoping and praying the hype would be worth it to two teenaged boys and our 22-year-old daughter who has enjoyed some fine dining in Paris.It did not disappoint. The vibe is casual and welcoming. We were never rushed or made to feel out of place. Our server was incredibly helpful, funny, and patient with five weary Americans. She walked us through and answered questions and directed us without encouraging over ordering. It was probably the richest meal we have had - caviar, foie gras, bone marrow, poutine, red wine, creme brûlée. Each item was perfectly prepared and served, and we rolled out of there with gastronomic memories we talked about for the rest of our week in Canada!

Although I am still saying four stars, this was the least satisfying of four bon repas during a recent stay in Montreal.Despite our long standing reservation, we waited on a bit on arrival. The maitre' d soon offered a table just inside the door which did not seem like it would be comfortable. After refusing that one and waiting a bit longer, we were awarded a slightly larger table, opposite the bread station. We'd made a bad decision - throughout the meal there we were disturbed by the constant rushing of the servers, with the odd occasional brush against. I began with a Negroni, well made and well priced, but on the small side. Moved on to wine by the glass.  La Portena also had a glass of wine. Although we were practically seated on top of the bread, and had a bird's eye view of the frenetic slicing, we were not offered any.After quite a delay, my appetizer, the Plogue A Champlain ($C31) arrived - lukewarm. The slab of foie gras on top was perfectly cooked, but the base of potato and pancake was heavy, the bacon forgettable, the egg was MIA. La Portena's tripe arrived in a ceramic pot to great fanfare and did not disappoint - the tripes, done in a provencale style, were delicious. The pig's foot was an unexpected surprise. chewy and gelatinous. The problem for her was that the pied du cochon comprised most of the dish - she ordered tripe, she wanted tripe, not trotter. At this point in the meal, we requested bread for sopping. The bread was excellent, and the butter with it was perfect.For a main course, I decided to forgo the duck in a can so we could share the special for two, a massive "trout." These were swimming as we arrived. The dish was well worth the long wait - the large fish was coiled around a sort of salad of a dark green lettuce that was unknown to me. From its size and pink color, I suspect le poisson was actually an Arctic char. Perfectly cooked, meaty and swimming in a delicious butter sauce - probably a variation on beurre blanc. The fish redeemed all that gone wrong before it. There was also a light dressing on the salad, and the whole thing worked perfectly.We were quite full and as so much time had passed,  we were in no mood for dessert.So I am a little torn by this restaurant - I believe whole heartedly in the style of eating it supports - but it needs a service upgrade in this writer's opinion. (See review by Howard K.) Still, I wouldn't hesitate to go back and try something else.

Do you love ducks? Or better yet, do you hate ducks? To the point where you'll eat ducks in every form for 3 different dishes? If so, Au Pied de Cochon is just what the doctor ordered.Sure, the name translates to the pig's feet, but the duck is where it's at.Foie gras poutine is about as rich and delicious as it sounds.The duck in a can (which COMES WITH FOIE GRAS) is also a must. Just watching the waiter take a can opener to it and drop it onto a plate is a thing of beauty. The entire can is boiled and then brought out. All the spices are infused and all the fattiness is preserved without getting boiled off. Super unique. Just don't overdo it. One can is probably enough for 3-4 people unless you REALLY want to feel unhealthy.We also got a side of duck fat fries, because WHY THE HELL NOT?There were 8 of us, so we did a few other entrees as well. One was the PDC's cut, which the waiter told us was a boneless pork chop (there was a bone). It looked dry, but it was actually incredibly moist. It was a gigantic hunk of meat too.We also did one of the specials - the Ahi tuna steak for two. Let me tell you, it was NOT for two. Maybe if you fasted and that was the only thing you ate that day. But it was also good. Perfectly rare, with a ton of veggies and cheese on the side. It was probably our least favorite of the dishes, but even still, it was very well done.We were seated all the way in the back by the wine cellar, so it was a bit of a tight squeeze (especially with another large group next to us), but there wasn't much else to complain about. They also have one hell of a wine list.Our waiter was super cool and gave us shots to round out the night.Probably one of the best meals I've ever had. Also, why I came back to the States with none of pants fitting anymore.

You don't go to APC for a healthy meal, you go to delight in oil and fat and meat. However, even with that said, there was a kind of perverse indulgence to this place that left a bad taste in my mouth. Each plate comes HEAPING with meat and foie that most diners are not going to lick clean, and so you see plate after plate of a delicacy borne from an animal's suffering go into the garbage. I don't think you have to be vegetarian for that level of waste to affect you.I think APC could go a long way in managing portion sizes to reduce this.

I ordered their foie gras nigiri and all I can say is - holy dank! It's super delicious! Foie gras on top of rice with maple butter in the middle. This is seriously one of the best foods I've ever eaten.If you come to Montreal, try this restaurant out. You will not be disappointed. It was a busy night when I went but I was seated right away. The staff were friendly and accommodating. Ambiance is good except the space is a little tight and the noice level is too high for me. Since the restaurant is more on the classy side, the price is a little expensive although I must say you get your money's worth. Truly a wonderful food experience for me!

From the Ouest we came hungry... and this place satisfied.We had bison tongue for an appetizer, Pork blood sausage in another dish, and it was all amazing. This food here is very substantive, so flavorful and authetic. The aumbiance was great, you can see all the chefs cooking and everyone was very friendly.

SOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOO AMAZING! if you are in Montreal, this is a must try. We had a group of 19 people and they were gracious enough to accept our table and provided the best customer service. Some highlights of the night were the foie gras patee, Poutine, duck in a can and the Pork Chop. We did family style and spent a little over 100 bucks per person.

I called 2 weeks in advance for a reservation, but when we arrived at the restaurant the hostess said my name wasn't there. Then she questioned if I called the wrong restaurant since there is a restaurant in France with the same name? I clearly said no, and showed her my phone record of calling. Then the hostess said "Sometimes we take reservations and do not write it down" ????? Not sure how that made any sense to me. Anyways, she then said there are available spots at the bar which was facing the kitchen and can actually see the chefs in action which I don't mind so we sat there. At least we got a spot, or else I would have been pretty pissed since I know this place fills up and you need to make reservations in advance. Regardless, sitting at the bar was an amazing experience seeing all the chefs cook. Reminded me of the movie Burnt.Asparagus & Morel ($22)Boiled Asparagus, Cooked asparagus and morel (a type of fungus), and topped with a slice of Parmigiano cheese. I still can't describe the flavor of this dish, but it was definitely tasty. I've never had morel before, but it had a really spongey texture - quite interesting. Foie Gras Poutine ($24)This poutine was hearty, but definitely amazing! Especially if you like foie gras. There were huge chunks of foie gras, and big chunks of cheese. Their cheese is actually made in house (I saw one of the chefs making cheese, although it could be for the Mozzarella dish, although I would assume they would use the same cheese). The fries were crispy and already flavorful on its own! With the foie gras, cheese, gravy, and a few fries all together in one bite - epic moment right there.Duck in a Can ($44)This was very interesting and creative. Essentially the chefs cook the dish and stuff it into a can. Then, when they serve it, they open the can in front of you and all the deliciousness spills out, served on top of a toasted bread with a layer of squash spread. The squash spread was really good. The duck meat was cooked just right, border line well done. It was delicious, but I do feel the meat could have been slightly more tender - it wasn't as juicy as I'd expect it to be. I really liked the shredded cabbage that was drenched in the sauce, very flavorful.Maple Syrup Creme Brule ($9)This Creme brule was really good, but SUPER sweet! Slightly too sweet for my liking but it tasted good. Really creamy and you can totally taste the maple syrup.The service was good, except for our waitress. This was my disappointment. Everyone but our waitress was super friendly and helpful. Out waitress did not check on us during our meal at all, and not to mention she probably missed our dessert. It wasn't until we sat there with nothing for 20 mins, she then came by acting like nothing happened and said "oh your dessert still didn't come yet?". Then I saw her keying something in the computer. We waited a total 45 mins for the Creme Brule! Even though at the end the waitress took the item off our bill to apologize for our long wait, that $9 did not justify the 45 min wait. Not sure if it was just my luck, but I wasn't pleased with the service experience. The food sure was amazing though. Definitely coming back the next time I visit Montreal!

Allow me to begin by saying that I rarely ever put my thoughts out on the internet...And yet here I find myself two weeks later, writing an honorary toast to one of the greatest chefs the world will ever see; and at the same time, struggling to suppress my arousals at every slightest reminder of the kind of night we had.Every once in a while, mankind will be come across a legend that will change our mind on everything we thought we knew about our existence. Nelson Mandela revolutionised South Africa, Michael Jordan shook up Chicago, and here in Canada, we are celebrated by the wild, incredibly talented, and fearless Martin Picard. People frequently ask "What exactly is Canadian food?" and I never really had an answer until now.Food served up here has more of a Quebec flair, but don't be fooled, this is not a pretentious Franco-Canadian dining room. From the moment you walk in and smell the fatty aromas, you know exactly what you're getting. I strongly suggest going with your gut feeling, because by the end of the night, you won't be feeling your gut any longer.  Côte de Cochon: So uncomplicated yet so unforgettable. So unassuming yet so unapologetic. My still-to-be-educated mind made the mistake of doubting the pork chops in this establishment, and damn was I humbled. The pork that is so tender and so juicy deserves more credit than my photo is giving it. The real show stopper is having each slice with the jus, that I still yearn for in my pillowy dreams. Canard en Conserve: The pièce de résistance, the bright light in these darkened times, the one amazing dish that can entice the feeling of gluttony, love and fierce loyalty (if that's not obvious enough by now). All the ingredients come together like a symphony on your taste buds. The foie basically melts and fuses with the duck breast. And the jus again does miracles to the meat, imparting smoky sweet bacon, earthy herbs and delicate cabbage with every bite. Also the whole duck-coming-out-of-a-can provides some theatrics for the 'gram, ya know what I mean?It has just been decided that Au Pied De Cochon will set the bar on my Yelp account as the only 5-star rating I will ever give. No review prostitution going on here. Vive le Montréal(Oh, and wear loose clothes)

Drip Drip Drip4 star for food and service but -0.5 star for all the water dripping from the vent on top of my head all through my dinner.Drip Drip Dip I know it was one of the hottest weekend in Montreal. It was end of July after all and I should be thankful for the nice cool interior of the restaurant with their AC on full blast. But with the water dripping on me the whole time (2 hour) while I was enjoying my dinner was not cool. The staff was all trying their best to stop the dripping from top of the AC vent which ran across the full depth of the restaurant by a squeegee sponge but it was not working....Drip Drip DripDinner was really good!! Excellent!We shared Tarragon Bison Tongue ($8.50) - I just love the Cornichon in that! And now I have a bottle in my fridge at home!Pâté de Campagne ($9) - So smooth and rich!Duck Carpaccio ($14) - Well seasoned, my first time having duck carpaccioDuck in a Can ($44) - So overhyped! The duck was dry and just not good! Foie Gras was so so. I don't believe I said that but I preferred mine seared...Braised Pig Feet with Side Pasta ($50) Seasonal - Must Order!! It was so tender and flavoured!! And the pasta which was prepared table side was so good! Perfect al dente and with BACON... Drip Drip DripI would have up my star to a 4 because the food was just amazing and the service was excellent. But the management really need to do something about their cooling system. I definitely would be back! PS The reservation system just got so much better as my reservation was confirmed by email and no need to play phone tag again!

Make reservations! Either call/email or reserve online. It's a must. Also come hungry, because, they serve a lot of food.This place gets super packed during the dinner rush. Even dining at the counter gets full.I'd recommend the foie gras duo to get the best out of APC. If you're dining with friends, then I'm sure you can taste each other's food. But for a single diner like myself, the foie gras duo comes with Foie Gras burger and foie gras poutine fries. Huge portions for about $50. Very fatty, very rich, and very good.I started off with the tuna tartare as an appetizer, but even though it is a small portion, I couldn't get through my foie gras duo because of the enormity of the portions. The tuna tartare was tarty and fresh.And I still wanted dessert after and I chose the toffee maple milk shake. They made it right in front me...I guess because I was in the counter, but you can see all the fatty goodness when they make this. Not to sweet, but I had enough room to finish it. I would order this again.Trying to find street parking might be hard for you during dinner time. And the metro station is several blocks away. You can probably try the bixi bikes if you have time to roam around this part of the Montreal neighborhood.

I'm not sure how this isn't 5 stars always. But after Visiting over 10 eateries around Montreal, we finished our trip here. And this was nothing but the best. The service, the atmosphere, The food, and a vibe like no other place in Montreal. We ate all that we could, and left a lot behind because as we thought the plates would be small, we were pleasantly surprised  Will go back to Montreal for this restaurant alone. Best in the business Fois Gras!

The best restaurant to be found in all of Montreal is the absolutely outstanding Au Pied de Cochon. Locals and tourists should all make the same decision and eat here as often as possible. Personally, I enjoy sitting at the bar, because I also get to have fun conversations with the outstanding staff.
Food is too different for me and did not feel the service is nice.  I feel the place is overrated

If you're like me, you live in a culinary desert (aka Topeka, KS) and you sit and watch the Travel Channel or Anthony Bourdain visit exotic locations full of wonderful cuisine and you hope and you dream and you WAIT. And once in a while when you've saved your pennies you go on a journey (I like to call them quests) and you get to experience the best that artisans have to offer.Last night was another of those times. I'll spare you the details of describing the fantastic Cromesquis de foie gras or table-side carved Jambon Canane. Suffice to say they were excellent, but not what I came for. My wife, who does not share my zeal for all things animal and fat and skin and connective tissue had the halibut. It was reportedly quite nice. But again, not what I drove 1400 miles for. It was the namesake that I sought. A glorious and enormous piece of swine trotter. Baked in their brick oven, "stuffed" with foie gras and blanketed with an epic mushroom and herb gravy over mashed potatoes. I can count on one hand the meals I have enjoyed so immensely. Tonight I am finishing the remains of what mere mortals could not consume in one sitting with a nice baguette and contemplating my return for an encore!

In Montreal, a city known for the quality and quantity of fine dining establishments, PDC is one of the best. Perhaps even THE best. Well, tonight was one of the best meals I have ever had! Ever! There has been so much written about PDC that I'm not sure I could add anything earth shattering. I'll just say thank you for a wonderful meal.  Attentive as well as personal service.  Patrick and Christian were incredibly helpful and kind. We were thrilled to score a reservation.  If you have never been there.  Make a reservation well in advance or you will be eating dinner at either 5:30 or 10:00pm. Of the two I would go with earlier as they tend to run out of there more exciting dishes VERY quickly! It's loud and crowded.  Not suitable for a romantic, leisurely dinner. The open kitchen concept works well here.  Makes for fascinating people watching.

It is decadent. Do not eat for at least 12 hours beforehand. This is not a good place for picky eaters or vegetarians. I would recommend ordering a mojito to cut through all of the salt and fat. The fois grad nigiri and fois grad poutine are must haves.

Guys. Guys! Would like you to know that for me it lived up to the hype. How wrong can you really go with foie foie foie, but also there was perfectly cooked meats and lentils, rich yet balanced flavors and a high note with every dish. Can we talk about the lentils for a moment? Lentils are difficult. It's hard, for me at least, to get that just right consistency of not mushy, firm but not raw. If you want the tl;dr version: This is one of the finest examples of traditional Québécois foodAlso, I'm including pictures of all of them!Foie Gras CromesquisFoie Gras PoutinePlogue a ChamplainSalmon RillettesMeatloafVeal LoinsDuck in a CanPork Chop with LegumesFoie Gras CromesquisFried foie gras with a liquid center. Different and interesting. It was good in the way anything foie is minimally good, but it wouldn't order it again. Good to try. Foie Gras PoutineUm. Yeah. Chunks of poutine two types of gravy that tastes like you would not believe. If you like foie, it will put you in goose liver heavenPlogue a ChamplainI'm still not sure what all I ate. It was like they put Quebec in a plate and wrapped it in a buckwheat blanket and drowned in, obviously, gravy and maple. Some things that I think I ate: bacon, foie, cheese, egg and l'amour. And a heart attack. Worth it. Salmon RillettesThank goodness for this dish. It was a wonderful palate cleanser as the lightest thing we ate. It would stand alone wonderfully and was probably my second favorite thing the whole meal. For the record: yes, I called it the lightest thing on the menu. Yes. Salmon mixed into an artery busting amount of butter and sour cream/creme fraiche was the lightest thing our entire meal. But this is the type of meal where considering the amount of cream and butter and fat is verboten. MeatloafAmericans, this ain't your grandma's meatloaf (unless your grandma was from Quebec). It was sweet and soft with this almost curry-ish gravy and topped with butter beans. Veal LoinsPerfectly cooked. Excellent flavor. Not the best bite of the meal, but if you served it to me any random day I would be glad to eat it. Another sweet and savory dish. Duck in a Can"Inside (the can) we have half a duck magret. 100 g of foie gras. Cabbage, onions, bacon, thyme and garlic cooked in butter. And a reduction of balsamic vinegar. The magret is cooked sealed with everything else in boiling water for 27 minutes." Yup. Pork Chop with LegumesHow could we leave without any Cochon? This was a very good porkchop with those lentils, remember, that were cooked so perfectly? I wish I had more pictures of the color of the cooked meat. Just close your eyes and imagine perfect. Et voila!

Yet another recommendation from Doctor Elsie W., and I am so glad that we came here. Oh, you STILL haven't read LifeOnMacro yet? Here: lifeonmacro.com/2015/12/…. You're very welcome.Food: I recommend the catfish fritters for appetizer. I ordered the happy pork chop but my wife ordered the special pasta, which really stood out. It was made with pesto and other sauces, but thereafter, the server put together the dish on top of a huge block of cheese. By adding a bit of hot water, part of the cheese melted into the pasta before it was plated. This was the special of the day and it was absolutely delicious. I was tempted to order the other specials and should have, but did not. I will next time. DO NOT SKIP DESSERT! We had the flaky hot pecan pie a la mode. We have not found a better pecan pie anywhere else, ever. The ice cream was freshly made in the machine behind us!! The price for all this appeared extremely reasonable to me, though I guess everything in New York City is inflated for no good reason.Service: among the greatest I've ever experienced in all of Montreal. The servers all anticipated our needs - the water was continuously refilled and our bread was always plentiful. The server appeared cheerful, too. Relatively rare in Montreal.Americans, please note: dinners in Montreal may take three hours, and that's okay. Per Doctor Elsie W.'s point: just accept the fact that this is the case. Chefs obviously take extreme pride in their cooking, and a perfect product takes time. Please try not to complain about the speed of food service and try to accept this new culture/environment you're in. It's evening time in Montreal, there aren't too many other places to rush off to anyway =).Tip: parking in this area can prove extremely challenging! Good luck!

Was an excellent meal and we weren't rush. Service was very good. Restaurant is not huge. I had the croquettes as starters but would not recommend them. For the main, I had the signature dish, the pigs foot; it was very good; huge portion with mashed potatoes on the bottom, gravy, mushrooms, and two sizable pieces of seared foie gras on top. We asked the server for a red wine recommendation and were very impressed with the wine he recommended. The bread and butter on the table were good. Others in our group enjoyed the duck in a can and a fish and mussels appetizer dish. The food here is very rich, French style food. Most dishes have meat in them... but may be able to find some fish or vegetable dishes, if you lean that direction.

Amazing restaurant for all things foie gras. We ordered poutine au foie gras, the ham dish on their specials, and the foie gras pasta of the day. The poutine with foie gras was probably my favorite. The crispiness of the potatoes and cheese curds were a great complement to the heavier foie gras and gravy. The ham dish, which featured thinly sliced iberian ham topped with a sweet maple syrup and accompanied by a side of beignets, was also a standout dish for its uniqueness and unexpected combination of flavors. The sweet and savory worked so well together. I was a little bit disappointed with the foie gras pasta. It was very cool to see it being made table side within a giant cheese wheel, but the pasta came out kinda cold. The portion was also very small. The texture of the pasta was tad bit too al dente for my taste. However, the foie gras mixed into the sauce tasted amazing. I think this restaurant is a great value (especially if you're coming from the US) for all the foie gras you get. A must try if you're visiting Montreal. Make rezzies ahead of time to avoid the wait!Food: 4.5/5Service: 4/5Value: 4/5Ambiance:4/5

Woah! This place is in its own world. The dishes are some of the richest tasting dishes I have ever eaten in my life. We ordered duck in a can, fois gras, side of veggies & fries and the creme brulee. For two people this was more than enough. We could have gone without the fries tbh. The duck in a can is its most signature dish, for obvious reasons. The duck was very tender and the fois gras was to die for. A huge surprise, were the roasted veggies. Not sure what herbs/spices they put on them, but it was one of the best veggies I've ever had in my life.  All in all a great experience and a renowned restaurant in Montreal. Tip - Make sure to make a reso or its difficult to get a table by walking in

Delicious food and a must if you're in Montreal. Come in hungry bc you'll get a rich and hearty meal. We ordered the infamous duck in a can, mushroom tortellini (tonites special), the steamed dumplings & plogue a Champlain "foie gras breakfast" - which was the highlight of the night. buckwheat pancake,  thick Canadian bacon, potatoes and cheese topped with foie gras. I wish it was one of the earlier items delivered I would have enjoyed a few more bites. Would def come here with a group to be able to taste more items on the menu. It's a busy restaurant so do make reservations. We scored 9:30 pm reservations on a Sunday night and place was packed with ppl still coming in with reservations after us. Service was slow and we had a really long wait b/t entrees coming out. We didn't leave until after 11:30. Luckily for us, our toddler was still on California time and was cooperative.

Love this restaurant.The vibe, decor and service are all great.A seat at the provides front seat view of the amazing kitchen and chefs at work.  Have had their fried fois gras, sausage pot, duck in a can, poutine and their brulee.  Super heavy and delectably delicious. Can't eat a lot there without feeling like I need to walk for 5 hours but I do anyways. Sausage pot is a repeat order!Their wine list and recommendations were good.

I don't know how I'm just now rating this place but it's one of the best restaurants I've ever been to. My fiancé and I came here on our last night in Montreal on vacation. Everything we ate was incredible but the star was the foie gras nigiri - an appetizer I would usually not order but it was incredible. The service was amazing, the bathroom is even cool... just go here.
Mediocre food and portions are way too heavy. Service feels rushed and everything is just too loud. I would not go back here

This place is insanely delicious.  The restaurant is a bit tight on space but the kitchen is opened. You can actually hear the staff call out orders.  There are so many options that we probably over ordered for two people!! For starters, we had poutine with foie gras, duck carpaccio and beef tongue.  For entrees we had the duck in a can and the blood sausage tart.  The duck in the can was amazing! We totally over did it on the foie gras but you only live once! We had so much foodWe had to call ahead so the restaurant could accommodate our baby.

Dined here for a friend's birthday and it did not disappoint. Just plan on going all in here and be ready for a decadent dining experience.  The deep fried Fois Gras is absolutely not to be missed and is the fois gras poutine.  (no it's not to much Fois!)  This is also one of the few restaurants that truly believes in the magic of air conditioning!  Arrive hungry and be prepared to lie down for a bit after eating!  YUM!

Great meal - rich and heavy, but thoughtful service and advice made it a great experience. We had the foie gras poutine and the pork chop for two - and (barely) saved room for the maple creme brulee...Highly recommended!

Came here for a birthday dinner and were not disappointed. The food was beyond delicious!! Portions are perfect for sharing, plus that way you can experience every kind of flavor. Anything you get from the Foie Gras section is cooked to perfection where it just melts in your mouth(I'm drooling as I write this review FYI). We also got a lobster roll which was the best  one I've had in a while. Definitely a cool experience but even better food!!

This restaurant is a 'must visit' in Montreal, serving dishes that are just beyond the ordinary! The ambience is lively, cheerful, and comfortable. Not a quiet scene, so if you're looking to have a deep and meaningful conversation, maybe head to speak easy after or one of the many public outdoor spaces Montreal provides. The food here is the star, serving unique fair of French inspired cuisine. Two 'must eat' dishes, the Canned Duck and the PDC (the restaurant is named after it). Unique and awesomely rich flavors, but will have you food coma'd before the night is out! Beware though, the PDC is a portion for 4 given its dense nature. If you're adventurous, try the 'whelk'. Served in its shell with ample amounts of garlic and butter. This thing had going back for more. Don't forget to mop it up with their freshly baked, sour dough!! (You won't regret it)Book in advance as this restaurant is booked out for at least 2 weeks ahead.

Came here on our first night in Montreal and we were not disappointed. I was able to book an online reservation for 2 about a week in advance. Would definitely recommend making a reservation as people were still waiting to be seated by the time we finished our dinner at around 11p.Food - We ordered the foie cromesquis, foie gras pizza, foie gras poutine and duck in a can. Loved the cromesquis (if you order, wait at least 30 seconds before eating as the inside filling is HOT) as they were juicy and flavorful. Don't want to be inappropriate here, but make sure you eat them in one big bite because the filling bursts in your mouth (please get your mind out of the gutter). The foie gras pizza was great with small chunks of foie that wasn't too heavy and fresh cheese. The poutine was also delicious and we finished the entire plate. The only mild disappointment was the duck in a can. The presentation was unique and memorable, but as a dish I thought it was only okay. It was very heavy and the flavor didn't wow me in any way. Ambience - very loud! I could barely hear my hubs so it was really hard to hold a conversation. Overall, I would recommend a visit and would come again to try more of the pork dishes for the entree.

We got the poutine foie gras and duck in a can - it was fantastic!!!! So good! I could see why Andrew Zimmern and Anthony Bourdain raved about this place. It's seriously super delicious and a great way to get a taste of the delicious culture here!

Alert: Richness overload aheadIn the quest of finding the best poutine in Montreal, I stumbled on one of the most iconic places in Montreal (my friend and Food networks seem to swear by it..so here goes). Foie gras on its own? yes!Poutine on its own? yes!Foie gras & poutine together? Why Not? Brace yourself for what could possibly one of the richest flavored food ever! This rich, unctuous delicacy is only served at Au Pied du Cochon! I remembered fries swimming in gravy deliciousness (with the cheese curds) and a generous chunks of foie gras on it! The foie gras added an additional richness elements to an already rich dish..to some extent a bit redundant.Bottom line/Final Verdict: instead of getting the best poutine ever, I got the richest poutine ever! But does it mean necessarily richest = the bestest? Not necessarily. But it's a pretty interesting take on poutine. A little too rich for my liking (I'm poutined up! Possibly because this dish is so rich that it just bump you to the limit of poutine quota), but still it does not take a way the fact that is a solid dish, and at CAD 24 plus tax this is the most luxurious poutine I ever had (more than I'd like to spend on poutine)PS: This is only based on take out experience. Be sure to make reservation way ahead of time if you want to dine in here! It seems to be always packed and not sure they let you in without one!

Au Pied de Cochon was an amazing experience. It's been almost a week since I dined there on Duluth Street, but I'm still talking about the evening. I booked reservations a few weeks in advance of my trip, knowing that it was not a place that you can walk into. A few people I met with in Montreal were surprised that I was able to get a seat - until they heard that I had planned ahead. Our waitress was great and provides great advice and recommendations. This place was hyped up and was ready for high expectations. Here's what we ate:Appetizers:Cromesquis Foie Gras - very rich and the right size to pop in your mouth. A nice way to experience foie gras. Poutine Foie Gras - decadent. My dining companion had this as his first poutine. All future poutine will now be disappointing. Smoke Shack Ham - served with lovely little pancakes. This was a delicious meat. Mains:Zampone - a pigs foot stuffed with charcuterie and served with a maple glaze. Very rich. A delicacy which will induce a happy food coma. Duck in a Can - the most underwhelming item we tried. It was not that flavorful and was a bit mushy. Dessert - we were too full. Did you read what we ate?We had a great bottle of wine and our waitress treated us to shots of a liqueur after lounging in our food coma state. The ambience was great. The weather was nice and the doors were open to the street. The restaurant was crowded but not uncomfortable. The restroom was really hot. It felt like the heat was on in there. In summary, make a reservation and go to Au Pied de Cochon! It's a wonderful gastronomic experience that blends the allure of the sugar shack with modern Canadian cuisine. I hope to go back!

Went on V-day and the place was packed. The food was fantastic!!! Duck in a can and foie gras (plogue a Champlain) are both unbelievablely amazing dishes. I know the French have pretty hard baguettes but I think their could have been a tad less tough. Other than that and it being a bit on the pricey end everything was delicious and staff were very friendly/kind. Tip: make reservations in advance especially for weekends

I've been recommending this place even before I ate there myself. It's reputation precedes it for good reason. I finally was able to enjoy the food here in a weekend trip with my close friends. Highly recommend to make reservations beforehand. The place is always full. Foie gras sashimi - I would drive ask the way back to Montreal for this single item on the menuDuck in a can - this is what they're known for, you can't eat here without ordering this. How they cook their duck to perfection in that can is just wizardry in my eyes. This also takes FOREVER to make, so make sure you order other stuff too to hold you over.Every single dish we ordered was fantastic. Our waiter was very patient with us because some of they had run out of some of the dishes we wanted. He suggested we share some items, but I was craving a burger (how do you share that?), so I got what I wanted and everyone share split pasta, meat loaf, lamb. Our duck in a can took nearly an hour to come out, and our waiter appeased us by giving us shots on the house. Don't mind the wait after that!

A bite from our full review - "Our waiter came with a small mezzaluna and cut up the pizza swiftly in front of us making for a great presentation. The portion was not too big, but very succulent. We felt an explosion of taste with sweet maple syrup drizzled on top, smoked meats and fresh mozzarella which felt a bit like ricotta instead."

I really mean to give PdC 4.75 stars but only because I went to Joe Beef the night after so I had a good comparison. Gluttony is my middle name and I can usually handle everything, but I woke up feeling nauseous because things were settling weird after PdC. Granted, I shouldn't have stuffed myself with all things fat and cream in one sitting...With that said, everything was really good, though again, really heavy with rich sauces and fat. We even ordered a salad, which didn't help, because there were cubes of fried pork in it. Now I understand why the French drink wine with their food. It definitely helps to cut the heaviness.Cromequis de foie gras (foie gras cromesquis) - Amazing! You let it cool for a bit so you don't burn your mouth, pop it in, bite down, and let the flavors explode. It's awesome. My friend had a bad experience with foie gras because it was grainy and we had to explain that foie is supposed to be smooth. She tried this and was converted.Langue de bison a l'estragon (tarragon bison tongue) - Another amazing app. The tongue is tender and flavors worked in unison. Plus, there were bits of carrots so yay for veggies.Carpaccio de canard (duck carpaccio) - I liked it, but my friends didn't think it stood up next to the other two apps. It was mild in flavor and I didn't care for the cheese shavings on top, but the carpaccio itself with good and fresh.Poutine au foie gras (foie gras poutine) - we ordered a half size because we had a lot of food coming. Fries were good and crunchy and gravy was poured over it. Sitting on top of the gravy was a huge chunk of foie. Overall delicious, but we're glad we didn't order the full serving.Special of the day: Calamari and fries in squid ink sauce - I guess when the server mentioned the special all we heard was calamari and squid ink sauce because we didn't know it came with fries. I think there were more fries than calamari, possibly half and half, and the sauce was decadent and thick. There were also gold flakes sprinkled on top which were pretty cool. Good dish nonetheless, and quite different from what I've experienced at other restaurants.Special of the day: Salad with pork - I forgot what kind of salad the server said this was, but it came with a lot of cubed pork on top of two or three pieces of lettuce and arugula. On the side were two rounds of bread with chevre spread onto it. Probably can skip.Duck in a Can - get this! Sooo good! Don't even ask questions, just do it.Ordered some more dishes... but I don't remember what they were at this point. I need a return visit to remember.

Au Pied de Cochon did not disappointment I had made my reservations for myself and 3 friends about 2 weeks out for 10pm. It was our big stop for our large road trip. The emails and telephone calls, the staff were very professional and courteous. When we arrived, it started to rain, so they had to move some tables inside, and we ended up sitting at the bar, which was no problem. The food was incredible, even when it was super hyped up to me beforehand. Usually being hyped up about something ruins an experience, but not here. We had the duck in the can, smoked meat, poutine, vegetable, carpaccio special, and one other dish that involved smoke ham and a sweet pastry. I wish we had ordered a bit less so that we would've had enough room for dessert!Our server at the bar was also great and friendly, and very helpful and attentive. She was pretty excellent. I feel bad because I had miscalculated the tip in my head, and gave a poor tip, this had only occurred to me much after we had left. Next time, I will make up for it.

Oh yes, if you have some extra cash and looking for a five star dining experience, you know this is the place to come. You will have to make reservations in advance and apparently Sundays are not as crazy busy as Fridays or Saturdays. Their foie gras is to die for! Literally, I had a foodgasm when I took a bite of this delicious goodness. Next comes the service, just perfect. The restaurant staff are polite, friendly and attentive, when you need to make a hard choice they'll be there to make a suggestion. It was definitely a different kind of dining experience and yes, I will come back again, not just because of foie gras. By the way, if you looking for a place to impress your date, this could be it.

PD f**kin' C!  Not the first time. Not the last time. Always a reason to come back to this joint. Spot on Service - maitre d' amazing - Food Spectacular! Atmosphere was only outshined by the Dishes. Creative. Flavorful. Everything you would need...... A+
Great service! Great foods! This meal is very heavy but too good! My favourite dishes is stuffed Pied de Cochon & Foie gras. The Pecan pie with homemade maple sirup ice cream is a must try.

After looking at all the great reviews. Decided to check this place out. We ordered the foie gras lobe that costed $120. It was either 500g or 600g of foie gras. It takes an hour to make this dish. It consisted of foie gras, ham, bread and berries. I did not like this dish. It was not to my liking. I did not expect this dish to come sweet and fruity. When the waiter said that there was a dessert that came with it. I didn't think that it was going to mixed inside with the foie gras. It was odd, different from the foie gras served at other restaurants. They had delicious bread too. Soft on the inside and crispy on the outside.  Presentation wise. The food was not appeal. On the good side, their service was great! The server came by really often to fill water. I may consider coming back to try their other foie gras dishes as they have a wide selection. But the foie gras lobe is totally not worth it. It just didn't taste good to me.

What can I say about this place other than it is probably one of the best restaurants to eat in Montreal.  You have to try it to even comprehend the types of food and flavours involved in the stuff they are making here.  On top of all this book in advance if you want to try it!  I had to book well in advance to even get a spot and the earliest spot I was able to get was a dinner at 10:30pm at night.  I guess everyone knows about how great this place is along with the tourists as well.My gf and I ordered  Duck in a Can, Foie Gras Poutine and the massive sized, Au Pied de Cochon.  I must say I have never eaten that much foie gras in my life let along in one sitting!  The poutine a staple dish in Montreal dining, was creamy and different than anything I'm used to having.  The piece of foie gras they placed on it was gigantic as well, about 10x larger than any fine dining restaurant I've been to.  Duck in a can was amazing, the presentation was unique and the taste was something unexpected.  So many flavours and juicy tasting duck crammed into a tiny can was incredible.  And the masterpiece known as Au Pied de Cochon, was huge!  The pork was very tender and went really well with the massive foie gras they placed on top.  This was so large of a dish we couldn't finish it and ended up eating it for the next 3 days!  Overall an amazing experience and I really loved the atmosphere.  Portions are ginormous here so keep that in mind when ordering.  The prices to me were justified based on the amount of food you get along with the ingredients used.  I literally had a couple of pounds worth of foie gras that night, so I was surprised the bill wasn't more.  I am definitely coming back here again if I can somehow get a reservation again!

This is one of my favorite restaurants, but I have only been able to eat at it twice in the last 2 years because I live in the USA. The last time I tried I didn't have a reservation and was turned away because they are always packed. Lock up a reservation a month in advance online. This weekend I had:Temaki TartareFois Gras NigiriFois Gras PoutineThis cod pastry, which I forgot the name ofCucumber/lime cocktail ($12)Cucumber/lime mocktail ($3.75)All this was $126 USD with tax and a 20% tip included. Damn I love that exchange rate!Everything was delicious like usual. The Foie Gras poutine was a little skimpy on the Foie Gras compared to the last time I had it though. Service is great. The bathroom has a Japanese toilet. I'm not really sure what the point of that is but its interesting.

My dinner here was easily in the top 5 dining experiences in my life. The food was fantastic. I had no idea Foie Gras could be used in so many dishes. There was a blood sausage dish on some kind of pastry that was also phenomenal. Sam, our waiter, provided service above and beyond anything we could have expected. We had a reservation for 11 for a bachelor party- not a particularly easy group to deal with. Sam and the kitchen staff really made the whole night an exceptional experience.

We visited this place for the first time, mainly driven by the great reviews and its vibrant atmosphere. We got the Roquefort salad, the Melting Pot and the foie gras burger.The salad was really good. The bread served on the side was fresh and tasty. The Melting Pot was quite indifferent. One of the pork pieces was seriously undercooked and impossible to cut and chew. The rest were ok. The foie gras burger was heavy as stone, due to the very strong taste of the patty.The service was exceptional!Unfortunately it was too greasy for me, I'll pass..

Very rich food. If you like your food too creamy or too buttery, then this is your type of food. Everything was just very heavy and I couldn't seem to finish the dish. The FG is actually not bad as this was my first time tasting it. Definitely not something I would typically eat but at least I tried it! Plogue Champlain $29Pork filet $30Fg hamburger $39Squash risotto $24Fg poutine $24Eel tart $14The place was jam packed and there's absolutely no room to move if you're sitting on the outside of the table. Service is slow because of how busy it is. Might take you 10min to get the attention of a waitress and another 10 for the bill. Overall definitely a place to try but not something I would do again as its not really my type of food fare.

I love pig, but this was a bit too funky for me. There were a lot of exotics like tongue and tail that were a bit risqué for me, so for that reason ONLY I gave it 2 stars. The place is packed and EXTREMELY popular so for the risqué people I'm sure it's quite delish, but for me, I'll pass.

If you are in Montreal, you must come here! The food is extremely unique and delicious. The foie gras nigiri, the onion soup, and the duck in a can are some of the most delicious food I've ever eaten. The service is unparalleled as well, Molina and Flo were attentive, friendly, kind, and created a fantastic dining experience.

One of Lonely Planet's top picks for Quebecois cuisine in Montreal.  It was a lively place on a Saturday evening.  The staff is super friendly and helpful.  Had to try the signature Foie Gras poutine and it was ridiculously good!  Big chunks of foie on top, a flavorful but still light gravy, and the frites were still crispy.  The duck-in-a-can is very innovative and the duck breast gets nice flavors from the vegetables and herbs it is braised with (and you get another hunk of foie!).Will definitely come back with a group to try one of the huge trout that swim around the tank in front!

DISAPPOINTED.I rarely write reviews. But my experience at this restaurant was particularly BELOW expectation in every way, that I had to write something about it.Me and my partner had a reservation at 8pm and we came in 10 minutes early. No one in the restaurant told us that there was this line just for those with reservations and people kept on trying to cut in because they also had reservations, thinking that this line was for those who just walked in. There was no one to keep people in order and it was just chaos. We were then seated after 30minutes of waiting. Once we ordered our food, we then had to wait an hour and 30 minutes for our first food to come to our table. No waiter ever informed us that our food will take this long, or even just assuring us that our food is on the way. A lot of people around us who were seated after us got their meals way before we did, which was bizzare. It was also really hard to get a hold the waiter. The food was just okay, nothing special.Will never visit this place again, and would deter all of my friends who even show interest of going there.

It was awesome. Point final. Super chill service! Felt like a chill small low key restaurant which is real cool considering its super famous now. Had canard en conserver, mapo tofu and cote de porc. Each of us liked one dish most. I felt like eating stuff that the coureur des bois used to eat. So rich. So satisfying

This place was highly recommended and it didn't disappoint! A reservation is a must! The restaurant itself is casual and every inch is  utilize for tables. You will feel a bit wedged in once you're seated but won't care once you start to eat! There were three of us in our party and we had the following: - Foie gras poutine which was a nice starter. The gravy was so flavorful, the curds so squeaky and the foie gras was just enough. We were happy the portion was on the smaller side so you don't fill up on fries before the main course. - Duck in a can which is one of their signature dishes. The duck is actually cooked in the can (for a precise 27 minutes) and they open/plate it right at the table. It was rich but delightful!- Foie gras hamburger .... amazing is not a strong enough word... it is beyond good. Incredibly decedent with the venison burger, foie gras, bacon and fixings, this one is not to be missed!- For dessert we got the milkshake XXX (meaning with booze) and the maple creme brûlée to top off our meal.Our experience was excellent from start to finish!

I'd be lying if I said I didn't have a tendency to overcompensate. I have been guilty of pushing myself to run 2-3 times the distance of a missed run day on the next day to "make up" for lost time; I once went 300 dollars overbudget on a TV because the exact one I've been saving up for was conveniently sold out the day I went to purchase it; I also drove 300 miles to a brewery to buy a case of beer when I found out that my local distribution wells had just sold out.Foie gras isn't something that I'm known to go nuts about--I've actually only had it once previous to my dining experience at Au Pied de Cochon--but it did bring a slight frown to my face when a state-wide ban on one of the world's three delicacies was instituted a couple years back, depriving me of the oppportunity to ever try it again (at least at my home state)So you can only imagine my delight when I stumbled upon yet another opportunity to overcompensate, when I learned about a restaurant that pretty much drowns everything in the chopped liver of a stuffed goose while conferring with a friend about a possible trip to Montréal; I was also amused when I found out that said restaurant also likes to stuff ducks into cans and serve them atop slices of baguettes, but I'll save that story for later.My Calgarian friend and I ended up at Au Pied de Cochon after making reservations weeks ahead (we tried the same for Joe Beef, but no such luck there.) Once we got to the restaurant, we found ourselves behind a murder of crow-like uppity bachelorette party girls who apparently had been double-booked and waiting for over an hour for the restaurant to accommodate. Whereas this wasn't a great start to the evening, listening to four Indian girls bitch drunkenly about how they think they're better than others and how the restaurant should cater to their every need brought both a chuckle to my face and a glimmering hope that maybe they would shut their annoying pie-holes.Annoyances you would more often than not experience at fancy world-class restaurants aside, we were promptly seated at the bar by the charming hostess who took our orders at the bar while securing our table in the main dining area. While waiting for the food, I ordered APdC's homebrew ale, which never made its way to me, perhaps because our tables were moved or because they forgot, but it didn't bother me too much.For the appetizer, we ordered the evening special which was a seafood gratin of sorts baked into a fluffy eggy batter with just the right amount of cheese. I can still remember every bite of that delicious seafood/vegetable filled fake-pie. What's more, is that I remember my friend trying to cut up and eat the cork wood coaster that the gratin was served on.Next came the Duck Carpaccio -- out of all the thinly sliced meats/fish/vegetables I've tried in my life, this was probably my favorite. The duck was topped with fresh onions and mushrooms, served on top of a dreamy bed of olive oil and a sprinkle of balsamic vinegar.While the main courses were cooking in the back, our Foie Gras Poutine graced the table like an angel descended from heaven -- my friend and I tried a lifetime's worth of poutine during our 3-day excursion in Montréal, but we both agreed that this was quite possibly the most exquisite that we'd had. The way the foie gras gravy mixes with the cheese curdles and the fries.... I have absolutely no words to describe the unholy matrimony of the two.The Stuffed Pied de Cochon was the first of the heavy hitters to land at our table. Think Schweinhaxe meets foie gras, takes her out to romantic first and second dates, and then goes hard and heavy on the third. I never thought I'd ever enjoy eating pig's foot (even though it does appear to be a delicacy in certain regions of my country of heritage), but who can say no when the meat is so tender, juicy, tangy, and tart at the same time? Hell, make anything taste like the aforementioned adjectives, and I'll eat anything -- just don't tell me what it is until I'm done.And finally, our coup de grâce was served to us in the form of a white can with the words "CANARD EN CONSERVE" and ungracefully plopped onto a serving plate on top of four finely sliced pieces of baguette. How it landed so perfectly and artfully despite its forceful ejection out of a metal can, I will never know, but one thing is for sure; I have never known life until I've had a perfectly delightful meal served out of a can, and I'm glad that meal took place at Au Pied de Cochon.Probably one of the top three best meals I've had in my life. I'll definitely be coming back the next time I'm in town!

dunno what happened the last time I was here. Service was pretty bad. Maybe the most junior bussers were given the opportunity to be waiters that night. It was like you picked up the staff from a student run cafe and put them in charge. The waiter congratulated himself on how much he could carry. Moments later he dropped a number of plates, a few inches from me. No real apology there. They brought some other table's drink to us. Don't know if they ever got it. We ordered coffee and deserts. Some how the deserts arrived 30+ minutes after the coffees. How long does it take to grab a premaid pie? The waiter forgot to get a signature for the credit card. Then he made a joke about how he could just forge the signature. Dude was in general creepy and not really funny in the way he thinks.

Highly Recommended.Get the Duck in the Can, Foie, and the Burger. And order some stuff to share at the table. Au Pied de Cochon is famous from its appearance on the Anthony Bourdain hosted No Reservations episode in Quebec. travelchannel.com/tv-sho…My first love here will always be the duck in a can (44.00$) which you can order to go since it'll last 2-3 days if refrigerated. This may very well be the best thing I ever ate that I didn't cook. half a duck breast, 100g of foie gras, mushrooms, half a head of garlic, and vegetables.The Foie gras shots are a winner to start with. Small, simple, superb.The Foie gras 'tout nu' is a very close second. Its simplicity is its strongest suit. Balsamic glazed seared foie gras atop large crustinis.If you want to turn the tout nu on it's head, but with the same flavors, go with the Foie gras hamburger, this massive beast of a burger will leave you with no regrets.The Foie gras Poutine is alright, I feel like they could have done so much more with this dish, same with the terrine. The next time I'm back, I want to try the cured foie gras & boudin tart and the foie gras DuoMy beer recommendations include the Cheval Blanc and Cream Ale. The XXX Milkshake is also a dream, like one of those really willd fantasies that make you keep wanting more.Chef Martin Picard does wonders with meats and foie. We had duck terrine, duck foie gras cubed, frozen and fried.

ATMOSPHERE 5/5 - Perfect and lively. We came at 8pm w/reservations and it was crowded! I think I made the reservation 3 weeks in advance on their website.SERVICE 5/5 - Our server was lively and helpful but my one critique was that he talked incredibly fast so we had a difficult time understanding the dish ingredients in combination to the noise in the restaurant. APPETIZER 5/5 - Tartare Temaki: I was really hesitant about this dish but because of my dairy sensitivity, it was the only appetizer that I could consume. Anyway, this was amazing. It was tender, tasty and it had a QUAIL EGG you pour into the temaki. MAIN 5/5 - Duck in a can (onions, cabbage, bacon, thyme, garlic cooked in butter and 100 g of foie gras). This was a memorable dish!!! It was so decadent and pairs perfectly with a glass of red wine. You'll never forget this dish and it's a must try in Montreal.MAIN 5/5 - Pork Chop: wow this was delicious. The sauce was incredible and the pork chop was cooked to perfection! If I come back to this restaurant, I would definitely reorder the pork chop. It gets overshadowed by the novelty of the Duck in a Can and the Stuffed Pied de Cochon w/foie gras. DESSERT 5/5 - Pecan Pie: again, I cannot eat dairy so this was the only dessert I was able to order but let me tell you that this was the BEST pecan pie my partner and I have ever tasted!! Inside was gooey caramel topped with perfectly toasted pecans. The crust = A++++BATHROOM 5/5 - I know.. weird I am commenting on the bathroom after dessert but the toilet seat was heated and bathroom was clean. There's a TV in front of the toilet that shows what's going on in the kitchen (I think). I need to come back to Montreal to have another memorable meal at Au Pied de Cochon!

I have been coming to APC since 2005 and every year we make our food pilgrimage to APC and every year it does not disappoint.  We are foodies that would drive 7 hours from nyc just for the weekend to eat and why not, for the price and the quality of food Montreal is it.  About two years ago we have decided to let the manager Florent to do the ordering for us.  I always have a posse of 6 or more people joining me as these portion are made to share and what an awesome time we all have.  Many of us go into food coma afterwards but since we have prepare for this very 6 months this is what we came for.  This is the place that gets better and better every year!!!! I cannot say enough about it.  The service, the food and even the loud atmosphere, I love all of it!! Everyone who I brought to this place is now a convert! Out of all the good restaurants in Montreal this is the best hands down but the only other place can beat this place is their Sugar Shack.  We have been lucky enough to score reservations for a few years now and yeah that place is better than this place but it is like comparing apples and oranges.  Anyway if I can give more stars this place would be it!!!

OMG!   What an "experience".  From start to finish, this place executed on all levels.   Great wine list, creative food and all while enjoying the show from the bar.  Paul is a gastronomical artist.  Watching from the bar allows you to view the well-choreographed chaos.   When visiting Montréal in the future, this is a must!!Thanks guys for a wonderful experience for my gf's b-day!!

The food here is very rich/heavy.We ordered:Appetizer - Foie Gras Cromesquis (2 pieces of fried bread cubes with foie gras inside) nice and small appetizer.Appetizer - Tuna tartare this was a special item. I'm not a fan of tuna tartar with olive oil, prefer it with some lime juice instead. The oil overpowers the fishAppetizer - Poutine gave it a try while in Montreal. Not a fan its french fries with gravy and cheese that does not meltThe duck in can - this was literally a duck (1/4 of a duck?) comes with some vegetables and foie gras. Rich meal, but not as much as I would have imagined for $44.Overall the food was fine. Be prepared for a heavy/rich meal.

Mecca for Foie GrasWithout a doubt, the world's greatest collection of foie gras preparations are served here. This restaurant was featured by the late and great Anthony Bordain on season 2, episode 4 of No Reservations.(dailymotion.com/video/x2…). After having watched that episode, I arrived with an appetite to experience this restaurant that went beyond that of my palate and stomach. It was meaningful to me that we were sat just behind the counter where Bordain sat during the filming of that episode. I ordered the Foie Gras Poutine. As many have stated, this was the best poutine I've ever had. The foie gras was seared and bite sized allowing for perfectly portioned trio of foie gras, french fries and curds. There was traditional brown gravy but also a decadent lighter colored buttery sauce. As a second app we ordered the Burrata special which came with cherry tomatoes and basil. It was also the best Burrata I've had. So we were two for two. I was really intrigued by the Duck in a Can and needed to experience it. In addition I also tried the Duck Magret. Although the Duck in a Can was an inventive way to prepare and cook that combination of ingredients, it fell short for me. The Duck itself was very tough in texture and definitely had a metallic after taste from the can itself. The foie gras that was included in the can was not seared (my preferred preparation). In addition, the Duck Magret was amazing in comparison so it was hard to continue forward with the Duck in a Can dish with a perfectly prepared medium rare duck breast on the table. It was the duck equivalent of best filet mignon on can have and it was served with a rich brown sauce accompaniment. Let me reiterate that I wasn't unhappy with my Duck in a Can. But I didn't eat much of it and denied the waiter's offer to wrap it up for me to go. To his credit, he wanted to know why I didn't finish it nor wanted to wrap it up and I explained (although that wasn't something I would have mentioned had he not asked). After hearing that, he spoke to the manager who offered us a complimentary dessert. We chose the pecan pie and it was an amazing finale to an amazing overall experience. The service was great. The restaurant is well, if not over, staffed and no less than 6 employees worked my table. This is definitely a must hit.

APDC is probably the most iconic restaurant in Montreal. It's a contemporary Quebecois restaurant, not French, but considered Quebecois or French-Canadian. The cuisine is extraordinary rich and heavy, perfect for carnivores, and fit as comfort food during cold weather. I couldn't have dined in at a more appropriate time, a day when it was snowing in Montreal during May.A long time customer who I sat next to at the bar told me that the menu got condensed over the years. He said that the food is still solid and decadent though.Sunday is probably the worst day to dine at APDC. It's the end of their week, so many items were sold out. The server named a few special items but was unable to translate it to English so I skipped them. Since the restaurant is known for cooking every single part of a pig, I ordered the "Happy Pork Chop". The next item on the menu "PDC cut" is basically a double portion for 2 people (over 1 pound of pork). I also ordered the signature cromesquis de foie gras as an appetizer.The cromesquis was like a pork-based croquette molded into a cube. It looked harmless on the outside, but it's lethal inside. The interior, filled with foie gras in creamy and runny form, explodes once the crust penetrates, so be sure to consume it one bite!The roasted pork chop was crispy on the outside but slightly on the dry side. The meat was tender and tasted great with the caramelized onion, button mushroom, and sweet bergundy mushroom gravy. The gravy was full bodied and the dish was very filling.Since I didn't order any large appetizers, I was able to save room for a dessert. I had the pouding chomeur a l'erable, a very classical Quebecois sweet consisting of hot crusty bread pudding drowned with housemade maple syrup. The thick maple syrup was very sweet but served warm and extremely comforting to eat. It was the perfect way to end the meal on a cold night.Being from California, I honestly don't think I would have a craving for the Quebecois food served at APDC. But since the mood and weather was a perfect fit during my visit, I had a terrific 4-star experience.A few tips:1. Make a reservation by email: reservations@restauranta…The restaurant somehow lost my reservation and was about to turn me away, but fortunately I pulled up my reservation confirmed by email and they let me in.2. Best seat is at the counter, not the bar, they're way different. The most you'll see at the bar is a server cleaning glasses.3. The restaurant is loud and cozy. 50% local, 50% tourists during my time of visit.

For my boyfriend and my final dinner in Montreal, we made reservations at Au Pied de Cochon.We were greeted by a friendly waiter and he went through the specials with us (there were a lot of specials). He described the cold lobster soup ($12) so well, I decided to go with it. We also got oysters (6 for $18) because I love raw oysters. Lastly, we had to get au pied de cohon au foie gras ($45). The waiter was nice enough to tell us that hte au pied de cochon will be enough for the two us and that we shouldn't order any other mains. They also offered us freshly baked bread as we waited for our appetizers and main meal.When we got the cold lobster soup, we were surprised because we didn't hear the waiter mentioning that it was cold. It was quite salty and I didn't catch any lobster flavour in the soup at all.When the oysters came, I was super excited until I saw the size of it. It was quite small considering it was $3 a piece. I could get the same size oyster for cheaper ($1 a piece) at Biff's Bistro in Toronto during their happy hour. Nonetheless, the oysters were delicious and the sauce that it came with went wonderfully together.Lastly was our main meal which took 30 minutes of wait time after finishing our appetizers. The meat fell off the pig's foot. The sauce over the mushrooms was so good. The best part was the mashed potato with cheese melted into it. This restaurant really lived up to its hype on this dish.However, our night sadly went downhill because the waiter was nowhere to be seen. We wanted to see the dessert menu to possibly order more food. However, every time we see him, he'll finish talking to another customer and then walk the opposite direction from where we were sitting. Finally, we decided to get the bill. We finally flagged him down and he didn't get back to us at all. From the end of our main meal to trying to get the dessert menu to us trying to get the bill took over 30 minutes. In the end, it was another person (looks like the manger) who got us the bill.I still give this place four stars. Although the waiter completely failed at serving our table, the food was awesome and the price point wasn't too bad.

This was one of the best restaurants I went to in Montreal, way better than the more highly rated joe beef. The duck in a can was such a cool idea but it was a little too oily even for me. I really liked the french sausage recommended by the waitress I think it was called audiolle? Made of pig intestine

Drove all the way from New York City to try this restaurant because Anthony Boudain was here..It is definitely worth the drive. The waitress was excellent, she was very thorough with the menu it's impressive that she remembered everything on it.I love Foie Gras, so I was in heaven!!..every dish had Foie Gras... LOVE LOVE LOVE

Must go restaurant in Montreal.My father and I went there for foie gras specifically. So we ordered three dishes with foie gras, cromesquis, fruit FG and duck in a can. They were all very good. My father said it was his first time to have foie gras smooth and soft like this.The duck in a can came after a long wait, but they compensated us with a plate of prosciutto, which was very good as well, a little too salty I would say. My father also thought that the duck was too oily. I kind of felt in the same way.Overall it was a great experience. I will come again.

the food is amazing, successfully balancing a bunch of bold flavors...the ham w/ donuts soaked in maple syrup: tremendous. the foie burger: over the top. the chicken: delicate. the maple pudding chromeur: insane.
