If I could give 3.5 stars I would, but our experience was not a 4.  The space is tight, but not terrible or a turn-off.  The servers were not the nicest or most helpful of our trip.  The open kitchen is cool but also adds to the already crazy amount of noise in the dinning room.We started by trying to order wine, but the waitress was not very helpful or interested in making recommendations.  Also, all of the reds were served chilled, which we were not fans of.  The beer selection is OK, but non of the brews are that great.The single dish that was the best of our trip and bumped up this place's total rating was the onion soup.  The was piping hot, super flavorful with lots of soft onions and huge chunks of bacon.  The broth was the best onion soup broth we have ever had.  The melted cheese and bread chunks were also an added bonus.After this starter, our hopes were super high.  Unfortunately, two dishes we were interested in ordering, the Happy Pork Chop and the PDC Cut were both out.  It was Friday at 6pm - how are you out?!  My wife settled for the Duck Margret which was a medium (she would have preferred more rare) cooked breast with a wine and mushroom sauce.  She said it was just OK, and after I tasted it I agreed.  Not bad, not good, nothing special.  My meal was much better.  I had the special: table side risotto, made INSIDE a huge Parmesan wheel, with peas and chunks of bacon.  It was very cheesy and delicious, but made table side also meant it was not tasted or flavored or seasoned as well as it could have been.  It was very good, but could have been better.After the amazing soup, the rest of the meal and service was a let down.  We expected so much coming in but left disappointed, which is a shame because it wasn't a bad meal but it also wasn't a great meal.

The hype - it's so real. Probably one of the best meals I've ever had, both for taste and for the memories. It's a beloved spot, and there's a reason for it. If you're a first-timer in Montreal, this should definitely be on your dinner list. First, make reservations (we emailed). I can't stress that enough. We made reservations 3 months in advance of our weekend trip to Montreal, and I'm glad we did - we watched throngs of people trying to get in on a Friday night without a reservation and they were turned away.Second, the environment. Bustling, boisterous, lively. Upscale feel but still comfortable and homey. Service was so sweet, not pushy at all, and made the effort to rattle off all 9 specials (by memory) including the price, so we wouldn't have to ask.Third, the food. Rich, comforting, and so delicious. Note that this is a very, very heavy meal, with large, generous portions, so come hungry. We ordered: a) Cromesquis de foie gras (appetizer, $4.00), b) Charcuterie Plate (appetizer, $16.00), c) Beef Rib ($30.00), d) Pork Chop with lentils ($20.00), and e) drinks. Everything was delicious, but the standouts for us were both appetizers and the Beef Rib, which also came with mashed potatoes. So rich, delicious, fell off the bone with the softest way possible. Everything was incredibly tasty, carefully cooked. The charcuterie plate was the best I've ever had, and cured to perfection. What else is there to say that hasn't been said already? I would definitely come back here again, and wholeheartedly recommend it, especially if you're a tourist in Montreal. The place is full of both tourists and locals, and is an atmosphere and meal you'll definitely remember.With tax and tip, the bill came to around $105.

When I asked a buncha friends where to go in Montreal, several of them immediately recommended Au Pied de Cochon as the "best meal of my life" but with the add on of "...if you can get reservations." Well, I remembered to go there but immediately forgot about the whole reservation part. However, that didn't stop us from showing up anyhow just to check if maybe we could slide by. Success!! We managed to snag the (apparently) elusive walk-in spot and were elated. The restaurant itself is bright and pretty, and the staff were super friendly and chatty. After a fantastic sparkling rosé suggestion from our server I was pretty much sold, we were feeling so good about getting in on a lark that there was basically no way this could have been a bad experience. We ordered the foie gras poutine (hey, I've never had it and we're in Montreal), dumplings with shrimp, pork and foie gras which were wrapped in squid ink and beet noodles and served with 'dragon sauce' and maple syrup (a real stand out!), and the duck in a can which also had foie gras. (So basically what I'm saying is several geese died for this meal.) Everything was very tasty- a totally satisfying and fun meal- though I can't say it was life changing by any means... it certainly seemed to be more of a seafood place so perhaps had we ordered the more expensive seafood-y stuff it woulda been life changing. Or maybe if I was a bigger fan of foie gras? (Like, it's fine but it doesn't make me do backflips.) But I'm pretty satisfied with it as just a good ol' fashioned stand out meal. We also ordered the maple crème brûlée because Canada- also a lovely choice. All in all, I think I would have been a little more disappointed had I waited months to get this reservation, but as a walk in it was positively delightful. (Maybe that's in part the bragging rights sweetening the deal.)

4.5 starsAu Pied de Cochon is a very lively restaurant. If drinks and fat in surplus is what you live for, you will love it here.I was lucky to visit with a friend of the chef so I have no knowledge about making reservations; only that you really need one and they are difficult to get. We sat at 9:30 on a Wednesday evening. It is a cute, small restaurant. Very narrow walking areas and difficult to hear. The music is quite loud. While all this adds to the vibe, I found it frustrating to not be able to understand the waiter or the people next to me at times. Certainly not a "romantic" evening spot.That said, the food is delicious, if very excessive. There is so much foie gras on the menu that it becomes shorthand to "fg".Overall, I found the food rich, too rich to me. There are no fruits or vegetables anywhere; just protein and fat. (Parsley was the ONLY green thing I saw all night long on a plate.) For some, this is heaven. For me, almost sickening. I love that the chef is true to himself though and doesn't worry about catering to everyone. He makes what he loves and forgets the rest. The wait staff is polite and helpful, explaining many things on the menu and patient with kids or large groups.We tried many, many things. The highlights?Maple soda. I did not see this on the menu but was offered it by the waiter because I passed on the alcohol; it is homemade and amazing! Bubbly, refreshing, not too sweet. The perfect cut against fat.Foie gras poutine - the gravy it out of this world rich and deliciousFoie gras fried bites - I forget the exact spelling but they were perfect piping hot squares of heaven. A MUST orderSeafood dumplings - a special that day; like dim sum with maple syrup on top. Amazing.Seafood platter - we ordered the "small" and it was still huge. so many things to try on it. A perfectly cooked octopus which is very difficult.Sugar pie - sweet, custard pie that is really scrumptious!The duck in a can was just okay to me - but I was overloaded by that point. Duck carpaccio was good. Bison tartare hand rolls were interesting with quail egg yolk - looked beautiful.---I would return if someone wished to, but not at the top of my list. It's just not my cup of tea. Everything was cooked well and interesting, I just need more vegetables and fruits.Everyone else in the group was on cloud 9 though, and so for that, I only deduct for the atmosphere, which is too loud to enjoy fully.P.S. Only one bathroom made wait times long, and no temperature control on the water. Washing hands in almost boiling water is so painful and almost made my kid sister cry. Ouch!

Over due update. I forgot to add to the original review that we had asked for the manager who said there was nothing she could do to compensate us for the horrible experience and she just claimed things happen sometimes.I contacted restaurant the next day and we played some phone tag due to cellphone coverage with a different manager or director/owner, he of course said he was surprised to hear my story. After some discussion he wanted us to come back in for another dinner. I explained to him that we were leaving the next day and that it wouldn't work. (Is that why they are consistently running behind by having make up dinners to unhappy customers?) His only other offer was to refund the cost of the duck in a can. It was really the least he could have done.If we had more time on our anniversary trip I still don't think we would have said yes to another opportunity to eat there.

The best meal I have had, EVER. My BF and I split the the foie gras poutine as an appetizer, the duck in a can and brussel sprouts. Generous portions. Great service. Sit at the bar in front of the kitchen, it is fascinating to watch the chefs do their magic. Cocktails were spot on and we also enjoyed a well-suggested French red wine with dinner. No room for dessert but it wasn't needed because we were both extremely satisfied. Highly recommend this place.
Awesome good, awesome time, great staff. Highly recommend it for large groups so you can get a ton of food.

Dear god. One of the best dining experiences I've ever had. Get the cromesquis, the foie gras poutine, the duck in a can, and the shepherd's pie, and the house cocktail with gin and maple syrup and champagne. Just delectable. Ask to sit at the bar to watch the kitchen work its magic. I have never seen such a loud, hectic, chaotic environment, it was like watching a food opera with chefs yelling at each other, tossing plates, salting food from across the kitchen, torching deserts, laughing etc. It was amazing, and a highlight of my trip. Despite the madness of how busy it is  they take the time to talk with you and ask to make sure your food is amazing. As a note, the "pied de cochon" dish is something suitable for 2 people minimum, so don't go there thinking you can get the two signature entrees for a dinner for 2. If you had a larger party you could probably pull it off. If you are visiting the area you must go here!

As good as it gets! --Probably one of my top favorite meal I've had so far in Quebec . We booked this place 3 months in advance because of how popular this place is and it was worth the wait. The place is not too small & not too big. There's no sign that says you're at APC, so I'd use google maps if you're not a local. We tried several dishes amongst the 7 of us and all of them met or went beyond our expectations. The foie gras pizza & foie gras poutine was a delicious appetizer that got our juices flowing for the entree. The fatty liver literally melts in your mouth. For the entree we shared a Tuna Steak Calamari & Fresh parmesan gnocchi. The gnocchi was prepared in a huge block of fresh parmesan cheese with pesto sauce. Definitely, snapchat/IG worthy. We wanted to try the pig's head but unfortunately they were sold out of it for the day. Other than that, service was phenomenal. Everyone was very attentive and helpful. I also must mention the bathroom, which was also phenomenal since they went all out with purchasing a bidet! A nice little treat for your tushy. I would definitely recommend this spot if you're visiting Montreal, but be sure to book this place in advance!

I came to APDC with an open mind and wallet. I wanted to experience an extremely decadent Quebecois meal. I didn't eat very much the day of. But, I did order fries as a starter. That's a terrible choice. The portions are massive, even from a usually undefeatable appetite as mine. It wasn't the size of the meal (though it was monstrous) as much as the density of the entree that made the mere thought of consuming it repulsive.Foie Cromesquis- I was unimpressed. The exterior was similar to the fried brading on a mozzarella stick. No special flavors to speak of. The inside of this bite-sized app I was hoping would really capture the essence of foie. It did not. The filling tasted mainly like french onion soup with a faint taste of foie. The texture was not particularly rich or decadent at all.Fries- Also unimpressed. I was expecting rich duck fatty deliciousness. Their fries are pretty standard style. Think boardwalk style: deep fried with the skins still on, just slightly thinner. They were OK, but the entire time I was thinking that I could and have made fries of better quality. Nothing special. Stuffed Au Pied de Cochon with Foie Gras-A ridiculously dense gut bomb of pork fattyness served over mashed potatoes with a porky demi-glaze with notes of red wine maybe. The dish was way too much food for me. But I'm fine with that. No harm there. This dish was offensive to my pallete. It literally had large pieces of pork fat and skin in it. The sauce was so dense I wanted to vomit. The flavor profile was so dominated by the taste of fat that I felt like I was spooning up an oil spill. I'd like to see some balance to this dish with acids.The execution of the pork itself was also questionable. The mouthfeel was OK, but it wasn't falling off the bone and flaky like some of the better pork tenderloin, shoulder, and ribs I've enjoyed elsewhere. The Foie Gras was fairly mediocre. Really did not have the same butteriness or depth of flavor that I experienced the night before from Chef Sakurai at Toroli. The service at APDC was excellent and all the staff were friendly and attentive. It was a fun environment with hip music and smiling people. I'll probably come back at some point to give a few of the other dishes of Au Pied a try. But I won't expect as much as I did this time.

Au Pied de Cochon is a restaurant founded by Chef Martin Picard back in '01, offering some new Canadian comfort fare.  The menu revolves mostly around the different parts of the pig, such as the pickled tongue, boudin, tarts, pork chops, pig's head, stuffed pied de cochon with foie gras, etc.  I made advanced reservations, and the hubs and I came here for a later dinner after we landed in Montreal.  We started off with the Fg Poutine, which was a plate of freshly-fried fries, topped with a lovely foie gras sauce, cheese curds, and generous chunks of foie gras - this was decadent, but not too heavy, and the gravy was super delicious.  For the main meals, we tried one of their specials, the Croque Monisuer with roasted pork loin and French toasts with maple syrup - we were not fans of this, as it just had too much going on; I wasn't a fan of the pork and the taste of it, as well as the oversweetness from the maple syrup-drenched toasts.  We then tried the Hot Chicken - this was pretty tasty, as the chicken itself was cooked perfectly and was super juicy; the salty crispy skin exterior had tons of flavor, and I loved the thick nice au jous-type of gravy that was drenching everything - I'm a huge peas fan, so the fact that there was an overabundance of this just made my heart happy!  For dessert, we tried the Milkshake with PDC Maple Toffee (one of the best milkshakes I've had, this wasn't too thick and easily drinkable - the taste was a mixture of funnel cake/creme brulee and something just magical - not overly sweet, but decadent enough), and the Maple Poudding Chomeur (love little bread pudding that had a yummy crunchy exterior, the hubs was a total fan of this!).  I'd love to go back and try out their Happy Pork Chop (which they were out, sadly), as well as their Duck in a Can.  Service was super friendly and attentive, as Gregoire and Louis were both fabulous.  We even received multiple complimentary bread (that had a lovely crust to it - rustic and yummy, it was great with the soft butter that was served).  The place is open late and it does get packed - reservations are highly recommended.+yummy complimentary crusty bread :D+Foie Gras Poutine :D+Hot Chicken :D+Milkshake with PDC Maple Toffee :D+Maple Poudding Chomeur :D+ask for Gregoire and Louis :D+friendly staff+reservations highly recommended!

The hype is real. Amazing experience. We ordered the PIED DE COCHON farcie au fois gras. The lady recommended to share it with 2 people, so we took an appetizer too. woowwo the Comesquis foie gras. CRAZY! You put it in your mouth and it EXPLODED of juiciness. So tasty. I would've have eaten 10 of those, no problem hahaThe Pied de Cochon is impressive. Crispsy on the outside, wall of fat and meat/ veggies and stuff inside. Foie gras a bit everywhere and potatoes on the bottom. Sauce matches well with the meal. I'd say the first 10 mins of eating is amazing. Then you feel like dying from heart attack ahha. Really fatty dishes, but if you take a drink it goes well. Once in a lifetime experience. Definitely coming back for the big head with lobster.Keep the good job! We like those kind of restaurants in Montreal

If there's one place to recommend in Montreal, it will have to be Au Pied de Cochon. Make sure to call weeks ahead for dinner reservations to secure a table. My friend and I winged it and walked-in hoping something was open and sure enough, they had two seats at the bar. We were stoked as we saw the view in front of us. We had the best seats in the house! It's an open kitchen with the entire crew sans Chef Martin Picard, working within an arm's reach. We got to see all the action, interacted with the chefs, and witnessed all the dishes before they got served to all the tables. How awesome is that?We were off to a slow start with our server being so busy with other tables but he got us started with our beers and gave us enough time to figure out what to get. It was a struggle as everything on the menu sounded so decadent. Being from California, the banning of foie gras has made me craving for it. This place has foie in almost all their dishes. Imagine my excitement! Here's what we ended up getting which my dear friend and I all shared:FOIE GRAS CROMESQUIS ($3.50) or croquettes if you will. It's filled with foie gras jus oozing out as you bite into the crisp, deep-fried breading. It was really just a bite to tease us for what's next to come. Then came the GUINEA HEN LIVER MOUSSE ($8). A jar filled to the brim with the mousse accompanied by some orange marmalade and sauerkraut on the side to complement each other. This proved too enticing for me to resist wiping out completely. Ask for extra toast if you run out or use the table bread which by the way, was also hard not to indulge in. Warm, crusty, and fresh from the oven.A special of the evening was their MOULES FRITES ($10). This was not on the menu but we saw lots of these coming out of the kitchen and we just had to order it. For an appetizer, the serving was hefty. The sauce, wow, buttery with bacon bits and a hint of white wine. It was addicting and to dip the bread in it was inevitable until all the white creamy liquid was no more. We had quite a pause until our main course came. We welcomed it and watched the live show in front of us, oohhh'ing and ahhhh'ing as we saw beautiful plates of pig heads, pied de cochons, foie poutines, meatloafs, and ducks in a can pass right in our faces. Finally, the star of the show, STUFFED PIED DE COCHON WITH FOIE GRAS ($45) was laid in front of us. It was ginormous! We were planning on getting an order each initially but bless Chef Audrey's heart for letting us know this was a meal a family can consume. The pig's feet was nicely breaded and laid atop a bed of super creamy mashed potatoes, covered with a stew of mushrooms and onions, then topped with perfectly seared foie gras. Rich, decadent, and seasoned without any apprehension, Chef Martin depicts his true colors on this one amazing plate. Needless to say, the other half had to be packed and eaten the next day. We left completely satiated by the "in your face" flavors on every plate and thankful for the crew that was fun and pleasant. Capping off our Montreal trip at Au Pied de Cochon could not have been any better. Merci beaucoup!

It's def a place everyone should visit when visiting Canada. All dishes are taken from the most normal typical food from Quebec and it's prepared and presented in a very special way. Every detail on the food is very well thought. Great ambience and i will def go back. Be ready for a heavy but delicious meal

We went on our first night in Montreal and holy shit this place lives up to the hype. We had a halibut tartar and the foie gras w potato and maple syrup and it was... wild. My bf had the duck in a can and loved it but couldn't finish. I don't love duck but I had the fish and chips and they were wonderful. We were stuffed by the end. Also the service was extraordinary, the servers made reccos, gave us details of everything as they served it, and told us how to eat things in the most effective way. Truly a night we will not forget.

A Pescetarian walks into Au Pied de Cochon.Loved it. Amazing service, despite how packed and booked this place was. They found 2 tables for us outside and our waiter was the best. He was cute, knew his beer, and made great suggestions and convo.My Blue Cheese, Apple & Endive Salad was worth every 10 of my $10. Its large, so much flavor, and pretty! The Foie Gras Cromesquis i could live without, not my cup of tea--i tried it well because...when in rome.. i mean when in montreal. My friend loved her poutine fries, deff worth every penny of hers. Also, they have a great stout collection here, over all we were pleased.

Some sweet lady from my hood arranged for the food truck to arrive on the last day of the local organic produce market. There is some kind of irony in that as I wouldn't associate the food of Au Pied de Cochon with organic and healthy, nor I would recommend it to vegeterians. Would I recommend it in general? Oh, yes! Must try!It has been few years since I visited the actual restaurant and my memories of it were kind of blurry. The foie gras poutine of the food truck brought back immediately the flavours of that dinner. The size of the poutine is decent for a food truck as well as the size of the foie gras in it. What makes the dish unique is the foie gras gravy, it is just delicious. We also shared le verrat à l'érable, battered pork sausage soaked in maple, which was really good and filling. The maple soda went well with the food. Conclusion I'm quite happy with my PDC truck experience and will do it again!

To be clear- you're coming here for fois-gras and a delicious but heavy meal. Food was off-the-chain and the service was on point!The owner hovers around and makes sure everyone is happy and if you're not he'll make you happy, either with his luscious beard or free offerings. We got both.Highly recommended for folks passing through Montreal.

This might be one of my favorite restaurants in the world. I'm never disappointed and always amazed. Their special this week: pork chop cut up on top of mopo tofu. Already I'm thinking non asian trying to pull off an asian dish cause I'm an dck. But jokes on me cause that mo mo po po taste as good if not better than the real deal. The whole dish just worked. Shame on me...Always. Always. I don't care if you like or don't like duck liver, always order the froie gras poutine.

This restaurant reputation is well known as such it is always packed and reservation days ahead is required. Every dish is very rich and heavy, with much focus on foie gras; tasty and saucy, maybe not always flavorful and lacking in presentation. Make sure you have decent appetite before going in, otherwise just piggy back your leftovers. Seating is very tight and loud, however waiter service is excellent. Not suitable for vegans.

At Au Pied de Cochon, you will most likely experience the heaviest meal of your life. From the foie gras dishes to the duck in a can, everything is over-the-top indulgent. We decided to get a tuna confit salad and a tuna steak (the special of the day) to balance out the meat, but even the tuna steak was really, really heavy. If I had to pick my route to a heart attack though, I'd go with the foie gras poutine. It was godly... definitely a must-order at this restaurant.Knocking off a star because of the horrendous wait time to get seated. We had an 8:30 reservation on a Saturday night but didn't end up getting seated until about 9:10. The hostess seemed like she didn't really know what she was doing, because all the reservations were backed up and there was a line going out the door. Lesson learned: don't come here at a peak time on a weekend.
The food is exquisite! A Montréal gem.The service is impaccable, drinks are good, very attentive staff.

We wanted to try everything on the menu but decided to go with the actual name of the restaurant so we had stuffed pig's foot with ham on top of butter mashed potatoes and sautéed mushrooms topped with a nice piece of foiegras Over the top? Yes! Delicious? Oh Yes! PS. The Bison Tamaki was to die for. Don't order the zucchini blossoms, they were just straight up greasy. I've had better.

Opted for the tasting menu here and it was one of the most decadent meals of my life.  Think foie gras everything topped with more foie gras.Nothing that hasn't already been said, but highlights included their infamous duck in a can, pork shank, and squid ink seafood pasta.  Recommend if visiting Montreal for the first time.

I never write reviews but even days later I am still so upset with my experience here.I'll start with the positive, with that the food and atmosphere is amazing. These two factors alone I would rate Au Pied de Cochon very highly. In regards to the food we ordered - we had the Foie Gras Nigiri, Duck Carpaccio and Stuffed PDC & Foie Gras. Each dish, more amazing then the previous - the highlight of my night was the Foie Gras Nigiri. You wouldn't think foie gras as a nigiri would work, but it does. The richness of the foie gras with the sushi rice and sauce made it a delicious bite, which I never wanted to end. The Stuffed PDC & Foie Gras was also really delicious - it's definitely not something two people can finish. I'd recommend ordering it if you had a bigger party.The problem of the night for us, was the service we received. When we were ordering, we were told that the 'Duck in a Can' was completely sold out for the night. Though it was what I had really wanted to try, I did not push any further. You can imagine my annoyance in seeing a 'Duck in a Can' come out of the kitchen and being served to the Francophone non POC couple that were seated and had ordered after us. Of course the couple could have put one on hold when making their reservations, but I had overheard their conversation as they were ordering - I can assure you they had not. To top it off, I was already peeved because I had waited 45 minutes between ordering and my first course arriving. Meanwhile the server had not dropped by to let us know why there was such a long wait or to check-in in general. Though I did observe him sneaking in sips of wine and beer behind the coat 'rack' quite a few times.All this added up to being a very unsatisfying experience at such a highly recommended restaurant. Such a shame.

f you want Quebecois fare this is the place to go. We went very late (10:30pm) and didn't have too much trouble getting a table for 2 without reservation (although it was still quite busy).We ordered the Stuffed PDC with a glass of red wine and finished off with a maple Crème Brûlee. The other reviewers were right about the portions! We were able to have another meal with the leftovers. The stuffed PDC was very rich and melt in your mouth tasty. I loved the caramelized onions that did help cut the richness. I was really happy that they offered bread at no cost (We went to another restaurant that charged $6 for bread and butter...what the heck??). The Crème Brûlee was divine. The red wine the server recommended was great as well! I'm not even a wine person and I liked it!We would definitely come back again and try their duck in a can! Thanks for a great meal!Food - 5/5Service - 4/5Atmosphere - 4.5/5 (patio seating, nice but a bit cramped)

We finally made it here.We saw the TV Show with them being featured. We came in the dead of winter,snow piled high. The place was packed. Got our seat, and ordered. We shared the duck in a can, which was amazingly good. Dinner equally good. We look forward to returning next time through. This is a unique establishment, I highly recommend going here for the experience.

The great thing about traveling alone you can always find a seat at the bar! the hostess was turning away groups but she seated me right at the bar overlooking the open kitchen.  Best seat ever because I was simply fascinated watching them all buzzz around.  Wasn't super hungry so I ordered the fried foie gras and French onion soup which ya gotta have when visiting Montreal, right?! The appetizer was just 2 tiny bites but I guess for $6 is ok... The French onion soup however was outstanding!  It had chunks of tasty yummy pock bits packed into it.  Now I want ALL of my onion soup like this.  *la sigh*

Most indulgent meals you'll ever have in your life. You'll leave here kinda hating yourself but it's so worth it!! If I ever came back, I'd def go with a huge party so I can try everything without feeling guilty. Every dish is so rich so you definitely need to share! I'm so glad I got to try this place! It's definitely worth the hype! I'd skip out on the foie gras poutine unless you had a huge group to share because poutine is so rich already, you have foie gras on top of it so it's a bit overload. Tartare temaki is my favorite! It was horse tartare with sushi rice wrapped in seaweed shaped cone. Anyways, if you're in montreal, do yourself a favor and go here!!

user_city: West Los Angeles, West Los Angeles, CA
user_review: This was one of our favorite restaurants in Montreal. Everything was amazing and everyone was sooo friendly. I would def make a reservation though. They are strict about walk ins or changing reservation times even when there may be a few open tables.

Summary: Delicious food but overall experience left something to be desired. When making a reservation ask not to be seated next to the cellar if you get cold easily!Food tip: PDC's Melting Pot is the best we tried on our table (vs. The fried chicken, oysters and pork chops that other members of our party ordered). The Melting Pot was literally a small pot with a bunch of different porks (pork flank, blood sausage and some others I don't recall) that seemed to be slow cooked and then laid on a bed of the most delicious mashed potatoes ever. This was a seriously good meal. The pork chops were a close second but I with someone on our table had tried the PDC's Cut because I suspect that would have been delicious.Atmosphere: The interior is very nice despite the single bathroom that means there will be a consistent line of anxious people waiting to use the bathroom if you sit by the cellar in the back and it is busy. The seating up front by the window looked like a nicer place to be in the summer. It was also cold by the cellar because they kept leaving the door open very long when going in there. Drinks: Lovely as well but not sure how the bartender did not know what either a French 75 or a Moscow Mule were despite having a full bar and no cocktail menu (i.e. you'd expect they know some classic drinks). I ended up having a simple Hendricks tonic with cucumber and it was perfect. I also like that they bring the tonic/soda water in a separate little beaker.One negative: The declined to give us the wifi password because the owner "does not like people being on their phones". Except this was only a problem for tourists because most people were locals and we're using their phones in the restaurant!

Decided to try this place out as many friends suggested I check it out.  Their duck in a can is really delicious.  It is literally a duck cooked in a tin can and then opened in front of you.  However the pork chop dish was just okay.  It was a bit dry and not very tasty.  The fries were tasty.  Their apple pie dessert was great.  Overall, it is a very good restaurant with great menu items, if the pork was a bit tastier, would definitely have given this place 5 stars.

Tasty, unique and rich. This place offers a great variety of traditional quebecois stuff that I never imagined I would eat. We had their meat pie which has rich layers of ground meat, cheese (whole brie, I think), thick bacon bits, arugula (makes it sound healthy) and (drum roll) pig brain. Good experience but I think for health reasons, I will avoid next time. Haha. The best was the blood pasta - soaked in chicken broth. It was divine! I now understand Anthony Bourdain's love for this place. It's tough to get reservations but I guess we were lucky that night.

This place gets packed real quick, definitely get a reservation. I had no idea what to order so I just took recommendations; they were damn good. Sit at the bar if you want dinner with a show. A lot of the food is prepped right there.

This is an iconic spot for excellent reasons. Packed even at 830 so make a reservation which we did. Good service of occasional spots of busy cause them to slow down. Do be aware that tables near the oven can seem warm.The food was great (heavy so resist over ordering)We had the horse tartare cones amazing presentation and flavour.A fois dish with buckwheat pancake maple syrup veal stock sauce which was beyond yummy.And a so huge we never finished it serving of taglitalle and meatballs. Along with a salad with enough pork to qualify as a protein and not a vegetable.  Great wine list too!

Let me begin this review by saying that this is a very special restaurant and that there's some marvelous cooking happening here. I'll also say that the fact that it has four stars and not closer to five is also telling how it borders on novelty (and given all of the attention it's gotten in the media, that's not a huge surprise). I imagine we weren't the only tourists there...Several years ago I drove up here from upstate NY and had the duck in a can, which was terrific, and no pretense of overeating, and left feeling warm and comforted. Two years ago I came with a group and we got the pigs head (for two!) This was one of the most decadent offerings I've seen anywhere (with a lobster stuffed into the head of a pig fried in duck fat...) We all took part, and our eastern European friend, who had zero fear or inhibitions about eating *all* of the animal gleefully consumed the brains, eyes, snout, etc... It was the summer and everything was great.Fast forward to last March when I visited with B and way over-ordered on the advice of the server. Everything seemed overdone--a level of fat (and I know that's what we're there for) that simply overpowered us. We got the eponymous pig's foot, which was mostly a gelatinous case filled with leg fat surrounded by goopy, somehow stringy cheese mashed-potatoes. All of the appetizers were, on the other hand, over-seasoned--too salty (the tripe), or too sweet (the salmon head). Dessert was nice--I got the maple syrup pie, which tastes like the real deal (amber best grade!) She got the burnt bread ice-cream, which was unremarkable aside from its name...The service was unfortunately C+. It was a busy night, but we waited fifteen minutes to order dessert and another ten just to get the check. They were, at least, very friendly and accommodated us quickly when we pointed out a mistake on the tab.And so I wish I could give APdC 3.5 stars. I'm not sure if I'll go back after this, but for those of you not tl;dr yet, here's the pro-tip for two:Order one entree to splitOrder two appetizers: one "exotic" the other a saladEnjoy the excellent bread but don't eat it all!Share a dessertYou'll be absolutely stuffed, but not regretting it all the next day as we were.

I've been itching to come here for years to try its porky and foie deliciousness.  It did not disappoint.  Our table of four chowed down on the following:  -Tarragon beef tongue with spicy mustard carrots and pickles. Tender and sumptuous. Definitely one of my favorites of the night. - Veal liver with veal tartar above over a bed of mashed potatoes and a veal gravy. One of the best but potent liver dishes I've had. - Poutine with fries cooked in duck fat, gravy, mozzarella cheese curds, and foie gras. The foie was just perfectly smooth and delicious. - boudin tart so a blood sausage tart covered in more foie gras. I enjoyed this a lot. - Lightly battered pork rectum (yes, really) in a homemade General Tso sauce, and beet and  roasted beets, and a light salad. It was surprisingly delicious though the first bite was fairly funky. The fresh orange juice and campari slushy was also delicious.  I will say that I felt like I was made out of foie gras and could feel it pulsing through my pores all night.  What a rich and divine meal!  It's fairly small inside and strangely laid out.  When we first entered, it felt like we'd walked in the back entrance and I felt certain we'd come in the wrong way.  It's laid out like a long railcar with the bar/kitchen along one side.  The bathroom's inside the kitchen, which is a bit bizarre.  It's so tight that whenever the waiters came by to bring us water or dishes, they almost had to dance on one leg to bring it over.  But it's warm and inviting and the service was friendly.  Unlike other commenters, I didn't feel like we ordered too much or were pressured to order more.  Our waiter told us we'd ordered just the right amount.

The Camion Au Pied De Cochon was parked at Dorchester Square when I saw them.  We ordered some fried pork rinds (skin I guess) dipped in a ranch flavour and some foie gras poutine.At first I really liked the pork rinds as it tasted like greasy but saltier sour cream and onion rings.  I always had a weakness for those when I was younger. However after a while, it got tired and too salty for my liking.  As for the foie gras poutine, I was not a fan of it at all.  Too heavy and rich for me.  I know that's the purpose of this restaurant, but I couldn't even have 4-5 bites. On the bright side though, is that it was reasonably priced as both dishes were under $8.50.Verdict: If you like greasy, salty food, you'll like it.  If you don't and prefer your food a bit less adventurous, then I wouldn't recommend.

Ouff getting a reservation at au PdeC was not an easy task ... who still operates over voicemail? Especially over a voicemail box that is always full?!But au PdeC still seems to get away with it thanks to all the hype Anthony Bourdain created during his 24 hour Montreal layover (if you've never watched it: dailymotion.com/.../xo2k…...).Needless to say, we had to try it out ourselves or we couldn't be called true Montrealers. But the overwhelming foie gras stuffed courses were too much for two people to handle, so we brought 2 friends for back up! All in all, if you come knowing that this will not be a fine dining experience and that you WILL be overindulging in rich and heavy courses, then your experience will be a satisfying one. And let's be honest, everything just tastes better with fat!From the foie gras stuffed croquettes that just ooze in your mouth as you bite into them, to the decadent poutine topped with foie gras gravy and a whole piece of foie gras and then the squash risotto cooked in a whole wheel of parmesan...! Your reward center will be firing away happy signals for hours to come smile emoticonAll this goodness, paired with a nice bottle of french wine (they have an extensive french heavy wine list and some good beer on tap) made this a highly enjoyable 'tourist in your own city experience'. Good food, good wine and great company along with a surprisingly affordable tab... what's not to like?

Wow! This restaurant deserves the 5 stars I'm giving it. Service: Very great. Staff was very attentive, friendly, and welcoming. There were 3 different servers tending to us (I think because it was a very busy night, and servers were covering multiple tables), but it didn't feel like they were overwhelming us with questions if we needed anything, or in any way intrusive. Food: Foie Gras Burger - thick burger. Doesn't come with any sides...just the burger. Coming in at a hefty price of $39 bucks, I wouldn't know if it was worth it. The foie gras slice is decent amount, but I probably wouldn't order it again. But don't worry, it's a pretty big burger so you'll leave full. Pigs feet stuffed with foie gras - this was really really really worth it! Definitely something to share with one or two friends. The pig feet actually came with mashed potatoes on sides and there was a little mushroom/rosemary/carrot/gravy moat around the giant pig feet 'castle'. A couple slices of foie gras were on top of the pigs foot. Honestly, there wasn't as much foie gras in this entree as I though...but the sheer amount of pigs foot definitely made up for it! Final thoughts: Takes about 30 min to bring out the pigs foot. There was a little hiccup in the cooking process which tacked on bout 20 min more BUT the restaurant was nice enough and considerate enough to bring out a complimentary dish of ravioli and artichoke hearts so I could eat with my other friends together since their burgers came out earlier. Very considerate and definitely enjoyed it. I would come back in a heartbeat. Definitely a cute place to bring a date. Just make sure it's not the first date, cuz you'll be setting the bar real high. Wallet was noticeably lighter after this meal!

Probably not much has been left unsaid about Au Pied de Cochon. Its one of the heaviest, most indulgent meals I've ever had. It is beyond rich and fatty. But the food does live up to the hype. Started off with coppa and bread, which may be one of the best charcuterie plates I've had. Also got the duck in a can, which was pretty good. Very rich, but very flavorful. Only knock on it is that the fat on the duck is not rendered off enough, which made it super fatty. I enjoy fatty/rich/decadent foods but this was too fatty even for me. I also tried the foie burger, which was as delicious and artery clogging as I expected. The desserts are just okay. Or maybe my heart had already stopped and I couldn't enjoy it as much. The restaurant is loud inside and they play a lot of loud rock music, which wasn't the vibe I was expecting. My main knock in this restaurant, which is why I didn't give it a 5 (because the food is definitely a 5) is the service. The service is spotty. I had specifically reserved 4 seats at the bar (so I could see how the kitchen works), but they had given that up to someone else. So I we got seated at a table. When I arrived, they said the people at the bar were getting their check and wrapping up, but as I walked by, the people at the bar were just getting started. No one else got seated between the time I arrived and when I got seated, so something does not smell right. The waitress we had was not nice and did not want to explain anything on the menu for us. She seemed very dismissive and gave off a "you should know this, if you're eating here" vibe. Not helpful at all.  We also asked for our bill on 3 different occasions and still didn't get it. It took about 20 minutes for us to get the bill. Very disappointing service.

It sucks having to write this because the food was delicious - however, service is also important. The evening started out great to be honest, we were there for my 30th bday celebrations and had heard nothing but the best going in.  It all seemed amazing because we ended up going an hour early and landed seats at the bar overlooking the kitchen (basically all up in the kitchen).  To be clear, our server was excellent.  Had great recommendations, was very pleasant, and strived to make the evening great for us. We had amazing dishes, and I will give the restaurant that. However, as I mentioned, we were basically in the kitchen.  We had to sit through preparations of our meals and appetizers (and also those of every other patron) and it was a really fun time, until this one person. There was one staff member in that kitchen, a female with very short hair and tattoos on her arms.  Frankly, she is the reason for this 1-star review and should probably not have a job at such a great restaurant.When the time came to order dessert, we ordered a crème brûlée and then the waiter's note about it being a birthday dessert clearly went through.  The staff member immediately started complaining, including a very, very loud "wow, can't people just pay for their desserts? This is so stupid" -- so a few things here: we were paying for our dessert; was it really so painful for you to pull a sparkler out of a cabinet, put it on a pre-made dessert and shut up; do you not realize that people can hear you, and who the hell cares? Now the answer to the third question - yes.  Yes, she did realize that people could hear her because she AGAIN loudly said "OH GREAT. They couldn't at least tell me they're sitting right in front of me? Now I look like a fucking asshole." No argument here - yes, yes you did look like an asshole. She then continued by pointing in our direction to another sous chef and saying "it's them right there, and they could totally hear me that whole time.  And they're looking at me." One - paranoia. I have an extremely short fuse and normally would blow up.  However, I chose to turn a blind eye to her nonsense that night and tried to ignore it and have a good time. Now any other person with any semblance of a clue, or any understanding of natural social cues would have realized how uncomfortable their obnoxiously loud voice and comments were making her colleagues.  No, not this one.  She just kept going.  Loudly complained about having to put sugar and burn it with a blowtorch (yes, she burned the dessert) on the dessert (OH YOU POOR THING - you work too hard). Now this seems like I'm harping on this one person, and let me be clear - I am.  She deserves it.  I have worked in the service industry and crap like that would have never flown for me in the restaurants we worked in. At the end, I bluntly told the server that she was excellent and made our night great.  But that sous chef in the kitchen ruined it. She shot a nasty glance over at the woman and indicated to us that she wasn't surprised, and this wasn't isolated behavior. She did her best to make things up for us, but we wanted to leave. We paid the bill and bounced.  To that sous chef, thanks for ruining a birthday dinner. I hope it was worth you looking like a "fucking asshole" that night.
One of my favorite places to gather in the city with friends. Great atmosphere great menu with Montreal is all about well done.

Warning!! MOUTH ORGASM!!! I'm posting this while im still at the restaurant. That's how damn good this meal was.. the duck in the can was insane. By far the best meal my girlfriend and I had our whole trip. Foi gras on the bread that comes with the duck is mouth watering delicious.. you can imagine how good it is since im posting while still here.. Don't shy away from this place if you're in montreal.

It's loud, the food is in your face. I think most of my family was offended in some way, shape, or form before we finished stuffing our faces. It was fantastic. Every dish was a flavor bomb. This place is a must if you're visiting Montreal.

O-M-G. The food here was right up my alley!!! I LOVE rich, intensely flavoured and umami-tasting food, and everything here fit the bill!I tried the foie gras boudin tart, the foie gras cromequis, and the PDC Farci au Fg, which was HUGE and lasted more than another meal at home! Servers were so friendly and helpful with wine suggestions. I wanted to eat more, but simply could not as I was stuffed, and brought a lot of food home. If they had half portions of the main dishes that would be perfect so you can try more dishes. Can't wait to be back! A no-fail choice to celebrate any occasion for sure!!!

I really wanted to love this place, and there were some delicious bites. But this wasn't a meal I could enjoy without suspending my taste for balance in a meal. Service was super slow, though at least they did acknowledge this numerous times. The server was very friendly and helpful. We started with the tomato tart and pork/shrimp/foie gras dumplings... These were the highlight of the meal. The foie gras melts on the dumplings, very decadent. I realized, however, that there's was nothing to cut the richness. Before my palette could recover, our mains came out (the "melting pot" and the pork chop with mashed potatoes)... They were delicious for a few bites, but I got overwhelmed by the rich, fatty, smoky, salty flavors. Maybe I just didn't know how committed PDC is to bring all about those things, but it made for what I thought was an incomplete and difficult-to-enjoy meal. Even some fancy housemade pickles or radishes or *something* would have made a big difference. I am probably in the minority here, since the place was nonetheless packed. Don't get me wrong - excellent food - but I wouldn't return. There are so many good menus in this city that I don't think I need the spectacle of PDX.

This is a generous two star review. We really wanted to like this restaurantFirst the positive:My husband is a huge fan of pork. Our starter gets five stars... It was the one and only thing we liked. It was an appetizer of thinly sliced housemade prosciutto served side-by-side with amazingly delicious fried pancakes floating in maple syrup. A bite of both together was over the moon. If we'd stopped there this would be a whole different review.Also of note: our server was very nice and patient when we asked a lot of questions.Now the gross yucky inedibles:I really hated the poutine. What is everybody raving about with this dish? French fries that were actually OK on their own smothered in run-of-the-mill gravy and  cheese curds. It's not that I have anything completely against fat, but if it doesn't taste good why bother?Next came our entrées:Mine was a hamburger with foie gras. I'm used to the United States kind where it's a pate and it's all blended together without any look of the organ that it once was. I didn't realize this was going to be the whole organ itself, so maybe it's my bad that I didn't know what I was in for. The bun of the hamburger was deliciously buttery but with all the other food we had eaten it just became overkill with fat upon fat upon fat. I ordered my burger medium and it came out medium rare: red and squishy and lacked the nice chew I am used to in a burger. My husband's entree was a blood pudding tart with foie gras. He generally loves this dish and when I asked him what he ranked it on a 1 to 10 he gave it 2. Now for our dessert:We shared a maple pudding for an unemployed person. There was nothing about it that made me want to have a second bite. It was overly sweet, and the texture wasn't good enough to bother eating. In my book it was just gross. If you look at my other reviews you will likely notice that most of them are four and five stars, so this is a real departure for me.A man who may have been the manager came to our table at the end of our meal and asked if everything was OK. I told him my experience of it and he said something to the effect that maybe I should've had a different dessert. He didn't offer anything, and our tab with the tip was $200.In defense of this restaurant, the people at the next table shared prime rib of beef for two. It looked absolutely fabulous and was served with mashed potatoes. I was also curious about the lobster. So maybe if you're going to this restaurant and you're thinking about getting some lobster or prime rib you'll have a whole different experience. Good luck if you go

Loved the foie, loved the duck!They absolutely know how to cook their local products and everything included the bread were DELICIOUS!I would give 5 stars but I think the service was not as expected. We noticed that all the rest of tables had bags with the leftovers packed, then we thought that meal was so delicious that people ordered extra dishes to go. But the actual situation was that there are meat dishes which were HUGE even for a family of 4. The waitress do not warn the client about the portions. There was a table beside us with a vety surprised girl after having been served.So that, we ordered an appetizer, a dish of foie and a dish of duck with mushrooms to share. We noticed that waitress didn't inform us about the portions and she was above all, pushing us to order more...

Wow. Carnivores delight!!! We tried so many wonderful dishes.  The Shepard Pie was good, as was the Lamb and the Ravioli was divine.  My fav was the Pate and the Foie Gras. Divine.  The desserts were equally as yummy.

Holy crap, this place is truly off the chain. First of all, I love the vibe of this place. It's off a pedestrian looking street (though I'm pretty sure cars can drive on this street) and inside, it's incredibly warm and happy. Second of all, the food here is incredible. I stopped by the bathroom before I ordered from the menu and literally my mouth was agape at all of the dishes on people's tables. If you think the same was as my sister and I did, you will want to get the pied du cochon dish - I mean, it seems to be the namesake of the restaurant! But, beware, it is probably the most food I have ever gotten ever. If there's just two of you, I would suggest only getting this dish. there's a ridiculously large and meat filled pig's leg with mashed potatoes underneath laced with cheese and tons of gravy. And, the bread is really delicious so you can get tons of that if you want. The food is so rich that I was almost sick afterwards, so if you don't want that happening for you, take my advice and order on the smaller side.

Heard lots of great reviews for Au Pied de Cochon. This restaurant was featured on one of the shows by Anthony Bourdain! Service was excellent.DRINKS:Pied de Cochon beer x 2TERRAINE OF FOIE GRAS (4/5)Came with jam and bread. So delicious - it's pure foie gras. The taste is very strong and flavourful. A must for foie gras lovers :) I actually enjoyed this dish better without adding the jam on my slice of bread.FOIE GRAS POUTINE (5/5)A-M-A-Z-I-N-G! The closer you are to Montreal, the better the poutine gets and this one is a 5-star poutine for sure! Large slices of foie gras and big chunks of cheese.. mm fatty good!DUCK IN A CAN (5/5)So creative! It's a mini show when the waiter comes over and open the can in front of us (I recorded it all haha). The duck meat was tender and juicy - delicious. I would order this again the next time I visit Au Pied de Cochon.

Foie gras, foie gras, foie gras. What can I say, almost every dish has foie gras in it!! This is heaven for a meat lover (which i am)...vegetarians beware -- do not come here as it's not for you.We had a group of 6, the table was a bit slow in front of us so we had to wait 30 min beyond our reservation time, but they were nice and gave us a free round of beer. Kudos.Now to the food, we had the maple ham,  duck in a can, foie gras poutine, stuffed pied du cochon with fg, dumplings, foie gras bolognese pasta, and another dish I can't remember the name of, but it definitely had foie gras in it.....I would say a must is the maple ham (which is a special during Christmas time, very very succulent), the stuffed pied du cochon with fg, and the foie gras poutine.The foie gras bolognese was a special, would've been much tastier if it was hot; pasta was a bit cold. What was cool about this was that they cooked it in front of you on a thick slab of cheese. They first put the pasta into the cheese slab, put hot water,  then put the bolognese sauce on, and then the foie gras. As they plated it, the scraped a lot of cheese off...so you get a very cheesy dish, literally.Overall, everything was very tasty. For the price, you definitely get a lot of foie gras as well....so well worth it!

My wife first heard of this place from watching an episode of Anthony Bourdains show No Reservations.  Ever since then, this place was on her bucket list of restaurants to try.  So during our 3 day stay in Montreal, we made reservations for dinner regardless if it was going to be snowing or not.  We started off with the foie gras croquettes which is just a small bite that explodes in your mouth with all the rich and fatty flavors of the foie.  Then for the second appetizer we had the duck carpacchio, which was duck breast that was pounded supper thin and dressed with some olive oil and mushroom.  Finally for the main course we had the famous duck in a can and then we finished off the evening with a maple bread pudding.  I know it doesn't sound like we ate a lot for two people but keep in mind that the food here is very rich so after awhile you can feel your arteries starting clog.  Overall it was a great experience, only wish they had the sugar shack maple syrup in stock that evening so we could take a few bottles home with us to the states.

After much hype, I made it here with a few colleagues on a Wednesday evening. The place was absolutely hopping and hard to get into, but we made a reservation a few weeks in advance.Once inside we sat at the bar, which is by far the best seat in the house. It comes with a direct view of the kitchen and all the goodness the chefs are whipping up. We started out with the ham special for appetizer, which was delicious. It came with a baguette and butter which made it perfect. We then had some poutine, which was also quite good. It was definitely better quality than most poutine dishes. For the main course, I went aggressive and got a mixed bowl consisting of blood sausage, pork sausage, mushrooms and onions sitting on top of mashed potatoes. The dish was very good, but not the amazing experience I was hoping for. Spices could have been a little better, but make no mistake it was a very good dish.With its popular reputation, upbeat atmosphere and good food, this is definitely a place worth visiting when in town. They also have a really good bar with interesting drinks. Great overall experience.

Omg!! Where do I start? First, i was so happy I finally made it to au pied de cochon. I've been wanting to try this restaurant since I saw it on No Reservations. Second, it did not disappoint. The food was insane. We wanted to try everything but we only had enough room for the stuffed pig and even that was too much for us. It was the richest, most indulgent and tasty little pig foot I've ever tasted. The service was excellent and the atmosphere of the restaurant made the experience that much better. I'll be going back the next time I'm in Montreal.

We highly recommend eating here if you are able to get a table. If possible make a reservation well in advance. The space is small & lively and the service was excellent. Our meal was so deliciously rich and satisfying. The bison tartare temaki was my favourite thing of the meal and actually of our entire weekend in Montreal.

My co-diners kept exclaiming ... "best meal ever" ... at the same time, I kept marveling at the servers and staff -- who were, without exception, lovely! I can't out-do the other reviewers' descriptions of the dishes, so just let me say, don't miss the shank and risotto as well as the pork chop and treat yourself to the duck carpaccio appetizer!

Most of what's been said about this place being proudly gluttonous is spot on. If you can embrace it for what it is, you're sure to enjoy it. This is a celebration of meat, and organ meat, and fat, and foie gras, and more meat-and the amazing things they create with them. This isn't delicate, subtle French dining. This is an unabashed, indulgent carnivore celebration. There wasn't a bad thing we tried. A tuna tartare appetizer was fantastic, as was the Duck Carpaccio. Poutine Foie Gras was a thing to behold. Probably the best poutine I've had, but it was too much for 2 people to split, IMO. You have to really love Foie Gras, but if you do, it's incredibly generous in that dish for the price, and it's melt-in-your-mouth tender (the way it should be).Service was very good as well.

The food is heavy. That is the most standout description i can think of. One does not need foie gras on everything. If you make it into a sashimi with rice ok that is innovative and blends the fatty taste of foie gras with the light sweet taste of rice seasoned with soy sauce and spiced with a touch of wasabi. If it is put on something like a pig leg then it adds fat to the already fat and heavy pigs leg. The drinks are really good. IIRC there is a maple beer. I haven't tried everything yet and with restaurants like this the menu items are really hit or miss.

One word: WOWThis place was packed even when we arrived for our reservation for 10pm. We were quickly seated and based on reviews here, I knew I wanted to order duck in a can for sure, not just for the concept but for the food as well. Our server who is very knowledgeable about the food here recommended that we share two dishes because anything more than that is more than enough. And he was right!We ended up ordering duck in a can - $44 and Plogue à Champlain - $29, and two glasses of chardonnay - $10.Both of these two dishes have small amounts of fois gras, if you are a first timer try not to order dishes with a lot of fois gras in them. Eating a bit of it is okay, but I find that if you're eating a lot of it, you'll end up getting sick of it after.The duck in a can is a cool concept, the chef makes the duck, then seals it in a can where the server will come to your table, open the can and pour out the food on a plate for you. The reason why it's put in a can is because it's to seal all the flavours. The duck is very flavourful, not dry at all. Best dish I've had. And the Plogue à Champlain is something I've never had before, the taste is very unique and different. It is "a small mound of buckwheat pancake, layered with melted cheese, roasted fingerling potatoes, bacon, all topped with a slab of seared foie gras and drizzled with maple syrup--heaven". Service was fine, I found that they took care of big groups around us much more which I can understand. Anyways, it was a pricey dinner but well worth it!
Absolutely amazing meal!  The foie poutine and duck in a can cannot be missed! The staff was fantastic

One of the best in the city, if you can get a table outside on a nice night it is ideal; however, the casual atmosphere inside is welcoming too.The quality of the food is outstanding, we didn't even try the foie gras OR the Poutine, so if you don't care for either of these items, there's still plenty of options.I never leave five stars- but three days later, we're all still talking about it.FYI, the pork shank with risotto is outrageous, and two people can definitely share it. The wine list is extensive and the price point is better than most in the city.If you only hit one place, make it this one, you must have a reservation, so plan ahead

Amazing food and overall experience was pretty good!  So let's start with - for a weekend party - you'll need to make reservations at least a month or two in advance to get a decent hour.  We ended up with a 9:30 reservation which worked out for us pretty well.We arrived and well the service was a little slow getting our table ready since we did have a reservation but was seated within 20 minutes, so with that said - i was thinking in my head...dinner will be at minimum 2 hours long.  And i started the clock.We were in the doorway and the waitress was explaining some of the dishes to me as i was asking about the different foie gras dishes they have.  The one that stood out in all of our minds was the Garlic Foie Gras, Foie Gras Poutine and "Duck in a Can".  So we sat and chattered away the waiter came by gave us menus and asked if he could be any assistance, but honestly - we didn't have a clue what to order, and he didn't have clue how to direct our menu for the night.  But, he did explain all the specials they had including this amazing looking tuna they had.  We discussed and decided to order the 3 aforementioned Foie Gras dishes and everyone else ordered their own dish, including a Parmesian Risotto, Hot Chicken (which was a snap change in decision when the waiter said it was his favorite), and the Bison Rib.  Sadly they ran out of pork chops and were unable to have those, sooo we ended up not getting those.The Garlic FG - amazing - they have a dish, with 3 slices of GF on there, some croutons and maybe something else, and this roasted head of garlic.  He picks up the garlic by the long stem, and with a pair of tongs, squeese out the garlic over the FG leaving the juices and the mashed garlic to fall on top of the FG and then he poured a garlic cream sauce over the whole dish.  That was gorgeous and delicious!  The Duck in a Can...everyone talked about it - bread and cheese curds on the plate...the can is opened up table side and poured over the bread and cheese curds and the heat melts the cheese, the juices are soaked up by the bread and the duck meat, gf and everything on that plate was delicious!Poutine with FG - good...not amazing, but the FG on the dish was delicious!The Parmesan risotto special had a ton of peas, roasted pork belly, and cream and was cooked perfectly and delicious.The Hot Chicken - was an amazing mountain of food - seemingly 4 pieces of fried chicken, with bread and peas all covered in a thick buttery and savory gravy that was way too much and very very tasty!The Bison Rib - was a roasted bison rib with a sweet and slighly spicy bbq rib.  The meat was very very tender and did require a little work to get at, but it was well worth it.We ordered up Dessert - a decent sized Strawberry Rhubarb pie with ice cream.  The warm pie and ice cream already is a delicious combo.  The sweet and tart pie was perfectly complimented by the cold but soft ice cream.   If i'm going to go back to Montreal - I'd make  reservation to get a better time.  We ended dinner around midnight completely stuffed!  For the 5 of us it was about $60 cnd per person.

I went to this restaurant after trying their sugar shack I brought my aunt for her bday and this restaurant didn't disappoint There was an issue with our reservations even tho I had confirmed and It seemed like I wasn't the  only one with that problem. Tip: Reserve early but verify more than once if they got it right  *Do not go there if your doctor put you on a diet **Do not wear a crop top like I did* *Do wear maternity pants* Every dish we tried was a knock out of the park We had the blue cheese salad as an appetizer Then we had the foie gras poutine and that's exactly when earth stopped turning for me. If my mum didn't teach me better I would have just licked the sauce right off my plate and ruin my name for at least 3 generations. After that, we shared the cote de porc and pdc mashed potatoes. We closed the show with their "pet de soeur" sugar pie. We had our wine by the glass because we have different wine style. I find it very fair for the price. After this meal, we couldn't walk and we couldn't breathBut it was one of my sweetest summer memory

This place is the epitome of French Canadian cuisine. If you want an authentic Canadian culinary experience then this is not to be missed. The food is not for the faint of hearts and definitely leave your vegetarian friends at home. I wouldn't say this is a good everyday-go-to kinda restaurant so come here when you have visitors from out of town or for a special occasion. On to our meal. After cleansing our palettes with foie gras croquettes, we were ready for our main event. We bravely ordered the whole pig's head for two and I can say that it has been one of my most memorable meals. The head of pig was roasted to glistening perfection. Paired with apple and root veggies, the whole plate was full of flavour and tender juicy porky deliciousness. Since they have an open kitchen, people took pictures of our food as it made its way towards our table. It was quite the show! Have to admit I couldn't eat pork for a couple of weeks after but it was definitely worth every bite. Eating at Au Pied is a special event you don't want to miss.

We had the foie gras poutine, stuffed pied de cochon with foie gras and a tuna dish. All were very rich in flavor and will lead to a heart attack BUT worth every bite. Poutine- get it! after all it is a Canadian dishStuffed Pied de Cochon with Foie Gras- this is large enough for 3-4 people to share, the best part about this dish was the MASHED POTATO, it is sooooooooo good! it has a different texture from the typical mushy mashed potato. Tuna dish- our waiter picked this for us so I don't know what it's called but it's a pretty good dish with gravy and mashed potato on the bottom but it was a little salty though. Overall, amazing FATTY French Canadian food.

This one had been on my list for a while, it's almost crazy that I hadn't yet made it! We came in on a cold night, so heavy food was in order. We went for the duck in a can and the stuffed pig foot with foie gras. Both were good, but it is a bit messy. It's rich, heavy and I can see why people love it. For me, it is fine, but a bit uninspired for the price.

After having been to the PDC Cabane à Sucre twice in the last 5 years, I've been meaning to eat at the actual PDC restaurant in Montreal for a while now (last 5 years, to be precise). But it took this long... and unfortunately, my experience fell way short of expectations. My partner had been in with a different set of people previously, and he loved it (he had the pork chop). He excitedly told me afterward that he had found this amazing restaurant he just had to take me to, only to realize that it was the exact same restaurant he'd been rejecting  every time I brought it up in the last 3 years. To remedy his faux pas, we made a date to go there for a special occasion last week.Our reservation was for 5:30PM, and despite being early, we were seated promptly. Service was ok, although we may have irritated our server from asking too many questions (we were concerned about portions, because we weren't super hungry when we arrived...). The menu had a lot of items in it, but surprisingly not a lot of cochon (unless you wanted the stuffed PDC, which we didn't). My partner was pretty disappointed that the pork chop (or some variation) was not on the menu.In the end, we got the foie gras poutine to start and one of the specials for our main: halibut for two. Yes, I know - why halibut in a restaurant famed for pig & foie? Well to be honest, they made a mean fish when we went to their multi-course sugar shack last year... so we were really hoping for a repeat of that perfectly cooked dish!I also had the maple gin and tonic to drink, which is just as tasty as I remember (from the sugar shack). The poutine was pretty good - the foie gras adds a richness to an otherwise ordinary dish.The disappointment lay solely on the halibut. The lentil stew with leek and mushroom was delicious enough; but the halibut was way too salty! I have a pretty high tolerance for salt, so it was an unpleasant surprise to admit that the fish was salty to the point of inedible. I didn't want to make a big deal about it, so we paid before I made the comment to the server. Which of course was just met with a sorry, you should have said something sooner (and maybe we could have replaced your food). Not sure if that was good enough, but whatever. For a restaurant that charges a premium for their dishes, I expected a lot more. In the end, our business was already lost.. I just hoped that my comment may have prevented an unpleasant experience for other guests that made the wrong order.We likely won't be going back anytime soon... if at all.

This place is amazing! The pictures I took speak for themselves.  Where else can you get a whole pig head with cow tongue and heirloom carrots.  The (french) onion soup, tuna collar with grilled onions and corn and great wine selection make this restaurant a must stop when you're in Montreal.  The seating is cramped inside the restaurant and they have a small restroom for the size of this restaurant but not that big of a deal given all else.

I tried Pig feet and foie gras poutine with a friend. They are so fatty...but...they are soooooo delicious!!! The foie gras poutine is the best that I have ever tasted in Montreal!! And in the plat with pig feet, there was also mushroom and mush potatoes. The taste was soooo gooood!!!

So I tried booking a reservation at the restaurant in the beginning of January. I called several times and every time they heard me speak English they hung up. So I tried calling again and spoke French this time and they finally took my reservation for the 12th of February at 8pm. We arrived a couple of minutes late because of the terrible snowstorm. We already checked out the menu online so we were ready to order as soon as we got there. We wanted to order the hamburger with foie gras and pdc farci (stuffed pig's feet) and the pig's head. It took a while to get our server's attention and the place was not even packed. As soon as we mentioned our orders, the server told us that they do not have any of them available for tonight. My partner and I were very disappointed but I convinced him to stay because might as well... the snowstorm was pretty bad and we did not feel like driving anywhere else. We ended up ordering the foie gras cromesquis for appetizer and we got the plogue à champlain and the pig's feet with mashed potatoes for the main course. And for dessert, I ordered the earl grey ice cream and the pouding chômeur. FOIE GRAS CROMESQUIS- Delish! The interior was  a very rich liquid foie gras and the outside was quite crunchy.PLOGUE À CHAMPLAIN- a slice of potato underneath topped with maple flavoured bacon and foie gras. The bacon was probably the best bacon I have ever had, it was juicy, tender and tasty. The foie gras was delicious, it was perfectly seasoned and cooked.PIG's FEET WITH MASHED POTATOES- the pig's feet was good but not amazing. The meat was really tender and juicy and it was sitting in some kind of brown gravy(kinda reminds me of poutine gravy). The mashed potatoes were the best part of the meal !!! Best mashed potatoes ever ! They mixed it with mozzarella cheese and it tasted just like poutine with the gravy but mashed version , omg ! I would definitely go back just for the mashed potatoes.EARL GREY ICE CREAM- good but nothing special. They put maple syrup on top which kind of made the top a little sour.POUDING CHÔMEUR- Delish! Extremely sweet and warm. I always love a good pouding chômeur. Overall, I was disappointed that they did not have everything on the menu , the service was not the best but the food was pretty good. I don't think I will be coming back anytime soon though. I recently tried the Cabane à sucre and I personally think it's a much better deal.

This is the best food I've ever had. Period. Highlights include the fresh butter served with the bread, the bread itself, the duck in a can, and the temaki tartare...so pretty much everything I ordered. Service was great as well. I will make a point to come back here the next time I drop by Montreal!

I couldn't leave Montreal without coming here, I wouldn't forgive myself. I was a broke student so I decided to come here with friend and order one main dish, one appetizer. Then the price wouldn't be so bad.Ok let's see.... I really wanted the foie gras poutine but the waiter came over to tell me Pain De Veau was the daily special! Damn it I can't afford two mains!! Well whatever I guess I'll just have to return.Pain de veau is a French dish and it's basically veal bread. Something I never heard of! At Au Pied de Cochon they made this with red wine, a lot of veal, some roquette leaves on top, AND FOIE GRAS. Of course FG. I'm not missing out.It's VERY flavourful, in fact really strong. It's extremely good! For the appetizer we ordered duck carpaccio $14, which is raw duck, mushrooms, cheese, egg yolk, dots of colours (sauces). And you mix all this together. It tasted more sour than duck which, to be honest, is usually what westerners do: cover up raw stuff with sour stuff. So you're tasting just the sauce. I would pass if this doesn't interest you. I personally would order something else next time.I think in total it was just $34 + tax and tips.SERVICE!Extremely good!!! I fell in love with the other waiter, not ours. Ours was amazing too. Please don't be jealous, hear me out. The other guy was just freaking nice and alive!!!! I think he works in the back (I sat near the door) and he brings food to the table. He doesn't take customer orders, he brings food from kitchen to table. But because the restaurant is ALWAYS so busy, he naturally helps out everything! Water. Changing tables. Checking up. Are we ok?? Napkins? Coming ASAP!!The only awful staff is the coat lady who's at the front of the door and she takes in new customers. I guess it's good I mean, her face just tells people without reservations to get out.Which reminds me. If you have no reservations, you'll be greeted by her and get kicked out. YOU NEED reservations.

Amazing food, so decadent and delicious. Started with the foie gras pancake cheese plate and then the old hen dish for two. It was excellent and well worth it. The staff and service were also top notch would definitely come here again.

Unless you are an absolute fanatic of foie gras, or a gluttonous meat and potato eater, skip this place. We came out of the restaurant feeling exhausted, and disappointed, from voluminous salty dishes and an expensive check (even though we ordered two of the modestly-priced bottles of wines on the list). Service could best be described as glacial as it took almost an hour for our main dishes to arrive. The restaurant is not big, so be ready for elbow-to-elbow seating. It's one of the famed Montreal restaurants and a very popular destination for foodies and tourists. We're New Yorkers, and former residents of Tokyo, who love trying food from street carts to Michelin-starred restaurants. That said, Au Pied de Cochon was nothing to write home about.

One of the best food I had so far. It exceeded  my expectations on every level. The place is nice just a little tight, the staff are very accomodating and the food is beyond fantastic. Always make a reservation just right after opening as late reservations gets seated delayed.

I book trips to Montreal solely on my ability to get a reservation at this place. Being from Vancouver, living in LA, Chicago, near NYC you get exposed to a lot of great food. Au Pied de Cochon is easily my favorite restaurant in North America, if not the world. The dishes are just so inventive, and crazy, like mad-scientist-chef crazy. Who puts a lobster inside the mouth of a roasted pig head? Chef Picard! That's who! This place is worth the hype. Everything I've gotten here is simply immensely flavorful and decadent. I was here by myself (the wifey is scared of this place) last weekend and the amount of food for the price is insane. A salmon head appetizer was only $5 CAD, and their poutine (even without the foie) might even be better than the venerable La Banquise.Just come here. Fly, drive, get a hotel, AirBnb it, Uber it, Metro it. Just do it. Please.

I really enjoyed this restaurant and the only reason why I am giving it a 4 is because one of the dish was too salty. However, despite the saltiness, it was worthwhile! The bread kept coming, our waitress was knowledgeable and other wait staff were accommodating (they kept the bread flowing when they realized we were low), my duck in a can was delicious and the foie gras?
