It was excellent. My sister's dish, the Pork Loin, was too peppery and salty but the overall dish - the pork itself- was delicious. Not sure how the tofu works with the pork loin dish (it felt like the dish was not well rounded or thought out since the tofu seemed so random) but we are very glad that we came here. It was a heavy meal but very much worth the visit!

This food is rich. This food is great.Don't come here very late.It's popular and crowded, you'll need a resy for sure,Try the duck in a can, and all the food cooked in le beurre!Okay, that's all I got. This restaurant is a classic stop in Montreal. You definitely need to add it to your list of places to eat at. We loved sitting at the bar, our favorite seat in the house. Make sure you come hungry.

Excellent food, outstanding service ( MC was nice and welcoming, really helpful with the menu). Great place for a date, a lot of dishes can be shared, but get everything! You definitely don't want to miss the Canned Duck!

As fantastic a meal as I gave ever had!!!!! From the small warm square of foie gras that started the meal to the last bite of poutine.... the only regret I have is that I didn't try the duck in a can!!!I will be back!!!!

Make sure you bring your angioplasty kit because It's a meat party.First, the waitperson  - obsequious woman - dissuaded us from ordering any side greens.Weird.Then we asked her to guide us so we didn't over-order.What did she do?She pushed an $80 special on us that we didn't even touch.Everyone raves about this place, but I'm not sure what all the fuss is for.

Definitely our best dinner yet. Au Pied de Cochon I'm so in love with your Foie Gras--  it's practically in every dish.  The Foie Nigiri is out of this world (w/peanut butter -- trust me, it so freaking awesome) the temaki tartare and the tuna belly cooked on a salt brick w Foie both spectacular, Pot Au Feu (braised chicken, shank, bone marrow and Foie --  so delish. (For you pinoys, it's a French nilaga - we had to ask for a side of rice (waitress was confused - but it was that good)), the maple pecan pie was 2die4 so leave room for that, it's a hot day in Montreal so we went w a Sancerre Rose to compliment our meal, wine list is extensive, service is swift and vibe is casual and neighborhoody -- I heart this place and will definitely be back the next time I'm in #montreal. Merci PDC Merci. You gave this foodie her most memorable meal. Au Revoir!

Everything was so great here!! We got bone marrow & caviar, duck in a can, veggies and maple pudding chomeur. Everything was amazing. We were both really glad that we tried different things. The duck was extremely flavorful and the dessert tasted like cake with pecan pie filling.

You definitely need a reservation in advance as they get fully booked, which also means not needing to line up!  Duck in a can was as delicious as expected and it comes with foie gras so you can technically skip on ordering a separate foie gras dish. Foie gras poutine was not as good in comparison, the foie we got there was less fatty and fragrant, so I wouldn't recommend that one.

Au Pied de Cochon was one of the things I was MOST looking forward to on my Montreal trip! I mean, how can your mouth not water at the sound of foie gras poutine?! The possibilities here are endless, and trust me, they have a ton of good stuff here!We started off with a couple of drinks (some beers and a few specials each night) and ordered the following: cromesquis de foie gras, crab salad, temaki de bison, poutine au foie gras, stuffed pied de cochon, and duck in a can.I can honestly say, each one was amazing and we overindulged. The cromesquis was the perfect bite, the crab salad was fresh and delightful, the temaki melt in your mouth tender, and the poutine au foie gras, stuffed pied de cochon, and duck in a can were all that I dreamed of and more! To be honest though, the stuffed pied de cochon and duck in a can are both heavy in taste and the flavors started to meld together after a while, but they are both still delicious. The presentation of the duck in a can was unique, and the tender pork of the pied de cochon topped with fatty melty foie gras was unbeatable. The stuffed pied de cochon is a large portion, so keep that in mind - it was a little too much food for my family! The staff there were some of the nicest and friendliest people, which just added all the more to the experience.5 stars all around!

This place came highly recommended by a foodie friend so it's been on my Montreal to-do list.  I would recommend making reservations at least two weeks in advanced if you'd like to have dinner at a reasonable time. Twice I've made the mistake of not making reservations ahead of time and was left with the choice of having dinner at 5pm or 11pm. You'd likely be hard pressed to find seating as a walk in, don't even try if you're more than 2 people. They do not do online reservations so my recommendation would be to see if your hotel or credit card concierge can make the reservation for you if you're visiting from the States. The place is incredibly lively and space is at a premium. Everyone, from staff to patrons, seemed to be having a great time.The food did live up to the expectations, I'll admit, but with some rather significant missteps. The food is rich, hardy, and will likely lull you into a post-dinner stupor afterwards. We shared the fois gras poutine as an appetizer which was excellent. The duck magret in mushroom sauce was also perfectly done. Although, if I could do it again I likely would have chosen the Duck in a Can which seemed to be a favorite. The Happy Pork Chop looked amazing when I saw it being brought to a neighboring table so I decided I would order it. Unfortunately, mine was raw in the center and I had to send i back to the kitchen. For dessert we had the Milkshake XXX, which has maple liquer, and the Choco Pie. Both of which were great ways to cap off an already rich meal. Sadly, our service was quite poor that evening. Our waiter was consistently disappearing to other tables despite the fact he would literally pass us whenever he went to the kitchen. We were left to piecemeal our service by flagging down other staff for help because he rarely would return to check up on us. Had to ask someone else for more sparkling water and had to ask another waiter just for bread. At the end of the meal we literally had to point out there was an available credit card machine because our waiter was ready to do another disappearing act as soon as he left the check at our table.

Our reservation was for a larger group, and as per usual i chose the tasting menu to see the best that they can offer. If you are a carnivore, this restaurant is perfect for you. Everything was delicious and as expected the Steak, and Pork flank melted in the mouth. The exceptional part of the night was a rare gem of a wine bottle that made this a truly memorable dinner. Good job guys
Simply the best meal that I've ever had... Absolutely must have the fois Gras poutine, as it's incredibly rich, flavourful, and memorable.
Great place with a stellar ambiance in the heart of plateau mont-royal. An extensive wine list. French bread to die for. Great service and delicious eats.

Let's put it this way. You came all the way to Montreal. it's not right  to leave without having a maple sugar high - which I managed to obtain in au pied du cochon. Don't get me wrong, their signature dish is amazing - it's a great pig out! So much that I had to yelp "get that away please " when the waiting staff asked whether I'm done with it! Starters are on the small side, but given how big their mains are, it all make sense. Maybe a better portion control is needed! Also their wine is amazing, reminded me of some of the vintage I had in France...

I would travel back to Montreal just for PDC. Food is simple and beyond great. Staff goes to all ends to make the experience memorable, despite a reputation that would make it easy to be pretentious. From the waiter who stopped by to calm our son who was losing his mind, to the guys serving our table that bantered back and forth, to one of the cooks who took time to explain what he was working on and to offer sample and to the manager who was sincerely appreciative of our patronage.

I was torn on giving this place a 3 or 4 star rating. We went there for my birthday dinner and had very high expectations. My friends are not very adventurous and I've been trying not to eat meat at all. I was going to make an exception for this meal. First of all the restaurant is very busy and very loud. As an aside, floor is extremely slippery so I wouldn't recommend wearing high heels. We had a couple of appetizers but it then took 40 mins after that to get our main dishes. At that point we were not hungry anymore and wanted leave as the server did not come by to refill our drinks or apologize for the long wait. We were sitting there with no drinks or food for a very long time It was a bit much so we felt we needed to speak to the manager who was extremely nice and apologetic. He brought a bottle of champagne and was able to smooth things over. Our food finally arrived and my ham with maple syrup, mashed potatoes and Jerusalem artichokes was excellent. At the end of our meal the manager brought a couple of desserts. Food was excellent but service needs to be a bit better. I think if the server would have been a bit more attentive and not just ignored us the experience would have been much better. I've been a server before so know how it can be with a busy kitchen.

Loud and jolly, Au Pied de Cochon is an excellent place to get your arteries clogged. Don't be surprised to find foie gras as the main highlight on the menu, they don't kid with that. Not for the faint of heart - you've been warned. Our waiter was extremely helpful and hectic, in a good way. He always had a smile on. He actually forgot a coffee order from our table but made it complimentary. The duck carpaccio was marvelous. There's something extremely satisfying about breaking the egg yolk and spreading all the yellow yumminess over the raw slices of duck. You're chewing on the delicate duck and then POP, a salty jolt runs through your mouth. The salt crystals were really a nice touch. With an adventurous mindset, I've also had the bison tongue. It's kind of hard not to think that you're actually French kissing a bison. With that aside, the tongue was tender and exceptional. For my main, I had the famous duck in a can. The blob of food that came out of the can was very good. The gravy where the duck was bathing was rich and flavorful. The duck itself was a bit on the tougher side but it was enjoyable regardless. Now, I highly recommend getting a reservation. I witnessed a couple beg the manager for a table. They even said that it was their last day in Montreal. Unfortunately they weren't given have the chance to try APdC.

It' s not awful by any means but I think it's overhyped.  I came here on a number of occasions over several years.  I was disappointed the last couple of times.  Both at the restaurant and the sugar shack.  My first meal at the sugar shack was lighter and more refined.  And since then it's been good but more focused on quantity.  Huge amounts of comfort food.  We went 3 times and then stopped going a few years ago.  This is because it's hard to schedule.  Certainly I would go back again.As for the restaurant, my dish the last time didn't have enough foie gras.  It was barely detectable.  Whereas I had hoped to be delighted, I remember being disappointed with my food in general.  They are very busy; it's very crowded and noisy.I did have a VERY memorable experience here however.  When my friends were visiting from out of town, we came here and ordered a PIG HEAD.  It's really the whole kit and caboodle.  The ears were crispy...it was actually quite good but it was hard to get past the visual.  And, our friends wouldn't have any of it.  But, it's good to be in touch with your food.  I don't eat that much meat and I don't like to waste.  So I like their philosophy to not waste.I think that if you want to be immersed in 'local' culture (food with a regional flair) or if you are a local with out of town visitors then this is a good choice.
Never fails. Menu changes often. The classics never change.I recommend getting a bunch of appetizers and sharing an entree.
Phenomenal foix gras. 7 varieties. Meat hedonism at its finest!  Visited Montreal's finest...Touché and Club Chase et Pece. This ranks among the best!

I am judging overall as a meal and the service. First off, the place doesnt have a banner so it is difficult to spot if you dont know where it is. Foie gras poutine. Very good, the foie gras melted in with the poutine and you were able to taste the foie gras. The texture or the plate was consistant, there was cheesy, crispy and then the foie gras made it very good. you were able to taste that the fries were fried in the duck fat and the gravy was creamy and rich. with that being said, a very good dish but will get heavy and sickening after you eat too much of it.Foie gras a la champlain. foie gras on top of a thick slice of bacon, on a bed of thin crispy potato pancake (like a thin hashbrown), topped with a generous amount of maple syrup sauce. First bite was veryyyyy good!! So cripsy from the potato, the bacon was thick and the foie gras was enhanced in this plate, the maple syrup sauce was a good amount of sweet and salty. But this is definitely not a plate you eat on your own, its best for sharing because after a while the taste and maple syrup is quite overwhelming. table side Squash risotto. risotto was cooked very well but since it was table side she made it in the a large parmesan cheese, mixed it all together. She over poured the chicken broth and the risotto became a soup. The waiter asked how it was and I told him honestly that I did not like it because it was too watery. He left then about 3-4 mins later he asked me "do you want me to take it to the chef to try it", well no obviously not! She should have known when she served it because it was clearly too watery. He knew I was unhappy and he was the one that was pushing for this squash risotto, he didnt do anything to make up for the bad dish. At a resto like that I would expect so much more. Overall, theres definitely better. I'm glad I tried it but I would not be returning.

Great foie gras experience, super tasty, but can get a little overwhelming. Foie gras is on everything! Known for the duck in a can foie gras topping, but I only found it okay. Liked foie gras by itself, pan seared with some sort of fig/fruit jam more. Come on an empty stomach!

Visit Montreal for a weekend and made a reservation two weeks in advance. Not too hard: I left a voicemail and someone called me back the next day. Between my friend and I, we ordered:- cromesquis de foie gras, basically deep fried fg. For $4, it was worth it. - temaki tartare, tartare Japanese hand roll. They didn't have bison available and we were offered veal. I quite enjoyed the layers of flavour and texture. - carpaccio de canard, duck carpaccio. My second favorite of the night. - and finally, poutine au foie gras. I hate to say it but this was a bit of a disappointment. I'm a fan of fg but this didn't have the ah-ha for me. We went later in the evening and 2 of the 3 cocktails were already sold out. My reco would be to go early. We also had a lot of trouble finding this place late at night. You really have to know what the front looks like!

When my friend and I were certain we wanted to try Au Pied de Cochon, I tried to make reservation (1 week in advance) but their voicemail box was full... I didn't know what to do except, trying to call in the following days... And finally, 2 days before the date we wanted to go, I was finally able to make a reservation (but there weren't any tables left, and the lady asked me if it was okay to be seated at the counter/bar, which I was fine with).Being seated at the counter/bar was actually one exciting experience since we were able to watch the chefs cook and take a glance at all the dishes other customers ordered! It was really mind-blowing watching them cook in a fast-moving environment! I really liked their open-kitchen. It was also fun to guess whether the dish was ours or not too (it was our first time at Au Pied de Cochon, so we didn't know what to expect!)Before coming to Au Pied de Cochon, I searched other people's reviews and made my mind that I wanted to try their Duck in a Can! And this was one of the two dishes we ordered. We didn't know what to order next and my friend thought the The PDC Melting Pot has an interesting name, so we ordered that! Our waiter served us bread and butter (we didn't eat a lot since we wanted to save the tummy for our main courses, but the bread was not too hard, it was perfect!)Duck in a Can: Ordered it like I said because a lot of reviews said it is a must there! It is without doubt an interesting and fun dish. It came in a heated can (like how the name of the dish suggested). So, the waiter brought it over and opened it in front of you, poured the content out of the can (which contains the duck breast, 100g of foie gras, cabbages, the sauce) over the bread with carrot and cauliflower purée. The meat was really tender and it went very well with the cabbage, especially when you eat it with a small piece of duck meat. I actually really like the cabbage! It balanced the richness of the duck meat and foie gras very well. The fat under the duck meat was so chewy (I like chewy stuff) but the other fat part was.... I didn't like it since it was too greasy but some people like the feeling of fat melting in the mouth. We finished the dish (expect for the fat part) since it was too much for us.Duck in a can was quite an experience to be honest, it might not be my favorite dish due to its richness and especially oiliness but it was definitely an unique and interesting experience due to the presentation of the dish in a can!PDC Melting Pot:We actually preferred the melting pot because the taste wasn't as heavy as Duck in a Can and the pot was full of surprises, which made it more interesting. This dish came in a pot which was already hinted with its name! There was pork sausages, shiitake mushrooms, buttery potato cheese which was like mashed potatoes with cheese at the bottom, blood sausage -boudin but it is not like the Asian style one-, pork belly (so yummy!), pork loin and onions. There were a lot of things inside the pot; a lots of surprises! I absolutely loved the "buttery potato cheese", it was so delicious and well-made! The pork was tender and everything in this pot went extremely well with the mashed potatoes! The onion sauce was perfect too! It was a rich dish but not overwhelming like Duck in a Can.We also ordered their Milkshake XXX. My thought of my first sip: this is quite sweet... But afterwards, it got better! I don't know what was inside this milkshake... It tasted like rum (I'm not sure if it contained alcohol though). This was one rich milkshake I would say!We were basically in a food coma after this! I would definitely like to come back again and try their bison tongue (saw good reviews about it!)P.S: Make sure to make a reservation!!! Keep on trying even when their voicemail box is full!

It's been 2 days and I'm still thinking about the Duck in a Can. I'm not a foodie and was expecting this place to be indistinguishably decent (as I'd categorize most meals over $45), but I am so glad my coworkers insisted on coming. The Pied de Cochon was also great, with the skin and the syrupy sauce and the soft tendon barely holding the bones together. Not so much into the beef shoulder special we ordered, that I would actually drop into the "just ok" bucket.Don't plan on doing much after, you'll want to go home and take a long nap.

This restaurant seems to have more hype than delicious food. We had it's famous foie gras poutine, it's ok it's very salty . You must reserve before you come, but honestly there's better choices. We also had something else, dunno the name. But it's only ok. I will not come back again when I come to Montreal.

Au Pied de Cochon cares about their clients. As hectic and busy as it can get (see for yourself) you will NEVER be left unattended, the waiters know the menu like the back of their hand- ingredients, taste, suggestions; they know it all.  The restaurant is self-explanatory. This is not a diet-meal restaurant, you come here to feast. Pricing is not inexpensive but fair and to be expected for quality food.As an entrée, we had the "tuna cake tartar" which was a seasonal special not indicated in the menu. It was good, not great. If you are Oriental or often eat sushi, don't order this. Basically this is a layered "cake". First layer was a crispy dough/rice cake, then the rice and topped off with the tuna and beets. We then had the foie gras poutine, probably worth the buck and worth to try in my opinion; this is not your typical poutine dish but more on the gourmet and adventurous side. So you have your typical fries and cheese curd then comes the white sauce which is a foie gras based gravy with slices of foie gras on the poutine. Last but not least we ended up having the seasonal special (not on the menu) steamed tuna  with vegetable and foie gras for forty something dollar- not out of this world but quality is there.The verdict is, the customer service is excellent; if I had my own business that's how I would want my team to be. In terms of food, if it's your first time this is quite an experience but I don't think I would come back any time soon.
Ver heavy food mix of french and American too much fat. Some of the food consists of just animal fat but the duck in a can was amazing!

All I can say is wow. Martin Picard really crafted a masterful menu that embodies the Montreal spirit. It transports you into a dimly lit cabin in the mountains. The neo rustic style of cooking really shines through from dishes such a duck in a can to a whole head of pig. They start you off with a made from scratch baguette, that has a insane crust. The crackle it makes when you break into it to the fluffy interior made it easily top 5 pieces of bread I've eaten. They serve it with fresh regional butter. Next, the foie gras poutine. The most iconic dish of Montreal. It might as well be on the flag right next to the fleur de lis. Then combined with gently sautéed foie gras to maintain that rich, creaminess. BOOM. Taste buds have just been assaulted. The chicken gravy is thick and the cheese curds have that squeaky snap that we all look for. I proceeded to think it was a great idea to order an entire pig's head next. Apparently, it had a lobster in it's mouth too. Some artistic ish. Despite the presentation, the meat was tender and the skin was crispy. If I had to guess, they roasted it. They also took the lobster tail, and made a soup. Wasn't too much a fan of the soup as it was really salty. Brain with liquid lemon butter on a crostini was next and it did not disappoint. The creamy texture was very pleasant with slightly tart butter. The tongue was so broken down that it would just break apart when poking with a fork. DeliciousAlso, they brew their own beer

We did not have a reservation, but they sat us at the bar anyway. We had our 4 year old with us and because it was early they let all 3 of us sit at the bar which was very nice.The food was tremendous. The people were very nice. Total YES recommendation! Make a reservation to lower your stress and get some foie gras!

Another one of those restaurants that your friends outside of Montreal tell you you have to try. As an important tip, you MUST call and make a reservation in advance. They do not take walk-ins, even if it looks like there might be a few empty tables.The warm, fresh bread and service were great, but it ends there. The restaurant smelled a bit stale, and their A/C was dripping. Their prices were expensive considering that it felt like a casual ambiance. Between the 4 of us, we shared a bison tail appie (7/10, nothing special, tastes like ox tail); foie gras poutine (7/10, nice and rich gravy, but curds weren't the best and the foie gras was just sort of there); Duck in a Can (7.5/10, neat concept, nice flavours, too greasy); pied de cochon hot pot (7/10, decent, nothing special about flavours); a beef steak with pasta dish (5/10; way too much salt and wine!); maple creme brulee (6.5/10, too sweet and texture was like pudding); pecan tart with ice cream (7/10; standard tasting, crust was a bit overbaked).In short, try it only if you're so curious, or if don't mind paying $$$ for salty food drenched in duck fat. ;)

Overall a good experience and some standout items - chicken liver mousse was outstanding and the l'ongion soup tops any chart, but don't be duped by the hype around the Canard in Conserve, way too tough, kind of gamey and generally doesn't come together. Go with the burger instead, you won't regret.  Service did not wow.

This is my favorite restaurant in Montreal !!! Definitely recommend you guys try this place, and you will love it so much!!!My friends and I went there for dinner during our traveling in Montreal this July. One of my friends has made the reservation a couple of days before our arrival, and this restaurant is always very crowded. When we left there around 11:30 p.m., there were still several people waiting for seats.This is a French bistro. The wooden interior decoration and a large liquor cabinet as the background creates a bright, sweet, and warm dining atmosphere. You will want to take a drink and enjoy a fun night unconsciously. Every dish looked very home-made, and in a large size, especially the main courses. We have tried the foie-gras terrine as the appetizer. The maple syrup sauce was really a big surprise, not to mention the rich and creamy foie-gras itself with the crunchy bread. We also tried the wine boiled pork shank with risotto. It tasted soooo great!! You could feel the soft and rich pork melt in your mouth, and your lips become a little sticky. The bacon topping brought another different texture as well. I personally really really love this course, it feels like I was in my grandmother's kitchen.The other main dish we ordered was baked pork shank with foie-gras and mashed potato. The crispy pork skin, the mushrooms, the creamy potato, and the foie-gras matched each other very well. They all together helped me to feel different layers of this course. Although the sauce was a little bit salty, I still feel that I could forget all the troubles just because I had this meal.The house special alcoholic drink (made by sake) was smooth. And the dessert drink (maple milkshake) made a happy ending for this dinner, though it was too sweet for me.We got nice service, and the server almost could answer any question we had about the restaurant and the dishes. We also saw other tables ordered charcuterie, and the server sliced a large ham in front of us. That was really cool, and I would like to try that next time.Considering the price, the food quality, the service, and the dining environment, this place is worth to try and come back again!!!!

If you love foie gras and you are in Montreal you have to come to this place. They have a foie gras section on the menu!! Far from a gimmick, everything is expertly and artfully prepared and the vibe of the restaurant is energetic, with an open kitchen.I came here a year ago and saw there was a draft sitting in Yelp and it wouldn't let me delete it, so I thought I might as well write a quick review. They had this giant, delicious sugar pie for dessert and I only wish I had saved some more room to enjoy more of it.

Place to go for authentic French cuisine, a great atmosphere, and delicious food. Went and celebrated an occasion with my brother and some friends and were greeted by friendly staff, quick service and foie gras everything. Fair value for the big sized portions and would recommend the venison, duck in a can, or lobster foie gras. Enjoy!

Decent food, almost unnecessarily decadent? We had the foie gras poutine, duck magret and side of vegetables. The table next to us had their duck magret with sauce on the side, I feel like we should have followed as the sauce was too sweet with the mountain of caramelized onion that overwhelmed the mushrooms in the sauce and the perfectly cooked duck. The vegetable was asparagus, charred and seasoned to perfection, but the cheese on top is total overkill and did nothing. Once the asparagus and the duck got cold (we sat by the window on a hot June evening), the cheese slide right off in a gross lump and the sweet of the duck sauce became unbearable. I have a strong feeling this food will be much more appreciated in the Arctic Montréal winter rather than a summer evening

A long awaited meal on my recent trip to Montreal. The previous night we had a disappointing meal at Liverpool House so I did not have my hopes very high for this meal. I was very surprised however.Service was on point and the atmosphere was professional. Restaurant was also MUCH more spacious and more than adequately staffed. Everyone was very friendly and attentive throughout the whole dinner. We had the foie gras, tartare temaki, and the house pasta. While our dinner tonight was smaller than the previous night, it was much better. The foie gras was served with toasted bread and a maple syrup sauce that was to die for. The tartare temaki was creative and so delicious. The pasta was very rich and filling. I wish I hadn't just had a charcuterie plate before coming here because I had no more room to eat! All in all I would love to come back here!

The famed Au Pied de Cochon.  Seeing it on Anthony Bourdain's No Reservations has made it a mecca for foodies, specifically for the numerous foie gras dishes and the canard in a can. So lets get down to it. The place was packed, make reservations in advance via email.Wine list is impressive, but go for their house blonde draft.  It's refreshing and crisp.  Perfect for cutting through the richness of the food. Started with the pate du campagne and the PDC salad.   The salad was excellent, nicely cooked offals over a bed of greens.  The pate was good, very rustic.  For entrées, the boudin and foie tart and the PDC pot. The tart was rich, decadent, unctuous... take your pick. The pot was great, several sausages and different meats served in a cast iron pot.Service was good, our server and busser were very friendly.If you were looking for great Quebecois cuisine, this is it.

Few things in life are special in their own way and are precious without a price tag. They not only leave a long lasting impression but ultimately they change who you are as a person and define what you become:- perhaps your very first memory ever, maybe with your parents in your childhood home-Your first kiss, the anxiety leading up to it  - am I going to do it right ? Will they laugh at me ? And the overwhelming happiness after.- First time you fall in love and feel on top of the worldThis is how I felt when I had dinner here - I ordered a baked squash stuffed with cheese and this is a first time I had squash that tasted this orgasmically perfect. I couldn't have asked for anything better that night - a warm cozy inviting ambiance that blanketed you like a warm smooshey blanket, a perfect bottle of wine, company of dear friends and THAT SQUASH. That squash was the most amazing squash I have ever had ! I eat it all, including the skin and I barely let my husband eat the tiniest piece. The rest of the evening was a blur, I think one of my friends ordered a "duck in a can?"But all I remembered was this butternut squash. I have since come home from this trip ( this was in September of 2015) and been cooking squash non-stop ever since. It's been over a year and a half and I still remember the taste of this perfectly cooked squash in my mouth !When a restaurant has this much power, you know it will be worth your visit. I been back to the city many times, but too scared to come back and ruin that perfect memory. Perhaps on my next visit, I'll take a leap of faith. This is a must to visit, you won't regret it.

One of the most memorable and decadent meals of my life (and possibly yours). Vegetarians, steer clear: This is a carnivore's paradise. If you love foie gras, blood sausage, and the like, you will absolutely love this place. If you're more of a green juice and kale salad person, pass on this.I came with a group of 7 and we were so lucky to get a reservation about a week in advance. I've read there are usually horrendous wait times. Definitely come with a group and share everything family style if you can. The portions are so enormous and there are too many things you'll want to get, it's best to sample a little bit of everything. The sheer amount of meat was overwhelming and potentially heart attack-inducing but I enjoyed so many things about the experience that, from the awesome service, laidback atmosphere, juicy juicy pork knuckles, to the foie gras, that I just have to give it five stars.Our waiter was friendly and super knowledgeable about the menu. He made our evening that much more fun and made sure we ordered the right dishes and, perhaps more impressively, the right amount. Instead of just encouraging us to get as much as possible, he actually told us to scale back.Understatement of the year: We ate a LOT. Little cubes of fried, melt-in-your-mouth foie gras. The most tender pork knuckles over a bed of mashed potatoes. SEAL RIBS, a special that we all wanted to try but were not blown away by. Amazing steak. A mouthwatering Monte Cristo (with pork belly, mustard, and french toast). Cassoulet. PDC Melting Pot. The best strawberry pie of my life. And, of course, foie gras poutine. Not every dish was perfect - some were too salty, others too fatty - but the meal was still mind-blowing. Although I very, very rarely consume this much meat, I will gladly come back here whenever I return to Montreal. In fact, I might return just to eat here...

Very very disappointed!The food is just ordinary! Don't understand what other people are talking about. The Duck in the can is the worst! The big chunk of meat was so chewy and I almost threw up when I saw the huge piece of duck fat. I asked the waiter what I was supposed to do with the fat. He told me it is just for cooking the dish not for eating. You got be kidding me! DO NOT SERVE ANYTHING YOU CANNOT EAT ON A PLATE PLEASE! By the way, the service is not great either. The waiter is not helpful at all for recommendation. It feels like he doesn't want to be responsible for any of your choices, or he just doesn't care. I wish I could make a reservation at Joe Beef instead. Next time, I will book 3 months in advance!

If you are ever in Montreal try this place. Absolutely amazing. One of the best meals we ve ever had. So much Fois Gras! And so delicious. Service was excellent too! A true gem of the French cuisine. Our server coursed our meals perfectly. We ordered a lot of food and the server made sure that our meal placement was exactly as needed.

This place is popular. We made a reservation during the week for Saturday and 10:30 is the earliest time. They have indoor and outdoor seating. The service is really good there. Everyone is very friendly. We tried the following dishes. I have to say I've never had so much foie gras in my life. - Tuna & foie gras: they have tuna special that day as they got fresh tuna in the morning. This one has tuna sashimi, raw egg yolk and foie grad with some sauce. They provided a spoon to eat it so that we can mix anything we want. - lobster and foie gras Cheong fun: very interesting dish as Cheong fun is a typical dish in Chinese Dim Sum. I like this dish the second. - foie gras poutine- Pork: I forgot the name but it's one of the special that day. It's pork in mushroom sauce with potatoes and some fresh mushrooms. I have to say this is probably my favorite here. Everything tastes good.

This was probably my favorite meal when we were in Montreal. I tried to learn French for this trip but was to shy to try because I was afraid to mess up. So when I asked the waitress if she spoke English she said of course and took amazing care of us. The food was fantastic.  I think the charcuterie board was my favorite part. Everything about our experience there was great.

It was my friend Justin's birthday, 2012.My friend Yi and I ordered the pig's head. But you see, it wasn't just a pig's head. A lobster in the mouth, and with the skull pried open to reveal the brain, this was a feast for the ages.Did I mention it was 2012? Ok, because that evening ex-Premier of Quebec Jean Charest walked in with his family and favorite bodyguards and sat on the table to our right. It was the height of the student protests and I guess the twittersphere must have been active that night. Within 20 minutes the restaurant was surrounded with angst-filled unfulfilled twenty-somethings banging on the walls and windows of the cozy restaurant. That said, my friends and I were far too involved with the pig's head to care. Get the pig's head.

We had the most amazing experience here last night. We were a group of 6 girls celebrating a bachelorette party. We were not sure what we wanted so our took our price point and designed the courses for us. We had the poutine, tuna tar tar, trout, ahi steaks, duck in a can, and more. The mashed potatoes were out of this world. The wait staff made sure we had an amazing night, bringing us shots, doing a champagne sabor, and introducing us to the bar across the street! I would definitely come back every time I visit Montreal.

This meal was spectacularly memorable. The service was impeccable. The staff were some of the sociable, inviting, fun-spirited (and knowledgeable about the food and wine!) I've experienced in a long time. We had the pleasure of sitting near the brick-oven stove and got a whiff of all dishes making their way to the front of the house. Everything smelled delicious!! And everything tasted even better. We ordered the naked foie gras, the an exceptional tartare with quail egg (don't eat the shell!), and of course, the duck in a can which (..not to spoil the surprise..) comes with foie! We got their at 10:30pm (exceptionally late) and the crowd was still  (definitely not rowdy) and there was an aura of energy and delight in the air... and foie!!! When I return to Montreal, I will most certainly be dining at Au Pied de Cochon.

Decadent, delicious and pricey. With exceptional food comes exceptional cost and if you're up for it this place is worth it. Tucked on a side street among other cool little shops and eateries, this restaurant has a great vibe from the moment you walk in. Staff is attentive and fun. Menu consists of just about everything to quench the taste buds of your inner carnivore. Fois Gras has its own place on the menu and is front and centre to the dining experience. We had a bunch of little apps and some bigger ones too and then gave in to the temptation of 90 day aged Wagyu steak. The sauces that accompany the dishes will have you using your finger as a spatula to get out every last bit. If you have room or even if you don't, order the sugar pie for dessert. Every bite at Au Pied du Cochon demands a moment of quiet reflection as your eyes roll back in your head.

Food: Only ordered the donut, I'm sorry but Tim Hortons cannot compare. Before eating digging in, the faint scent of chocolate filling is already to die for~ One bite is sufficient to conquer you! Perfect crunchy outside but soft and tender inside, with the liquid chocolate filling, not overly sweet but enough to fill your whole mouth with an explosion of chocolate taste, hm... I'm salivating again now...Service: Staff are super nice and fastValue: A little overpriced (like most food trucks)...

Upon learning that Au Pied de Cochon likes to inject foie gras into everything from poutine to pancakes, I knew I had to give these people some business.One of my friends scored us reservations at the bar which adjoins an entirely open kitchen where Chef Martin Picard and his capable cadre of culinary alchemists created their inimitable dishes mere feet away from us.Picard is hands-on and oversees or participates in every aspect of the food preparation, all while getting wasted in plain view of his customers. Watching Picard chug an Irish Car Bomb, two glasses of wine, and three pints of beer in the two hours I was there was unreal. By the time I left, the dude's body was rocking back and forth and one of his eyes was permanently closed. It was awesome, they should give him a reality TV show.I began the meal with the bison tongue appetizer, tender strips of meat prepared with tarragon. The meat itself was sweet and had a powerful and distinct flavor.My dining partner ordered the venison tartare, which she let me taste. Nicely seasoned with capers, shallots, lemon, and a hint of capsicum, it was probably the most delicate and lean of all of the food that I sampled.My entrée, however, was a unique and innovative achievement of culinary gluttony -- "Canard en Conserve," or "Duck in a Can." Duck in a Can is half a duck magret with a hunk of foie gras tucked under the skin, buttered cabbage, bacon, roasted garlic, two sprigs of thyme, and venison demi-glace, sealed and cooked in a can.The can was opened by the server in front of me and dumped over toast covered with celery root puree. Yes, it tastes as insane and rich as it sounds.My duck magret was not the only tantalizing piece of meat at Au Pied de Cochon; prep-cook Emily's derriere thrilled as she calmly executed Picard's grand scheme -- such a full, wonderfully shaped backside for a white woman that I slurred on about it ad nauseum, even as my friend's eyes rolled each time I did so.Emily and all of the kitchen staff were friendly, occasionally stopping in-between chopping vegetables to ask how we were enjoying our meals, or to answer our questions about dishes they were working on.The only negative thing I can say about this place is its lack of quality single-malt scotch, but this appears to be a systemic problem throughout Montréal. I happily settled with a Macallan 18, which went well with the Pouding Chômeur dessert, literally translated as a poor man's pudding. This resembled a bread pudding made with a maple syrup custard and sponge cake.I look forward to returning to Au Pied de Cochon on future visits to the city. I'd recommend this experience to anyone who loves food, and would also suggest that you try to score a bar seat reservation so you can watch Chef Picard get piss drunk in front of you.
It is truly an unforgettable experience. Dress up to get tanatlized. Truly unique to quebec and many other places I have been to. Here is where we send all the rock stars.

Our night at Au Pied De Cochon...Long review but worth the read. Please don't get fooled by the hype.We were on time for our reservation and the Maitre'd wasn't even around for a good 5 minutes which was alright. We were able to get to our table by 910pm.By 922pm we were ready to be assisted. Our waitress wasn't the usual who would talk to you and recommend anything. I had to ask if they had any specials, recommendations, etc. They served baguette which was good. So we were happy and thought ok this will be a good night. Lol. What we ordered: shrimp temaki (specials), French onion soup, Foie Gras hamburger and Côte de cochon heureux (pork), maple creme brûlée & specialty coffee (had maple alcohol)So the appetizers started arriving around 15 minutes so that's 9.40pm. After 50 minutes of waiting for the main course!!! The food came out... This time we were already getting annoyed. The shrimp temaki: was only good because of the nori, it lacked a bit of zing to it... I'm pretty used to eating Japanese. So I just wished they made it more flavorful and refreshing (cool in the mouth) and a little bit of wasabi too. In the end of the temaki had bacon bits which was not good. The French onion soup: lacks the onion taste and onion and just had beef in it.  Foie Gras hamburger: this one the Foie gras was good! The patty and buns... Don't waste your calories. It was a bit cold too they let it stay out for awhile now.Côte de cochon heureux (pork): over cooked. Dry. Cold. I had to let them take it back. Which the waitress did and said they'll send me a new one. I then decided that I was too full to eat it. I talked to the manager/owner telling him I wanted to cancel the order already and told him the reason why. We ended the night with our coffee and dessert. Then our waitress said the pork isn't going to be charged and we get a free dessert. That's why I'm even giving a 1 star to this review (if I didn't need to it would have been a zero)Even the creme brûlée took so long to be sent out. The waitress gave us our bill. When we got our dessert it was so cold already!! Creme brûlée isn't supposed to be served cold. I just cannot. What a way to celebrate our first night in Montreal. Never going back to this restaurant. Service isn't so great as well.

Indulgent Monstrosities. That is what you are paying to battle in Au Pied de Cochon. Huge portions of delicious delicious beasts imaginatively cooked, outrageously decadent, and quite often topped with foie gras. This is a popular destination so be prepared to make a reservation (via email or phone) at the very least a month in advance. Make sure to confirm my reservation the night or the day of via email/phone. I failed to confirm my reservation the first time I came here and when we showed up our name was not on the list. Luckily we didn't wait long to be seated.The interior is casual and cool;  with a accordion windowed doors in the front that opens in the summer and hanging pendant lights with Edison bulbs. The layout is a little weird and somewhat cramped. The bathrooms are at the end of the bar/ kitchen area. If you're seated in the front, it is an odyssey to dodge and duck your way to the bathroom. Service each time was friendly and quick despite a crowded night.The food is amazing. Luxuriously rich and served in gluttonous amounts. You need to be a rotund competitive eater to be able to eat everything.-Duck Carpaccio 14It looks like art and it tastes fantastic. Drizzled with olive oil and the yolks of some unknown fowl, each bite is unctuous goodness. -Foie Gras Poutine  24This is probably my favorite poutine dish. Creamy rich fattiness over crisp fries. You just have to order this.-Stuffed Pied de Cochon with Foie Gras 45This could probably feed 3 to 4 people comfortably. Its pigs foot cooked til the skin is delightful crisp, covered with creamy sauce, over some wonderful mash of potato married with cheese. All crowned with an obscenely huge chunk of foie gras.-Duck in a Can  44I ordered this the first time I came here. It is an experience you should have when you're in Montreal. The duck breast with foie gras is cooked in the can. The meat basically cooks in this rich fatty bath. They open the can at the table and dump the contents on a plate of some creamy puree. It is incredibly rich. Be careful not to order too much if you plan on ordering this.-If it appears on the menu again get the Foie gras Tout Nu. Heavenly morsels that melt in your mouth with this dark thick sauce that makes your taste bud sing. This was my first taste of foie gras and it was an experience.-My husband got Horse tartare the last time we were here. It was a humongous portion and came with crispy a yummy fries. The horse tartare was seasoned beautifully. It had a nice heat and was so flavorful.Drinks are great. I had a bourbon cocktail with maple syrup ($12) and my husband got the cream ale ($6).Despite already coming here twice and despite there being so many other places I would like to visit in Montreal, it would be hard for me to resist the temptation of coming here.  Fight the urge to order everything. It is a great experience to dine so sinfully.

Simply amazing. As our waiter listed each of the specials, I knew it would be really hard to choose. We decided on the beef tongue appetizer, the halibut nigiri, the naked foie gras and the halibut collar. (We definitely overate, but had to try several things). The main entree was huge, and the fish and the vegetables were amazing. The beef tongue was my favorite dish. I would definitely recommend!

Au Pied de Cochon is bad, and it's bad in a disingenuous way that is insidious and upsetting. It simultaneously wants to be upscale and populist - Poutine, but with foie gras! Lobster rolls, but with foie gras! Chicken nuggets, but with foie gras and maple syrup! A fun-house restaurant like this could be excused for the many, many lapses in service, quality, and good taste. However, the prices and officious service make it very clear that this is a "serious" restaurant and demands to be judged as such. I won't complain too much about the overbearing wine service, as it was the only time in the multi-hour meal where any server seemed to remember that their job was to serve. I hesitate to even refer to the men and women in matching shirts as servers, since they seemed to spend the evening engaged in some kind of Olympic qualifying event involving running, shouting, and breaking dishes.Before I document the numerous outrages of the service, perhaps we should discuss the food? Perhaps you're wondering what the titular and famed Au Pied de Cochon (pig's foot) stuffed with foie gras tastes like? I also wonder - it was out by the time we were seated, and our dilatory waitress (the first of many) deigned to stop by -- approximately 30 minutes later. The pig's head for two was also out. And the crab. And tartare. That eliminated roughly 40% of the menu, and essentially all the things for which APdC is known. One can't help but wonder why a restaurant would have a 9:00 seating if all the food is gone. The waitress tried to upsell us on some specials , including a gnocci made in a hallowed-out wheel of parmesan, the cart for which was rushed around by frantic waiters through the evening. Unfortunately, my dining companion's chair was inconveniently situated in the dining area, and often in the way of this cart. My friend spent his dinner being jockeyed aside by the harried server. When we needed time to consider what food to order, our waitress (#1) disappeared for another 30 minutes - undoubtedly to give us time to peruse the remaining 8 menu items. This was interrupted only by the first appearance of the wine steward who informed us that the bottle we ordered was out.When our waitress finally reappeared (my companions and I now having grown beards and birthed children, who in turn had given us many grandchildren, bringing joy and delight into our lives), I was heavily sold on the PDC Melting Pot--it was a "staff favorite". No sooner had I ordered it then I was informed it, too, was out. Here's what we ended up managing to order from the apparently empty kitchen:* Foie Gras Cromesquis - foie gras croquettes with a liquefied center, imagine a hybrid croquette and Xaio Ling Bao with foie gras. These were very good. * Duck Carpaccio - doesn't need description. Tasty if unremarkable. * Chicken Nuggets with Foie Gras - Well-seasoned, deep fried boneless chicken with foie gras with maple syrup on the side. Also good. Foie gras added nothing, though.If the meal ended there I would consider this a good if unremarkable restaurant with atrocious service. Unfortunately, we made the error of moving to main courses. I ordered the "famous"(?) pork chop and my companions had the famous Duck in a Can, but of which resembled unappetizing brown mush. Both the duck and the pork chop were tough and somehow bland. Did I mention both came in a thin brown sauce that slopped around the plate? I should have, as our waitress (#3) nearly spilled all of it on my shirt when she tossed it on the table. Thanks to the long waits between seeing a server, we were spared ordering dessert, which undoubtedly they would have been out of anyway. Once the bill arrived, we finally had attentive service -- the wine steward somehow noticed a bottle was left off our bill within seconds and snatched it away to inflate the final invoice. It was the first sign of efficiency, competence, or haste the entire evening, unfortunately coming at our expense.The final insult arrived after we'd paid the bill when the maître 'd arrived to ask how everything was. One of my companions added that we'd had water dripping on us all evening (true). The captain 1) denied all knowledge, 2) basically claimed it wasn't happening, and then said he would 3) look into it once we pointed out the water drops clustered on the ceiling above. "In all my 7 years," the captain mused, "I've never seen that happen." Strange, as an hour before we'd seen one of his staff come out and wipe the ceiling with a cloth on a pole, made obviously for this specific problem. I mentioned before that I think this type of food and service is bad and insidious. Dining like this tricks people into thinking this is what "fancy" or "upscale" food is like - worse versions of things they eat cheaply (poutine, chicken nuggets) served with a sneer. Like all that is pretentious, it is a strange combination of sickening, embarrassing to watch, and infuriating. This is a must-avoid.

We had a raucous time at this most celebrated eatery. Mostly what I remember is being so stuffed that it was borderline uncomfortable. The owner of the place was there that night and he kept ringing this bell which would signal the kitchen staff to take a drink. So much fun...Anywoo,  the foie gras... that was the highlight of the meal (though we're not used to it being so veiny). We had a couple of different varieties, along with the "PDC's cut" (huge), and the "PDC's melting pot". We even managed to stuff down some french fries cooked in duck fat. Luckily we walked there through the snow and ice so we managed to at least burn some calories walking back to our hotel.So much meat it kinda bedazzles the taste buds, but you could hardly call that a complaint. But if you're looking for a quiet, romantic night out- that this is not. But for a fun time with a lot of meat this is your spot.

A palace of meats. We were steered here by someone acquainted with the city who had declared it his favorite restaurant in the world. I came in excited for the bison ribs, only to see the last rack of the night carried away as we were seated. I ended up with a pork chop and cider, she went for the sea bass. The quality, the service, and the price were all aligned. I would not come through Montreal without stopping here again. You'll need a reservation, and should probably skip the previous meal to prepare. Some items are prepared in advance and they will run out as the evening goes on.

A very rich and tasty meal.  The staff were very friendly and accommodating to our two small children. The food was very rich and flavorful. We had the pork leg special as well as the foie gras poutine. Sooo good. Didn't have room for any desserts.

If I could give 10 stars I would. This place was the best dining experience I have had in a very long time!We are visiting from California. I was dying for foie gras because we don't have it anymore in California. We asked our concierge for a reservation. He called said all they had was 9:30pm. A little late for dinner but I was excited just to go. Every restaurant on the street was slow except this one. Completely packed with people. We go in and all they have is a spot at the bar. My boyfriend and I didn't mind and followed the hostess down the hallway dodging the servers who are running back and forth. This place is chaotic and loud in the best sort of way. Our bartender/server was named Jerrome. He was the best bartender I have ever met. He was exciting and fun. He made our Experience incredible. He was knowledgable and entertaining. He was from France and such a happy guy. You could tell he found so much joy in his job. We ordered the poutine fries with foie gras. I don't think you should come here and not have them. They are incredible. Then we had the melting pot which has different kinds of porks. It also come with mashed potatoes. Lastly we had duck in can. Omg that was the best thing we have ever had. I was a little scared when it actually came in a can and they opened it right in front of us. They literally dump all the goodness on top of a toasted bread and cauliflower purée. This also comes with foie so you can't lose. The wine by the glass is a little pricy. We ordered the Pinot Noir which was $17 per glass. It was worth the price because it was smooth and wonderful! I don't think we stopped smiling once. I highly recommend siting at the bar. If your someone who is looking for a normal fine dining experience I wouldn't come here. This isn't a white table cloth stuffy kinda place. This is a place to enjoy amazing rich food and have an experience like no other. I will miss Montreal for this place alone.

A reservation is needed here! Even with a reservation, be expected to wait if you're dining in during the weekend. The restaurant had a working kitchen that you can see and also a view of all the different seafoods such as oysters. The entire menu is in French so we had the waitress translate the menu for us. It was packed to the fullest and literally, you are on top of everyone when sitting. No personal space really but they moved us to a more open space in the back of the restaurant.The food here was delicious! We ordered the cromesquis de fois grau and it was delicious! I couldn't believe how flavorful it was in a single bite. The staff was amazing and very friendly here. They offered us a complimentary assortment of meats for the long wait. I tried the duck in a can and it tasted so good and so rich. It's definitely a unique presentation, something I haven't seen before.

Amazing meal was had here. Great for big parties. We ordered everything with foie and I had one of the most memorable dishes ever! A whole pig head! The gelatinous and meaty nomz that kept me eating for hours. Everything was good except the poutine with foie think because I'm not a poutine fan. We had leftover to nosh on the next two night back at the hotel. Taaaaaaasty!!! Would love to go back again next time I'm in Montreal!

Au Pied de Cochon is an institution owned by Wild chef Martin Picard.His love for Pork,Foie gras & Maple syrup reflects in most of his dishes.Pied de Cochon means "Pigs foot". The food here is Heart stopping..... Literally. If you are a health freak, this place is not for you. Most of the dishes here are capable of putting you into a food induced coma. We started with a Maple bourbon daiquiri. Ordered the BC oysters, Duck fries & Tomato Tartlet. The BC oysters were big and fresh. Also the sauce it came with was very flavorful. The duck fries were kinda meh. I've had better. The Tomato tartlet was very rich, flaky & full of flavor. For mains we ordered the Lobster roll with foie gras, The Bison rib, Duck in a can & Pied de cochon. My favorite was Duck in the can. Duck breast with skin marinated in foie gras and served on a bread. Was very rich. A bit too rich for a couple of my friends, But I enjoyed it.The Bison rib was really good. One giant rib cooked to perfection. The lobster roll was good. The buttery flavor and foie gras make it very heavy. Pied de Cochon was pork with foie gras on a bed of mashed potatoes and foie gras infused mushroom gravy. We couldn't finish it all. It was an amazing experience. I OD'd on meat. Now have to go on a detox diet for a week. But was TOTALLY WORTH it.Food : Gastronomically deliciousService :GreatAmbiance : Casual/LoudWorth the price : Yes

Oh so good but oh so freaking heavy. Everything we sampled was amazing but my god the stuffed pigs' feet was easily the heaviest dish I've ever had. In life. This thing could've knocked out a small mammal. I think it's worth a shot to check this place out but this is almost a bachelor party kind of meal and would be pretty ideal for 5-6 guys to just feast in.

Full stop - this place is unreal. The flavors and food combinations are so unique and incredibly delicious. There is nothing else like this restaurant anywhere in the world. This was our favorite meal in Montreal (and we tried many of the other popular places, including Joe Beef). Attentive and authentic service. We will be back!

It has been a week since we ate here.... And I am STILL talking about this meal! I have one picture- of an empty plate. Favorite items were:1. Creme Brûlée: hands down perfect & I'm a brûlée snob.2. Foie Gras Cromesquis: I've never had anything like it. Amazing. 3. Duck in a can: GET THIS! I asked if I could buy these cans to take home... They told me no. Lol! 4. My drink: Bombay, maple syrup & champagne 5. Nigori foie gras. Rich and felt like a glutton... But well worth it!
Love this place. Open late. Always a good time!  Rich food!You really can't go wrong!Go there!

Long story short: you will be fed to death for what will be the HEAVIEST meal in your life. Highly recommended for tourists like myself. The experience is incredible. The staff is very friendly and knowledgable. The vibe is ultra cool and you will probably get a lifetime's worth of foie gras in one meal.

IMA in Montreal.  I loved Au Pied de Cochon!  First, the room is casual, nicely lit, and has a great feel to it.  It is the kind of place where you know you are going to have a fun night.  But of course, you are there for the food and drink.  Unfortunately, they were out of the duck in a can, but it ended up being a blessing because we got to try the Guinea Hen for two, which was one of the best meals I've ever had.  I also enjoyed the fois gras poutine and some of the appetizers. I appreciate that the restaurant also has some very reasonably priced wines on their expansive yet focused wine list. All in all, a home run.

Heard so many great things about this place so I knew I had to try it when I was visiting Montreal for the long weekend. The restaurant atmosphere and service was fantastic. The food was good, really good.. although I admit I may have walked in with overly high expectations. To start, I ordered the Cromesquis de Foie Gras which came with two bite-sized pieces. The batter was perfectly crispy with the foie gras filling a smooth creamy texture. My initial thoughts were that the size was smaller than expected, however after eating the entire piece in one bite as per what the server suggested, I realized it was the perfect size. Anything larger and the filling to batter ratio would have been offset. Then came our foie gras poutine. This dish was all sorts of goodness. There was definitely a generous serving of foie gras in this dish and it tasted really good but I feel that some acidity to cut the fat would have made the flavours more balanced. Each bite was super creamy and salty (not a bad thing at all) but after half the poutine I felt that I needed a week-long cleanse. Totally worth it though. The last dish that we ordered was of course the Duck in a Can. I appreciate the innovation behind this dish as I have not heard nor seen a dish that is even remotely similar to this technique. The waiter explained that the ingredients are all cooked inside of the can for 40 minutes. Pretty cool. The contents of the can was then poured over a crispy crostini with carrot purée. I loved crostini as it added more texture to the dish. However I felt that was flavour of the broth/sauce in which the duck was cooked in quite one-dimensional. It reminded me of a stew with a bunch of different ingredients and soggy vegetables. This is not a bad thing, in fact the overall dish was quite yummy but I can't say it met my expectations especially after hearing so many people rave about this dish. I felt that the fat on the duck breast needed to be rendered down a lot more and I ended up just avoiding the skin all together. Portion wise, it was the perfect amount of food for a main course if shared with another person. Overall I found that this restaurant was a good experience and would recommend it to those looking for innovative dishes and a unique dining experience. I am curious about what else they offer and will definitely be returning.

If you love Foie this is the place for you.  You can't go wrong with anything.  I especially love the carpaccio and PDC salad.  The Foie poutine was great too.  I look forward to coming back to try the other items coming out of the kitchen which passed by me :)The service and the people were impeccable!

We visited here in Montreal.  It's not too far walk from a Metro stop, and easy to walk right by.   Pros:  the food.  I had the salad as a starter.  It has a wonderful light erasing with slivers of Apple and crumbles of Brie and blue cheese.  My husband had the foie gras pancake with maple syrup.  He though the savory and sweet flavors were wonderful.  For the main I had the pork chop (gluten free) and it was amazing with every bite.  My husband had the rabbit meatloaf, very rich.   For dessert the maple syrup cake.Cons:  the atmosphere is not conducive to conversation.  Loud, loud, loud!  My ears were ringing when I came outside.  The tables are squeezed in tightly and not comfortable.  The kitchen area is directly behind the bar and it is loud and chaotic.  The waitstaff runs up and down the narrow aisle next to you.The waitstaff was distracted.  We had five different staff members wait on us at any given time.  Confusing.  They are dressed very informally so you cannot tell if they are a guest or waitstaff.

I will say this: Au Pied De Cochon is the best restaurant I have ever been to. Saying anything else other than what's already been said and illustrated in pictures, would just be redundant and not do this place justice. We come here every time we visit beautiful Montreal.Get yourselves the duck in a can with the PDC mashed potatoes and vegetables side for a complete and delectably rich meal. Don't forget to wash it down with a Griffon brown ale!P.S. The above meal I suggested can, and SHOULD, be shared between a couple.

If you love pork and foie gras, this place is heaven. Recommend getting the foie gras poutine and the duck in a can. We also ordered the onion soup, duck carpaccio and the dumplings.Onion soup - your standard cheesy onion soup done right. Super tasty. Foie gras Poutine - must get!! Abundance of extra buttery and fatty foie gras with fries and gravy. This is a heavy dish so great for sharing and having a cold beer. Duck carpaccio - the presentation of the dish was beautiful. Thinly slice duck with chives, raw mushrooms and a yolk. Duck in a can - must get as well! The waiter brings over the can and opens it in front of the table. The content of the can contains the small duck, foie gras, cabbage which is all poured over the bread with carrot purée. The meat was tender and succulent.The service was very good - our waiter was extremely nice and helpful in making suggestions. There are so many options to choose from so it's great if you come with a big group and share everything!

Great spot however most of the items we wanted to try were sold out. Such as the lasagna, which you should clearly try if possible because it seems like a bestseller. If you've never tried French expect to experience a lot of rich dishes.

We made the reservation two weeks ago. Probably because it's weekday, we are the only customers at 5:00pm.We didn't drink alcohol, only a bottle of water. The water is in glass bottle, taste better than thesame brand in plastic bottle.Tarragon Bison Tongue is the first dish. The tongue is from beef. Mr. Tang said it's good. I prefer the pickle, since I didn't try the tongue.Catch of the day, we picked the smoked eel. It also served with a piece of veal bone, you can eat the marrow(not sure if it's this word...).Fg poutine is great, although foie gras is too greasy for me.The duck in a can is great too. The duck is juicy and fresh, also with blood. The veggie taste a bit sour, really savory.The one missing star is for the dessert. Both icecream and pecan pie are too sweet for me to enjoy.

Checked this place out on a business trip last week and was very pleased.  We started with the cromesquis de fois grau which included two that were a single bite each - considering this, the price seems a little steep however I can assure you they were the best single bite I think I've ever had in my life. Awesome!We also had some tasty beers and the fish and chips with the duck fat frites - the fish was perfectly cooked and very tender and the fries were great as well.  I can't forget to mention that our server was exceptional and took great care of us also.Overall a great experience - next time we will definitely have to try more fois!!!
Very hard to reserve, call ahead of time! Good food, worth to try. Good service as well.

Food was a 3.5 but I'm rounding up to 4 because of the nicest, friendliest, and entertaining bartenderI relied on Yelp to help me plan what to eat during my visit to Montreal. I saw that Au Pied de Cochon was the #1 restaurant on Yelp in Montreal. I figured well that's a must! First off, we tried to make reservations via phone for several days during various times (e.g., before 5pm, after 5pm, after 7pm, after 10pm) and we left voice messages. We still couldn't get in touch with them to make a reservation. We came in on a Saturday early evening around 5:30. Luckily, there were seats at the bar with no wait. Although the restaurant was empty, all the tables were reserved. They did fill up quickly as the night went on. I experienced such wonderful and fun service at the bar that I'm so happy we were never able to make reservations! The bartender offered us a drink, samples of his cocktails, samples of garnishes (i.e., ground cherry, toffee chips)! It was also fun to see him make his cocktails with his wide smile and sense of humor! Really made the whole experience a lot of fun!Food: In my opinion, it was just OK. A bit salty. Nothing spectacular. Poutine with foie gras: definitely my favorite dish; foie gras was delicious and the whole dish just went well togetherMelting pot pork dish: a mixture of different cuts of pork; pretty tasty; came with mashed potatoes as wellA replacement duck dish for a sold out menu dish was too salty. I don't remember the name but it was duck wrapped in some kind of pasta/crepe covered with mushroom sauce. I wasn't a fan. Beefsteak: pretty good, but nothing special. came with fries dipped in duck fat which didn't taste any different from regular fries.I think my experience here wasn't as great as other yelpers because there were a lot of dishes that they no longer served or were out of. IDK...maybe we should have gotten the duck in a can???! Oh well.. at least the poutine was good..

A fun place to fatten yourself in a meal full of foie gras! There's a whole section in the menu dedicated to just foie gras dishes! Do try the foie gras poutine as a starter to share for $23 or better yet, get the "foie gras duo" for $51 which is a bison burger and foie gras and balsamic reduction and a half order of the foie gras poutine. Extremely decadent duo but great if you want some burger and fries and a whole lot of foie gras!The duck in a can $43 is another must and yes, the dish comes out of a can that is opened in front of you. It comes with a duck breast with 100 grams foie gras, balsamic reduction, buttered cabbage, roasted garlic and thyme. Extremely rich but worth trying. The duck was extremely tender. The whole dish is very brown with more brown so it's hard to see what you're eating. Service is extremely prompt and friendly with lots of knowledge on the food and wine. Bathroom is located at the back and one behind the bar counter (weird spot). Not a fan of the soap they use....hate actual bar soap in public places as it feels pretty nasty especially this bar of soap as it was one of those natural soaps with lots of tree branches and such embedded in it. ew. Nonetheless, fantastic over the top foie gras eatery that's a must try if you're in Montreal.

The authority on rustic Quebecois and Canadian food.  Portions are generous.  Service is friendly.  Wine is extensive, and they'll recommend based on price.  No pretentions, just great food.  No cheap, though.The duck in the can is a staple of their menu for a reason.  Duck carpaccio was incredibly light and complex.  Maple pouding chomeur was good, but I enjoyed my previous experience with the sugar pie more.Book well in advance.  Vegetarians should look elsewhere...unless you eat fish.

Excellent food and excellent service! Pretty much our main inspiration when planning a trip to Montreal (along with those Fremont bagels! lol).I would recommend ordering (ahead) the pigs head! It is seriously the most delicious thing ever! Yeah people will gawk, I dunno why, but they do- let them! Its so flavorful, the skin is very crispy, the meat tender and full of flavor, and if your an adventurous eater- everything is good! The tongue, the brain, (the eyes if you wanna get all Bizarre Foods Ala Andrew Zimmern- we did, lol) everything on it is absolutely delicious! Should be good for 2 people, or 3 if you don't eat much.Have also had the stuffed pied de cochon w/ foie gras and foie gras hamburger.  Both are very good and flavorful! Fyi, I cannot understand the reviews that complain about the food being heavy...where did you think you were eating?? lol. The food is heavy, it is rich, it is delicious! If thats what your going for- come here. The vegans expecting a light dinner, um don't? lol.Also, the service is super great. I remember a couple visits ago I dropped my butter knife, I saw a waiter approach me so I turned my head, in a matter of seconds of dropping that thing, one waiter replaced my knife and another picked the one I dropped off the floor!! I was like :O :O :O what is this crazy attentive service I am experiencing?? So awesome! All the peeps that have served us there have been very friendly, on top of service, given full descriptions of what we're interested in ordering, just fantastic!Also, really love the vibe, its loud and fun, love the open kitchen, gives you something to look at. Last time we were there Emeril popped in for dinner and I just thought "Yup, this place is the shizz!"Great restaurant, always leave feeling super full and satisfied! :)

An experience you must have. First the selection of foods i was lost as i did not know what to have. The ambience is relaxed, dynamic and all about food. The open cuisine give you a peek of what to expect. I am a person that experience food visually first ,when that is satisfied the taste buds come in hand . We were 3 persons , waited in line to get seated ( reservation is a must especially at night) , the waitress was very pleasant and professional helped us get our selection in order. We shared the bison temaki, the salad and bison tongue all tasty and very well presented. I took the foie gras burger, what a taste !! simply delicious but gigantic . One of my friends took the Duck in a Can ; definitely my pick for next visit. We shared different selection of deserts , my favourite was the tarte au sucre. Wine selection is good but prices are on the higher end;  with such a culinary experience a good wine or a beer will complement the dishes. One of my best places in Montreal.  Will definitely return and i highly recommend it.

Does another review make a difference at this point? There's so many! But def go check this place out if you're in Montreal. Hubby and I still talk about the duck after almost 2 years of being there! Must get the duck from the can. I need to go back just for that.

Hands down Au Pied de Cochon has the poutine way better than any of the popularly voted poutine places, and Au Pied is not even "just a poutine" place.Each ingredient here is made properly and there's balance and harmony in the taste when every ingredient come together.  Nothing too salty, nothing too greasy, nothing too dry, nothing too uneven in the texture (it happens with some of the popular poutine places where they put two or three big chucks of cheese curd in and the rest of the cheese bits are like over-crumbled feta).  I had the version with foie gras added, but it would be still heavenly without it.

Amazing everything. Service was efficient, courteous, and attentive (immediately refilled our bread when they saw that we had extra food gras terrine, which was awesome). The food was everything that people say it is. I suggest ordering as much foie gras as possible, but don't eat anything for a few days afterwards.What we ordered: duck carpaccio, foie gras terrine, foie gras poutine and the pied du cochon.

Ah, the house of the pig. Had this place bookmarked for years after all of the notoriety surrounding it. Ended up getting a last-second reservation around 10 on a Friday. Felt very lucky. Had the cromesquis (small fried foie gras conduits)-- which were delicious, the foie gras burger, cooked medium rare, which was the most flavorful burger I've ever had. The foie gras pizza-- delicious, fatty, and so greasy, loved it, as well as the duck fat fries. Opted to skip the duck in a can (just didn't find it exciting), but we left thoroughly satisfied. Casual, friendly, fast service with delicious food that wasn't super expensive. I felt like I had a very expensive meal but split between two of us it was $43 CAD each after tax and tip. You should check it out if in town-- only note that the bar is NOT open seating on the weekends.

PDC is one of the best restaurants I think I've ever eaten at. The dishes are extremely rich, but everything we ordered was fantastic. We split the foie gras cromesquis and white ham appetizers; we are big charcuterie people and the ham with browned butter was decadent. The cromesquis was a great little taste of foie gras for us as we don't frequently eat it; it's so rich. For entrees, he had the veal chop and I had the duck in a can. My food was fantastic aside from the 100g foie gras I struggled to finish! The veal chop was delicious but a bit salty. The playing of the food is lovely and everything is so complimentary - vegetables, sauces etc. but it is rich. For dessert we split the maple creme brûlée, which was incredible. The house beer was a great compliment to the meal, and we also ordered a cappucino at dessert that was served with a tiny carafe of real maple syrup. The homemade bread is delicious. We had a very nice table facing the kitchen, and loved the atmosphere - it's a nicer restaurant but not stuffy at all. Overall this was a splurge (both in terms of money and waistlines!) but a really unique and lovely experience.

We were here on a Friday night and we were one of the first to arrive as soon as their dinner service started. We had the foie gras croquettes which we loved. It had a warm melted foie gras concuction inside a crisp outer shell. Delicious! I had the Ploque a Champlain which was an appetizer that i had as my main course. It was buckwheat pancake, ham, cheese, foie gras drizzled with maple syrup. I was very disappointed as it was coyingly sweet for me. It was drowning in sweet sauce and the pancake soaked even more of the sweet syrup. I had to ask for a separate plate to transfer my food away from the pool of sauce. Looking back I should've complained. My husband had the halibut with scallops which was good but also drowning in sauce. We had a drink each and no dessert and our bill with tip was around $150. The experience wasn't great for me that night....there was too much noise... servers rushed here and there. It felt chaotic even with a few diners at the beginning of service.
