Came for the dessert. I ordered the pecan pie with a serving of their homemade grilled bread ice cream. It took a while to come out but it was like they had made it fresh. This dessert was more than expected as they give you a mini pie and not just a slice. It was sweet and super decadent; I recommend sharing the desserts!

My second time to Au Pied de Cochon and by far one  of my favourite restuarants in Montreal.  In fact, it might be one of my favourite restaurants of all time.  You have to make sure you make your reservations early.  I made mine a few months in advance.In a nutshell there is amazing Fois Gras and amazing Cochon, which is pig by the way.  My partner and I started with the Fois Gras appetizer which was the special.  Essentially it was Fois with cheese, blueberries and Sugar Shack maple syrup.  Probably the best thing I've ever had to eat.I'll let my pictures do the talking but I highly suggest you make a reservation here.

Sausage in a brioche, with foie gras sauce and grilled asparagusOreilles de crisse with Ranch saucePoutine Foie grasDr Pepper w/ maple syrup.The sausage was wonderful and the brioche was a nice change from your standard buns. The grilled asparagus was perfectly cooked but there was some stringiness that made cutting though it a bit of a sport. This caused a bit of a structural failure that made eating the sandwich a fun and messy affair. The poutine was too salty for my taste, there being even a bit of salt burn on the tongue. The foie gras on the poutine however was a brilliant and soft counterpoint to the saltiness, as was the hyper-sweetened soft drink. The Oreilles de Crisse were light and crunchy so texturally they were fun but again it was another experience in "too much". Deep fried fat will tend to do that.I don't know if I want to fall asleep or just curl up in a corner and have myself a heart attack. 4 stars. Would do this again.

They were parked just by Place du Canada at around lunchtime. The truck itself is pretty cute with 2 pick-up counters - one for sweets and one for savoury food. Because the weather was a little poor, there was virtually no lineup. I ordered a beignet with haddock and homemade tartar sauce inside for $7. The beignet itself was definitely very cool and just something different, but the tartar sauce wasn't impressive and had a bit too much onions in it, for my liking. The sandwich itself was very juicy and well portioned - a good size (and good price) for a lunch. I'd probably stick to some of their more well-known dishes, for example the foie gras poutine or their sweets as a safer option.

It's hard to miss this spot when in Montreal. My husband and I kicked off our mini moon at Au Pied with a 9pm ressie. You should make a res, they seat as right away.  Service was very polite and helpful - we ordered the house beer (good) and a Pinot noir like French wines. Everything is french, including the wines so I had to get used to some unfamiliar names. But we had great service and recommendations all the way.We ordered the ham plate (plain) to start which has a yummy maple glaze atop, came with yummy french bread.  Definitely order this. We moved onto the pig foot for a main - this was really good. It was fatty, and fried but meaty at the same time.  The base sauce for so much of French Canadian food is like a beefy, brown French onion soup - and that was kind of what this was like.  Came with hearty vegetables, and mashed potato. We also had the famous duck in a can. I'm sorry to say but I didn't love this, I guess we also don't love foie gras and everything about the foie here is one big slab. It's Better I feel when simmered into a sauce. Anyway, while the cooking technique of sous vide duck breast with hearty vegetables and potato in a can is fun to watch and interested, can't say I loved the taste. The duck was rare though and done on point.We had a side of duck fat fries which were just ok. Didn't taste much of the duck fat but hey fries were always good. We were too full for dessert but looks like they do some good milkshake and ice cream. Definitely can't miss it when dining in Montreal, it's a staple. It wasn't our favorite as I overall felt the food was a bit one note but it's definitely a fun experience - they know what they're doing.

3 words: fantastic, creative, and enjoyable.A girl on the rideshare which I was taking from ottawa to montreal told me about this restaurant and insisted that I would have to try it. And I did go there with my buddy in Montreal, who was also first time going to this place. He was in the restaurant business and has been manager for several well known brands in the area. So he had high standard when it comes to fine food. After the dinner, he simply said "amazing" and that what it meant happiness to him.For me, I ordered "duck in a can" and IT WAS AN ART. Very creative dish, from the way it was prepared, cooked, and served to the way it tastes. Simply amazing dish. I also had the squid ink poutine for the appetizer and that was yummy as well, although not as unique as the duck in a can (well, not many dishes in the world would be that unique anyways).If I'm going to rate this restaurant based on the Michelin star standards for the food quality (yeah and I mean the food quality only, screw the formality criteria), this place would be "4" stars.One advice when you go there though:  if you are not going in a big group, sit at the bar. You will be able to see the whole crew in the kitchen preparing the food. And that is very entertaining to watch.

If you are in the mood for a gluttonous meal, Au Pied de Cochon fits the bill.  I think that I knocked several years off my life here.  We were a group of 11 and they handled us well.  I think we went through 11 bottles of wine and this on the heels of drinking rather heavily before.I would describe the meal if I could, but I sort of was in a meat/wine/beer coma throughout.  Everything we ate was rich.  The duck in a can was a freaking duck in a can.The place is lively and you will be packed into a tight seat.  Deal with it.

Given all the hype surrounding this place, I was stoked to tuck into a gluttonous meal with my family and slowly waddle home satisfied and overstuffed with pork products but was frankly disappointed. Having made a reservation weeks in advance, we were disappointed to find our table stuck in the furthest darkest back corner of the restaurant underneath a freezing cold air vent. To start we ordered a charcuterie plate which was delicious with thin cuts of house-cured meats spectacularly draped over a pig's skull but the rest of the meal was kinda lousy. I ordered the infamous duck in a can with foie gras, thyme, and cabbage. The duck was tough, the foie gras gelatinous, and the overall dish just a one-note fat-flavoured slop. My boyfriend ordered the foie gras burger which he described as being just a very regular burger, the best thing about it being the in-season tomatoes on top. Our server also goaded him into getting an order of fries to accompany an already mammoth meal that no one ended up eating. My parents both ordered seasonal specials which they both enjoyed, but not enough to justify the price tag. Beyond that my Dad's dish arrived a good 10 minutes after everyone else's which made for a brief bit of awkwardness as we started our meal. What was supposed to be the one fancy night out for my out-of-town parents ended up being a bit of a bummer. It feels like with all the fame that the restaurant has received they've become a bit uninspired when it comes to churning out their greatest hits but put more effort into their specials that allow for less gimmick and more culinary creativity. As predicted, I did end up waddling home with a full belly but ended up totally disappointed and would not recommend Au Pied de Cochon.

I was worried that this place would be hype only, but was so wrong. We got Duck in a Can, Foie gras poutine and their namesake, Au Pied de Cochon, and each one was excellent. Of course, I didn't anticipate just how large the portions were.  Seriously. They could feed a small country. Or at least,  a party of 5 and not 2.Such deliciousness!! They were super generous with the fois gras, duck was tender, pork incredibly tender. Had to takeaway most of the Pied de Cochon but even cold.... Was amazeballs!!

Foie Gras overload. Wow. Crazy decadent rich meal. This place was packed with a line out the door. It has a nice vibe (definitely not "fine dining" but more hip gastropub) and the waitstaff were really nice and took time to give us specials, answer questions about the menu, and give us reccs. The food was pretty good but definitely a little on the rich side. We had the foie poutine (delicious) as well as the buckwheat pancake with bacon/foie/maple syrup appetizer which was also delicious. Folks at my table went with the special tuna which was pretty good. I went with the duck in a can. I dunno if I was foie'd out at that point but it was a bit too rich and not quite as tender as I thought it would be. That being said, the flavor was good and the presentation fun. All in all, a good experience but I'd probably try out a lot more restaurants in Montreal before coming back. Also, while I don't think it is necessarily overpriced (good portion sizes and high quality ingredients in unique food) it also isn't cheap or one of those places you come out thinking "wow, that was such a good value." So yeah, overall, probably closer to 3.5 than 4 stars for me. That being said, I'm looking forward to eating my leftover Foie once I recover...

This was the best meal of my life. To start with our server Greg was amazing. Patient in helping us create a meal, attentive, witty, and even did a shot of brandy with us to celebrate our honeymoon. The place is perfect in its feel: come as you are, and be prepared to eat unabashedly rich and descendent food made with love and attention to detail.Our fois on a buckwheat pancake with chèvre and corn immediately blew our minds. The canned duck was the star of the evening, with a pairing of flavors I could not even begin to describe to do it justice. Savory, sweet, acid, age and lots of delicious fat.All of the food is rich to be sure. Don't expect to walk away feeling light and fresh. But if you want eat at a place where the program is centered around good food, good people, good wine, and good music, you cannot beat Au pied.

I genuinely cannot understand how this place has the ratings and high acclaim that it does. The treatment we received from the hostess and servers was simply atrocious. After hearing the high acclaim and a positive recommendation from friends who had eaten here the night before - we were thrilled to dine at Au Pied de Cochon the following night. We made the reservation weeks in advance at the only available time - 10:30pm. We decided to show up a little earlier in hopes we could be seated prior to 10:30. We approached the hostess stand and proceeded to wait there approximately 10 minutes until a hostess showed up and acknowledged us. We gave her our name and reservation information and we were told we could not be seated until 10:30. I completely understand that. We asked if we could get a drink from the bar while we waited. The answer was no. The reason? People are eating at the bar and we can't go get a drink". So we had to go wait outside. We were sure to stand where the hostess would see us to ensure we wouldn't be missed when it was our turn to be seated. After waiting through the rain outside, the time passed 10:30pm. It was extremely frustrating to see people walking right up to the restaurant and being seated right away AFTER our reservation time. After seeing this, we approached the hostess again to find out what was going on. She looked up at us and greeted us as brand new customers, acting as if she had never seen us before. We had to provide her with our name and reservation information again for her to cross-check. Without any regret or apologies, we were finally seated. The table was directly in a walk way and it didn't take me long to realize the ceiling was leaking and I was being dripped on throughout the entire meal. Especially fun after waiting in the rain for so long. We were ignored by wait staff for another 10 minutes prior to a server finally engaging us. Our friends who had dined there the night before told us their waiter was fabulous at explaining the menu and making suggestions so we asked the same of ours. He provided no such help. We were rushed into making some sort of selection. This was the last time the server came to our table. Somebody else delivered our food. We had to ask for silverware. The fries included in the poutine tasted old and for the amount given - was not worth the price at all. The duck in a can was overly rich. I had a few bites and called it a day. I was already so frustrated we were giving this establishment any of our money. If I could do it again, I would have left after the hostess fiasco. We were hoping the food would redeem the service. It did not. A third person came by to process our payment. When she asked how everything was I had a really hard time crafting a response for that. We told her we weren't impressed. She said sorry and got us on our way. I'm having trouble determining why our experience was SO terrible when the reviews for this place are so high. What is it about us?! It appeared people around us were receiving good service and so had our friends the night before. Must be something about me. Horrible.

We were told by a few folks from the area to make a reservation here weeks in advance, and glad we did so. The food was quite good and it was very busy. Service was a bit slow, and the place is expensive but you should come here and check it out.We got a charcuterie platter, the tuna tartar special, and duck in a can. The tuna was awesome, charcuterie was great, and the duck was amazing. We didn't love the pig brain but everything else on the platter was delicious. The duck was great, that is a must if you come here. And they serve hot bread which is quite tasty.Worth making a reservation well in advance.

A punch of flavors in my mouth! We feasted on foie gras poutine, duck two ways, and the namesake dish, pied de cochon with foie gras -- it was nothing less than decadent. Service was excellent and attentive, even in an extremely busy environment. I would highly recommend getting seats in front of the kitchen for all the action.

I would recommend going with people so you can order more.My hungover eyes ordered more than I could eat.Skip the APC beer because it's a lame adjunct lager. Order anything else.The little foie croquettes are a fun experience of exploding liquid foie in your mouth. The pickled tongue I could have passed on.The French onion soup is classic, although with chunk of pork fat inside.The pork chop special was killer with the most wonderful and colorful tomatoes surrounding the dish.The duck fat fries were decent, although if I came with people, I would make them foie poutine or regular poutine fries.There was no wait for myself on a Friday night. The waiter was extremely kind. He was humble about his English, but I understood him perfectly.A fine meal. I ordered too much and paid about $70. I think a person can reasonably spend $50-60.

It's hard to get a table, so I strong advise to book in advance.We are from Toronto and for table of 3, booked 2 weeks in advance and we were seated without much wait.Pros1) excellent service2) wine list is great, and the server knows a lot about wine pairingCons1) pretty crowded, wish we could be seated more comfortably

So if you love foie gras, this place would probably be your heaven.  I did like the foie gras cromesquis and mashed potatoes.  However, I found the rest of the dishes to be very, very oily.  The duck in a can was a fun concept, but way too heavy for our liking.  We also thought the chicken burger was fun since it came to us in a fast food paper box, but again, it was so oily that the paper surrounding the sandwich was soaked through.  Biggest mistake was I ordered the fish n chips b/c I'm not the foie gras fan--my husband is.  I blame myself.  Why would anyone get fish n chips at a Canadian French restaurant that focuses on foie gras and meat? The sturgeon was so fishy, I couldn't even finish it.  They were really nice about it though and let us replace the fish with something else on the menu.

My oh my! Dinner at Au Pied de Cochon was one of the tastiest meals I've had in awhile. Their house dish, Pied de Cochon was spectacular! The skin of the roasted pork underneath that gravy... Superb! It was so delicious and the flavors really complex. French Onion soup is a must here as well as the Apple, Bleu cheese & Endive salad. The soup was well made - not overly salty and made from scratch (the way it should be). We added 100g foie gras which elevated the dish to another level of decadence!Foie Poutine was the dish to catch my attention on Yelp. But unfortunately, it was the most forgettable dish of the night - What Poutine? Another dish that fell short from hitting the mark was Duck in a Can. My gosh, this dish was super salty! Aside from the saltiness, I just don't remember anything about the Duck in a Can. There is a cocktail made with fresh squeezed orange juice - get it! This drink was the most amazing cocktail I've ever had. Service here is great :) Very friendly staff that is attentive, talkative but not overbearing.

I have been dying to go here for literally years and it was everything I had hyped it up to be and more. The service was extremely good and our waiter's recommendations were given heavy weight when it came down to order from this overwhelmingly awesome menu.We started with the plogue a Champlain--an amazing sweet and salty blend of I still don't know what. Next up, one of the specials of the day, aged prosciutto which was particularly fatty and delicious. And for the main course, duck in a can with a side of duck fat fries. If my arteries clogged today (which they might), I will still die happy.

It almost seems unnecessary to review this restaurant because it is has such a high caliber of food, and the dining experience is wonderful. I think it doesn't matter what you order it'll be more than satisfying. I had a "wow" experience as I ate the dish named after the restaurant - Au Pied de Cochon. It consisted of pig's food perfectly cooked in a heavy savory sauce with mushrooms, foie gras and mashed potatoes. The first bite was the absolute best. I couldn't believe how good it tasted. This meal is best shared with someone as it is heavy and too much for one patron. In addition to the food, I had a blueberry mojito made with the restaurant's own gin...very refreshing and tasty. They also have a nice wine list if you want it by the glass or bottle. Be ready to pay for what you are getting; it's worth it. The people working there are also extremely accommodating & friendly. Overall, it's a fantastic dining experience.

Must do when in Montreal. Have been here a few times and food is consistent with great service.  We probably have tried everything on the menu and nothing I wouldn't recommend.  Has gotten a bit more touristy that last few years.

Oh my.. Ok, so I've been recommending APCD to anyone that'll listen to me without having being able to go myself.  For the most part, everyone's thanked me for it.Sooo finally I managed to make it, and it was all I hoped it'd be.Unpretentious yummy meaty food.Even though everyone favours the Lamb Shank, I had to go with duck margret, just because it is one of my favourite meats.As much as I wanted to add a piece of foie gras to the poutine, I couldn't do it.  I only wanted a mild heart attack, not a massive stroke.The bread.. oh geeze.. I consumed several loafs, and was just completely content with taking it and dipping it in the duck sauce (Barbara Streisand).All in all.. Yum.

I rarely give fives but this place is deserving of it.You can tell immediately the head chef or owner takes great pride in this place and it shows. He proudly offered us a tasting menu which and house made brandy which was delicious. The portions are generous and rich. Among my favorites was the pork chop with shrimp and salmon tartar on a pastry. Highly recommend this place as it is one of the best restaurants I have ever been. The pride in quality shows.

Indulgence and excess of the highest order is how I'll remember my night at APDC. This was a meal to end all meals. We had reservations for 8:00 pm on a Wednesday and I almost wish we hadn't eaten anything the whole day. We knew we were in for a night of unrivaled gluttony the moment we walked in, smelled the food and noticed the huge portions sizes on some of the plates.We wanted to start off with something kind of light (by APDC's standards) and got the blue cheese salad,  a sizable plate that came with endives and chunks of blue cheese.  I tried not to use too much cheese on the bread they had given us when we sat down but their fresh bread was addictive and helped balance out the strong cheese.The second dish was one of the specials on the night - baked clam with cheese sauce. I have a hard time stopping myself from trying clams whenever it's on the menu, especially at a place like this when I knew they would prepare it in a way I've never had before. It didn't disappoint. As heavy as the sauce was, the flavors were well balanced and even though each bite was probably a hundred calories, I couldn't help myself from mopping up some of the sauce with more bread.We were already getting full so when informed that our Pied de Cochon with foie gras was going to take a bit of time to come out, we were glad.  When it finally arrived, any delusions we had of trying the duck in a can afterwards quickly disappeared. It's as if French gastronomy took a look in the mirror, didn't like what it saw, and decided to get juiced. All I could do at first was look at the huge portion size of the dish and then feel intimidated by the size of the foie gras sitting on top of the pile of pig knuckles, chunks of pork and onions . Somehow after an hour of battling this dish, aided on by 3 shots of single malt Scotch, we emerged victorious. The only thing I lost in the process was my dignity.APDC is not the place to come and hold back. This place is a weight watcher's worst nightmare... but sometimes it's good to be bad and if you are thinking of going all out,  there's every reason for you to come here.

I went with a southern French person to this restaurant but he did not completely agree with my assessment. Just a caveat. :-)We really wanted to try a Montreal special, as this place is very well known. This place has the famous foie gras poutine and Duck in a Can. We decided to all share to try a few more dishes. The baguette is good!The ambience is nice. We went right when it opened and there was a small line waiting. You cannot get seated if you have not made a reservation. Plan ahead. 1. Garden salad: not on the menu, but we figured we were having so many animal parts this was probably a good idea. $15 for generic salad. The salad was fresh but basic. 2. Mushroom risotto: this dish is very expensive for what it is, but you get a show. They come to your table with a large cheese bowl and add the risotto, mushroom, and even Canadian bacon. This dish had potential but was much too salty. It was hard to finish. 3. Terragon Bison tongue: this is tongue well done. The texture is very soft, which is impressive given the quality of most tongues. The sauces and everything just work well together. However, it's game-y so just be warned. 4. Foie gras poutine: loved it. The fries were good. The gravy was also good. The foie gras was in large blocks and was nice and fatty. I think if you come here, you should get this dish! 5. Duck in a Can: I loved watching them pour half a duck out of a can. Life experience. It even looked nice coming out. The duck came out as a thick filet attached to a flap of lard and also fatty liver (foie gras). I enjoyed this dish very much. It was over puréed cauliflower. The issue I had was that the duck meat was very thick. I had to eat it with slices of the lard to complement the taste. Overall a good dish. 6. Dessert: we got the maple cake and the lemon pie. Both were pretty good. Get the maple cake for novelty sake! Very sweet but good flavors. It was a pricy meal, but for a specialty restaurant it made sense.

This is not a spot for a romantic night out with your honey as it's fabulously busy with an open kitchen, dynamic wait staff and full of people. Every dish was huge so plan to share. We ordered the charcuterie and the prosciutto was unbelievable and the chorizo was fantastic. The asparagus with morel mushrooms is delish. My honey ordered the steak that was served with a massive morel stuffed with foie gras on a bed of mashed potato. My pork chop was WAY too big for me but the flavor was delish. My honey also enjoyed the lemon meringue tart (he mentioned it was unusual with a flaky/crunchy base). We watched some incredible meals being delivered. The duck in a can sounded weird to me but so many people ordered it and were raving about how delicious it was. The owner was actively walking around, greeting guests, chatting to staff and made us feel welcome. When you make your reservation, specifically ask for a table, we were initially seated at the bar (which I normally love) however my honey kept getting knocked by the staff and guests. We requested a move to a table and the hostess very reluctantly agreed and was quite snooty about it so that was the only drawback of this fabulous spot.
My favorite place to eat anywhere. I make the journey here at least once a year and this is always a highlight. My pics are horrible but food is great.

This place is part of my top 5 places to go in Montreal! (Visit my page to read my other top 5 reviews!)Oh my god. Oh my god. Oh my god! This is probably one of the best places in Montreal. I started with the Foei Gras poutine and it is absolutely delicious. The flavors are rich and savoury. It is a bit expensive, but the portions are quite generous.The next dish I got was Pied de Cochon farci au Foei Gras, which is Pig's feet stuffed with duck liver. You cant go wrong stuffing things with duck liver! Similar to every other dish, it was so rich, juicy and flavorful.  Really great experience. Strongly recommend!

Called here to make a reservation and glad we did because this place was packed and now I see why. The foie gras here is better than Daniel's in NYC and reasonably priced as well. So here's what we've tried: We were going to try the Poutine au foie gras for appetizer like everyone else, but our waiter highly recommended the Plogue à Champlain, claiming that it is his absolute favorite dish so we had to try that instead. And....it was AMAZING! In simple terms, the Plogue à Champlain is a combo of buckwheat pancake, potato,  fle-aux-grues cheddar, fried egg, thick cut Canadian bacon and foie gras covered in a maple syrup. Super rich and flavorful, and the foie gras itself just melts in your mouth. Unforgettably delicious. For main courses, I ordered the Duck in a Can, and my husband had the Catch of the Day, which was their tuna steak. The Duck in a Can was unique and unlike anything I've tried before (the can was opened right at table side and contents flipped/poured on top of veggie puree). The foie gras and duck meat were even a little bloody looking on some parts, but the waiter guaranteed that everything is cooked (super cooked) in 200+ degree temperature. I don't know, I probably wouldn't be ordering that again. Don't get me wrong, the duck meat itself was tasty, but the veggie puree/sauce was too salty and the foie gras was too bloody looking for me. As for the tuna steak, the husband said it was very good. Unfortunately, I couldn't try since it was raw, only seared on the sides and raw fish is definitely not for pregos. To be honest, I shouldn't even be eating foie gras, but I could not resist so let's just pretend that's ok. Anyway, I did not find their desserts interesting, so skipped dessert here. Oh and did I forget to mention that I had lots of their house bread? Their house bread (baguette) was so good, coupled with the soft butter. I was very satisfied since I walked in starving. PS: Overall, the foie gras was top notch. I was also impressed with their service; the bread was refilled when down to 1 slice. Water glass was never left empty. Super knowledgeable waiter who wasn't afraid of being adamant about certain dishes when asked for his opinion. Definitely worth a try if in the area, enjoy~

My expectations were surpassed more than I could have imagined.  I'm not a huge fan of poutine but their Foie Gras Poutine was delicious.  They had a decent amount of foie gras in the poutine and the gravy that covered everything was amazing.Many recommended the Duck in a Can, so I ordered without really knowing what to expect.  Everything is cooked in a can and then opened in front of you.  After transporting the contents on to a plate, there lies a perfectly cooked piece of duck, a lot of fat, and a huge portion of foie gras.  The duck and foie gras together was a beautiful marriage in each bite.

This is a tough call.  I know that lots of people really like this place.  While I did, I can't say that I get all the hype.  But if you want to experience something different, then give this a try - that is why I did.  The foie gras crommets (little balls) were ok.  I ate one, but only sucked the insides out of the second.  I ordered the pied do cochon - it was enough for three people.  Loved the foie gras served on top.  The meat was tender, the sauce was very good too.  Quite pricey.  Here is the deal - if you have a spouse or girlfriend who are trying to eat health - don't waste your money here.  There is zero here for them.  Come with a bunch of hungry people and prepare to indulge and be unhealthy.

You know, this may have been the biggest disappointments of my Montreal trip, not because it's terrible but because it simply did not live up to the hype. 4.5*? Not at all, in my experience. The positives: The free bread was incredible, the portion sizes were beyond generous, and the prices were very reasonable.The negatives: Everything was too rich (it's hard for me to frame this as a negative but when you start eating the food, you realize it's just too heavy). The $22 "Pied de Cochon" came with the richest mashed potatoes and fried thing on top and very hearty sauce underneath. The huge piece of meat would've been enough for dinner for a family. It felt like a chore to eat it because on the one hand, I didn't want to be wasteful but on the other hand, how could anyone eat something so heavy?I'm clearly in the minority here but it just wasn't an enjoyable experience.

Wow... Buckle up kids. I'm gonna let you sit front seat for a journey through the worst service I've EVER had. From start to finish. Tighten up. Preface: I own a small wholesale pasta company in California. (It costs me more to run than I make) I'm not bragging. I make my paycheck working 50-60 hours a week in another restaurant. I take a lot of pride in my work there as a pastry chef. I don't make a lot of money. I DO invest heavily on where I spend it. And here I am. In Montreal. The most beautiful and fantastic city I've ever been to. (Seriously... Well done civil engineers)I call a month before my trip. (For my 30th birthday) and instead of calling the number I left on the answering machine, they call the number I  used to make the call which was the restaurant I work at. After a frustrating (although hilarious) interaction of two different restaurant hostesses not knowing they're taking to anther restaurant. I confirmed my reservation. So we arrived. 15 minutes to spare. Thank you Opus card. "Bonjour, avez-vous une réservation" "Oui," I said with fear. (Knowing there would be a follow up question in French and I just exhausted the extent of my French vocabularie. Why couldn't she have started in Spanish. I would have had a chance then.)Well, now I've been outed. No problem she speak very good English. And... It turns out I don't have a [recorded] reservation... B-effing-S. 20 minute wait. Well I've already come across the continent, I'll just be patient.Boom. We're sat. We got a beer and a wine, and we order a couple things to start.  Then she returns to finish our order and we order Au Pied de Coichon with foie. First, Bison Tongue comes. Done. Fantastic. Second, Dumplings come. 6 for 12$, or 12 for 24$. I got twice as many as I ordered but I understand the mix up. Maybe my fault maybe hers. But we can split the difference. They were fantastic.And now comes the main event....Any minute now.................. (sigh)......... She returns...She notified us it'll be here shortly 10-15 minutes. (The seed of frustration has be planted.)"What?!" I look around and think to myself, "I was here well before that 4 top over there was even sat. And they've got multiple courses. They're all happily eating their main entrees. And this two top directly next to me was sat at least 30 minutes behind me and they're almost done." (My frustration seed is budding with impatience.)After an excruciating period of being ignored by our server. She was really good at that. We'll call her Matthrine with a C. I stop her and ask her very politely. "Will our food be much longer?"She "promises" it'll be "right out" whatever that means. 45 f@$k!4G minutes later we get our 1 entree. The manager himself dropped it off. He rectified, "I'm sorry for the wait. (Blah Blah) I'll take care of this." I smile. I literally don't want this. I didn't want this a while ago. I would have gladly shot this dying horse 30 minutes ago and just parted ways. But no. You ignored me and "tried" to make it right. Now we're all in this mess together.The pig foot is here, just eat. Thank god. At least the kitchen is worth the hype. Well done. So now here we are. I'm done. I've given up. I'm exhausted. I literally have to pay more money than it's worth to be as angry as I am right now. So I ask for a check. And a new problem. Our server informs us she was going to send out a dessert. I felt confused. I've never been in a place where I wanted to refuse a free dessert. I just want to go back to my hotel room and conclude my birthday on or around the toilet like I do every year. She walks away.Well, I grabbed her attention seconds after that exchange and just ask for it to go. She insisted mind you. The expression on her face says that's somehow a problem. She brings us two glasses of something I can only describe as the syrupy excrement of an apple tree. And the bill... Full price. Apparently they charged me for the time I sat there waiting for my food.  F-you. Here's your cash. Here's the generous 12% shit tip you didn't even earn. We leave. I cool off. I get to the hotel. I lie down. Hooray I'm 30 and should have gone somewhere else for my birthday. [Pity party]Two hours later. I wipe my tears away. After all, I'm an adult now. "Maybe a free dessert will cheer you up." I take a bite. It's undercooked I think... Maybe that's intentional. I take another bite, it awfully bitter. I flip it over and the bottom is burnt. Like Cajun salmon. Black. "Custard" or whatever that was filed with runs out like syrup. It's a tart shell with a half inch of chocolate glaze? Anyways... I spent the rest of my night here. On yelp. Hoping someone fires you. Thanks for the classic 'bait and switch...'I'm apparently missing something here. Fml.
Pretty cool place! A touch over rated!

If you are looking for a french restaurant with a Québécois twist--- Au Pied de Cochon is the place to be.  You also need to be a meat eater as this restaurant is not vegetarian friendly.  I made my reservation for 10:30PM the night after Xmas as that was the only thing available.  If you want to make a reservation, do so by email as no one ever picks up the phone.  Photos is the best thing to do here.  Portions are ginormous and everything is super heavy.  Main dishes are best shared, anything for 2 is really good for 3 or even 4.  I had the Stuffed PDC w/ Foie Gras and I couldn't even get through a quarter of it myself.  Do yourself a favor and skip breakfast AND lunch before you come here for dinner.  I'm not even kidding.Ordering apps is a great way to lighten the main dishes load and try more of the menu.  The duck fat fries and cod fritters come served in a cone made from pages out of Martin Picard's award winning cookbook.  I wiped them down and saved them-- hoping that one day I'll attempt to make some Mille Feuille.  Tomato tart tastes like a personal pizza, the foie gras in the croquette is in liquid form so that was interesting.  I forgot to order the boudin tart!  =/If you love foie gras, it's very easy to get trigger happy here.  There are 9 dishes w/ foie gras!  The foie gras croquette was bite sized and a cheap thrill @ $3.50 a bite.  I felt it was unnecessary with my stuffed PDC, too indulgent with the poutine, slimy and odd with the duck in a can, etc.  Nonetheless-- it's tough to find foie gras on any menu in NY, never mind this many options and at such reasonable prices.  So take a dive and see what you think.Duck in a can is worth the hype.  It's a generous portion and we found it to be quite the spectacle.  Still amazes me how everything is cooked perfectly coming out of the can but it was and that duck breast is to die for.  PDC it's the name plastered on the walls so I had to try it.  Best when shared in a group of 3 or more.  Be patient as it takes 45 mins to prep.  It's really not pigs foots, more so the pigs leg that you are eating.  It's a big serving.  The skin has a light crisp straight out of the broiler but the meat and tendons have a soft, waxy texture from it being cooked just right.  It's served on a bed of mashed potatoes and marinated champignons.  The tough decision at the end is whether or not to box the leftovers.  I passed on it as I think I've reached my pigs foot limit for the year.  Hard to do but try to make room for dessert.  Everyone praises the sugar pie and such but I had no room left at the end.

What an experience! I had to make a reservation a whole month in advance in order to get a dinner reservation at a reasonable time on a Friday, and even so was only promised bar seats. When we got to the restaurant, a fortunate turn of events meant that we got to sit at a table.Service seemed really rushed and hectic, but the food was entirely worth the three times our server walked us by without taking our orders. I tried the starter of apple foie gras, and the mains of duck and mushrooms and a bowl of potatoes and cured meats. The apple foie gras was beyond delicious.I would highly recommend making Au Pied de Cochon a pit stop if you are visiting Montreal.

After viewing Au Pied and the chef/owner on Anthony Bourdain's "No Reservations," my hubby and I chose to take a trip to Montreal with one main goal of dining at de Cochon. If you are a foodie, it is a MUST DO on your bucket list. Called before leaving the US to make reservations to sit at two of the five or so counter seats they have that overlooks the kitchen (were Tony sat). It was absolutely amazing to see how many fantastic plates were consistently handed out from such a tiny space. Watching the chefs true symphony of movements between one another was incredible. The food, ahhhh the food. So rich, inventive, highest quality ingredients. Husband had a foie gras burger. Thought it would be a burger with a slice of foie on top. Nope, Whole "patty" was foie. I had the terrine. Cannot find the words to experience the flavors and textures, other than to boldly say an orgasm in my mouth. Chatted with the chefs the whole time and even got to meet the owner/head chef toward the end of our meal. As a result we were offered several free tastings of other menu items including foie gras poutine and even little deep fried cubes of foie (yup, I know). (Another advantage of sitting at the bar.) For the first and only time in my life I experienced a true "food coma" is. No amount of vodka or walking could resurrect my foodie spirit from the depths of foie overdose, but ya know what?...I would do it again tomorrow. Next time I think I'll try the "duck in a can." Merci beaucoup!!!

similar hipster feel to my beloved Brooklyn Hood,  the food was no joke and the only thing beyond reminiscent to billyburg. The service was exemplary,  well deserving of the 30%tip.  Then there's the actual,  food,  no,  It deserves to be called cuisine.  The wild ... Worth the tracking and trappi g of this rustic yet exquisitely prepared meal. I'll be back for more than one dish next time.

The froie gras poutine is even more delicious than the reviews described. Fries are cooked perfectly, gravy is rich but not heavy, and the froie gras creamy, silky, and delicious. It was more than worth the mile walk through the snow!

DEHC - CUH - DEHNCE. Decadence. Eating at Au Pied de Cochon has been one of my best dining experiences. It's not cheap, but the environment is not stuffy. It's lively and cramped, and comfortably overwhelming. We sat at the bar and watched as the 10 chefs in the tiny kitchen worked in unison. It was entertaining as we waited an 1.5 hours for our pigs head. In between us and the pig's head, we had a few appetizers. The fried fois gras and carpaccio. The fois gras happily popped in our mouth. Finally, alas when our pigs head came out all eyes were on us. It was over-the-top. There was a half lobster in it somewhere. A gold foil delicately balanced on the dead pig's head cheek. A separate sauce was made to drizzle on the brains. Who knew the head contained all these marvelous textures of pork? AU PIED DE COCHON did. We washed it down with delicious local beer (Cheval Blanc) Expensive, but plus side was, being American it felt like the menu was 25% off. NOTE: THE BATHROOM IS COOOOL. It had one of those 1k toilets installed with the warmed seats, but not the kind of warmth when you know the person before you just took a dump. SIDE NOTE: I enjoyed this pig's head more than the pig's head at Cockscomb in San Francisco.

Over rated. Not worth the out of the city side trip.After all the rave reviews on Yelp, it was a complete let down. Mcdonalds would have been better. I left a 15% tip, but it wasn't for the food, but for the service.  The water guy was attentive. We ordered the Duck in a can, very little meat, lots of fat about 2/3 of it. The Fois Gras poutine as well was a disapointment. However, the only thing I finished was the appetizer, the duck carpaccio. The venu was significantly out of the way. For a tourist using the metro for transportation, which was about 15 min walk away, this was the biggest disappointment. The highlight of this excursion was a hammock attraction set up on rue saint-denis.

Everything you read.... Everything they said... It's all true. There isn't much more to say other than have an open mind, make reservations in advance, and pace yourself so there's room for dessert. We loved every single crumb and morsel. The bread and butter, the charcuterie drizzled with olive oil and maple syrup, the cocktails.... All were amazing. We had the artichoke ravioli which will probably not be on your menu as this was a special of the evening. We also had the 'shepards pie' or Paté chinoise. Wow. It was sooo rich, creamy, savory and even sweet with the creamy corn layer. The melted meat bits were perfectly seasoned. The creme brulee was crisply charred but not burned. I would drive another 5 hours for dinner there, that's how much I loved this restaurant.

There was a poutine à la foie gras and other meat products. Being a vegetarian, I can only review the beverages. The water but a bit overpriced,I would just to a fountain instead ....The water is the only thing I would want when I am on Mount Royal.  The camion au pied de Cochon  should take into consideration that it is mostly health conscious people that hang out at the mountain.  Mount Royal 3$ for water versus Central Park  1 $ ,water  me think not I will come again

This is only regarding the blueberry beignets. It was 1 for 2.50 or 6 for 10, thus we got 6.It was super duper sweet and tasted basically like any fast-food donut filled with blueberry jam. My dentist would not approve =(Wish they still had Foie Gras poutine... the guy said it may come back mid 2014...

Talk about a great dining experience. This place is a MUST VISIT. When looking at the menu one might think "why would I pay 44$ for duck in a can?" or " 39$ for a foie gras burger?"but trust me this place is worth every penny. If you are a visitor, or a local this place can't be beat! Love, love, love this place!

They don't waste anything... they serve every parts that could be eaten out of pigs. We went here for my birthday dinner and it was pretty interesting.We had pickles pig tongue, Bison tongue and blue cheese and Apple salad for appetizer. Pickled tongue was not my favorite but bison was pretty good. Loved the salad.I had the pork chop which was tender and delish, and my husband had a special dish which was pretty much was the pig's leg - pig knuckles, pig shank, meatballs with potatoes and some veggies on the side. It looked like a hearty dish and our French Canadian friend said he had this kind of dish at home growing up. Make sure to make a reservation. We called one month ahead and they gave us a choice of 5pm or 9pm... popular place. Worth trying at least once, I liked the casual ambiance, but very snug seating. Bathroom situation was odd for the size of the restaurant... one unisex stool with 3 faucet...?

For a place named for pig, we may have ordered the wrong stuff...but I am NOT sorry about that ONE bit! We got the lobster roll & small order of the fois gras poutine. Both were absolutely phenomenal. I don't use that word lightly folks. PHENOMENAL. The poutine was surprisingly not heavy, given what it is...fries, gravy, fois gras...It's a MUST try. I can't sum it up in words. The lobster roll was equally as remarkable. The bread was perfection, fresh, crispy just where it needed to be, buttery (I love the French and their butter obsession) and the lobster chunks were gigantic and fresh! There was fresh parsley in the lobster meat as well as something else that I can't quite put a finger on. The result was something truly unforgettable. Get a reservation. This place is busy around the clock for a reason & it's tiny. If I ever return to Montreal, this will be first on the list to revisit.

Drool*!Came here with some girls for one of our bachelorette night dinners out and had such a fun time! Wine, fois gras poutine (omg drool*), duck in a can, special crab salad, carpacciothe tartare, hand rolls and more that i can't even remember now..The food was so yummy! I cannot pick a favorite! Though actually my least favorite was duck in a can, but i'm glad we tried it! Was a cool experience :) The waitstaff was so nice and helpful, very patient and knowledgeable of the dishes and wines. The place get super busy and packed, but why wouldn't they?I would definitely come back when i'm in Montreal again!

Tried so many times to eat here.  Finally made a few months ago.  We were seated in the rear and right up against the wall-a little uncomfortable.  That was the only negative.  House beer was really good, I mean really good.  Onion soup was good but too much cheese for me.  I had duck in can which was very flavorful.  On top of the perfectly made mashed potatoes,  the duck juice tasted sinful.With so many great restaurants to try in Montreal, it will be while before I go back.  I really enjoyed the night and was not disappointed.

Wow!Great spot, fantastic food, wonderful service.We were going to do without appetizer but was told duck in a can takes 25 min so went with the tongue.  Very very good.Duck in a can was rich, flavorful without being greasy (which I'm not sure how that's feasible, maybe it's the quality of the ingredients?).  Definitely a must have.  Hubby got foie gras tart with blood sausage which is good.  But if you're looking for seared foie gras, that's not it.Finally, dessert.  We searched hard and found room!  Got the sugar pie with ice cream (so creamy but not heavy and soft...!) which was really good and lemon meringue pie which was good but just a tad sweet for my taste.  Really great spot!

Holy momma!! Food was amazing, service was excellent. Real French cuisine with a touch of everything. The foie gras with the maple syrup and bacon is a must try. I died eating it......twice. Will be coming back.

No wonder this place is the highest rated restaurant in Montreal on yelp and also world renowned.  It's on a small one way road off of rue st. Dennis with a bunch of small restaurants on it.  We were sat immediately by the hostess.  The waiter was very nice and took time with us about recommendations and the specials and was always coming by making sure everything was good and our wine glasses stayed full.First off we got bread and butter which was baked that day which was very tasty.  We decided to share a few appetizers.  We started with the foie gras cromisque  and duck carpaccio.  The duck had an egg yolk that blended perfect with the taste of duck, herbs and spices. Next we got the show stopper.... The foie gras poutine which was nothing short of spectacular.  All of the flavors combined perfectly.  If I could eat one thing for the rest of my life it would be that.  We also had foie gras tout nu which was also delicious.  My girlfriend and I thought we were still hungry so we got the gnocchi.  They prepared it table side mixing everything in a large cut out cheese wheel peeling off cheese while they mixed if was great.  We could not even finish this..... We were so stuffed.  Our clothes felt like they got a few sizes tighter and our waist lines a bit bigger we had to get dessert to go.  But a few hours later a pecan pie in bed was a perfect way to finish the night!Overall of the best meals I've had in my life.   A MUST GO TO in Montreal.  Will 100% be back.

What more can you say about this place that already wasn't said?  My friend and I were headed to Montreal for the weekend and managed to score reservations for Saturday night at 8:30pm.We were staying in the Plateau - Mont Royal area which was a 15 minute walk from our B&B.  The entryway to Au Pied de Cochon is a narrow and a bit tight to wait in since there's no waiting area and  it's too cold to wait outside. Saturday night was definitely packed and loud.  If a group of your party is waiting patiently for your table, the hostess will offer your party beers or glasses of wine.Since we were a party of 2, we opted for the bar to watch the action.  We started out with some cocktails that included maple syrup and since most of these dishes were decadent, my friend and I opted for plates to share.Based on the recommendation of our waitress, we started out with plogue à champlain which was smothered in maple syrup, topped with foie gras and cheese.  The plate was rich and sweet and for my taste buds, the perfect way to start a meal on a chilly evening.I recommended my friend try poutine and our waitress recommended it with foie gras but since we already had a dish, it would be overkill and just opted for the classic.The best dish was the PDC melting pot which was blood sausage, pork belly, and sausage in mash potatoes.  Between the cocktail, PDC melting pot and the plogue à champlain, this one of the first meals in a long time where I refused dessert!  There was definitely no room in my stomach and there's usually a reserve but after experiencing PDC, I am a total devotee of all things Martin Picard.

Amazing service, amazing food, amazing experience. So decadent. We had beef marrow to start and beef tongue. I had the canard in a can which is the funkiest presentation I have ever had at a restaurant. They literally open a can and dump out a fully cooked to perfection meal on your plate. So soooooo good.

This place was lovely with a wonderful staff and the food was great. We sat at the bar and were entertained by the waitresses/bartenders mixing up various drinks. One cocktail that caught my eye was the strawberry daiquiri, so I requested one for myself and it was delicious. These were the food items we ordered. I recommend all of them.1. The pig head that came with lobster over mash potatoes and carrots2. Cromesquis de foie gras3. Temaki Tartare

Must make reservations and a must try while in Montreal. Heard Anthony Bourdain was here for one of his episodes, and I'm glad I tried this. I love foie gras and theres a huge menu of foie gras items. Definitely order a few small items to share and an entree.1. Foie Gras Cromesquis - two small croquette's filled with foie gras. Eat it all in one bite and it bursts. 2. Duck Carpaccio - meat is very soft, loved it.3. Foie gras poutine - The gravy was so good, it was probably the best poutine dishes I've tried while visiting. They can do half orders too!4. Duck Magret in Mushroom Sauce - only ordered this because they were out of the Stuffed Pied de Cochon with Foie Gras =( Creme Brulee was good, but they burned the top. Overall great experience, but would of loved to have tried more items.

While dining at Au Pied, I asked the waiter if we had enough food. He said we had ordered too much. We hemmed and hawed, and finally decided to cut the zucchini blossoms. Tough decision, but probably necessary.When the crab salad came out, it had two zucchini blossoms on it.That's a really classy move. Made me love the place not only for its decadence, but also for great service. I'll tell anybody visiting Montreal to come here.

A very inappropriate place to keep a diet!  But oh so good!  We just watched a PBS show in our hotel before departing for APDC that said that fatty food was actually good for you!  Perfect timing!Since it was our first time, one of us had to have the Duck in a Can and while a little pricey compared to other dishes, it was excellent!  Amazed they got that much duck breast and froie gras in a tin can and cooked perfectly rare for duck.  I could not finish all.  Kept the can too, don't know why but I did.We actually started with the fried froie gras and it was excellent and melted in mouth as our server said....wait one minute before popping the cube - one bite does it...only $3.50...a must.Then we had the Terrine of Froie Gras with a toasted baguette and every last molecule of froie gras was consumed since it's a banned substance in California!Our other entree was the Veal with gnocchi - fall off the bone tender and tasty!No room for dessert.Don't eat anything heavy or for 10 hours before your meal, this will allow you to enjoy one more dish maybe.
One of my favorite restaurants in Montreal. You really can't go wrong ordering anything here. Their fois gras burger is particularly great!

You know that feeling you get on thanksgiving after you've eaten that last bite of pie at the end of the meal that put you over the edge? Try multiplying that by 10 and then dumping all-you-can-eat foie gras on top and you get the Au Pied de Cochon experience.Don't get me wrong - the food was AMAZING!!! I'm just saying you shouldn't eat the 24 hours preceding your reservation (and you WILL need a reservation - people were being turned away at the door because the restaurant was fully booked until midnight!).I'm not sure what I was expecting, but I think I had a more 'fine dining' experience in mind when I booked a table for me and my sister during our Montreal vacation. I was greeted with a bustling bistro/pub combo that fully embraced the gorgeous summer weather with an open storefront. Our table wasn't ready but they had availability at the bar with a perfect view of the kitchen, so we opted for the 'dinner and a show' experience. It did not disappoint! There were 2 cooks (chefs?) in charge and a floating number of supporters manning the 2-stove, 12-burner, no flat-top, and one double fryer line. How they pumped out food for what must have been an 80-seat restaurant AND take out orders is beyond me.The food was DELICIOUS. We opted for the tried-and-true fare - a plate of the foie gras poutine, duck in a can, and the eponymous signature dish. Such richness!!! I've never eaten that much foie gras in one sitting in my life! I couldn't even make it halfway through my entree (and that NEVER happens to me). Even after having a day to reminisce over the flavors, I still can't decide which was my favorite dish - I recommend trying them all.This is - in every sense of the phrase - a 'splurge meal' (for your wallet and your waistline) but it is WELL worth it!!!

Certainly worth visiting especially if you are only in Montreal for a brief visit.  It is one of the top restaurants in Montreal.  The unique menu is has a few choice selections including the canned duck which is excellent.  Really unique approach to preparing high quality food...

Visited here on the recommendation of a friend who used to live in Montréal. This was my first experience of Poutine. I had the Foie Gras Poutine and I was not disappointed! It was amazing. Any poutine I ever have again will always be compared to this dish. Also had the seared tuna belly on the recommendation of the server. It was an excellent choice.  Service is a little slow just because the place is so rocking busy! The sign of a good restaurant so it's hard to complain. I was in town on business and so travelling solo - arrived at 6pm on a Tuesday and I was lucky to get a seat at the bar without a reservation. But they did ask how long I would be staying because there was someone else with a reservation for 8pm. I wouldn't have thought this would be an issue because it was 2 hrs before but with the slow service I was out until 745pm. I'd definitely go again but it would be more fun with a group. And reservations - there's no way to get a table without it.

this was my culinary highlight of our little girl's trip to Montreal but let's rewind 2 months; i heard it's insanely hard to get reservations here and after marking it on my calendar, i made sure to contact APC right when they opened their books prior to 2 months. it was relatively easy and the email reservation was simple :)we went for our a bachelorette dinner and honestly... leave your fancy clothes at home! we were so overdressed but with plenty of people celebrating various occasions we thought it'd be ok but sadly no need for dinner jackets or heels here.  we spotted at least 2 bachelor parties and 1 birthday party, just in our vicinity so it's quite special.the restaurant is located in a cute portion of avenue duluth and if you're not looking for it, you may miss it. we had a 8pm reservation but didn't get seated until 8:30pm; not bad.the restaurant is long and narrow and almost shaped like a backwards "C" if that makes sense.  not circular but with the kitchen and bar located in a pretty central location- it's not a place where you can expect to see the people sitting in the back of the place. we got all shared dishes for the 6 of us and sadly we didn't even finish it!we started off with the foie gras croquette- eat in one bite. savor the oozing morsel of goodness. probably the BEST thing. we then moved onto sharing two onion soups.  the stock was hearty and onions were plentiful.  i'm glad we shared because i would have not had space to eat more.we also ordered the dumplings and i wish the server explained why dumpling skin colors were different but the 2 sauces to drizzle that accompanied it was good- just wish we knew what it was.we got the special poutine but i honestly thought the poutine at valentin's (the chain) was better. ha! it was with duck fat fries but trying to make a non-fancy thing fancier...hmm, probably would not order again.duck in can- with veggies/ duck/ and a slab of foie... it's preserved, opened table-side, and poured over some bread.  it's rich so be ready to be foie gras-ed out. really delicious but if you don't like duck or foie, you shouldn't be here.big eye tuna - why get fish at a place called "feet of a pig"?  because it shows just how good the establishment is with being so versatile.  at first, i was surprised our server would recommend it as a special but as they were OUT of the pork chop and head of the pig, i guess there's not many other large format meals to recommend. the tuna was almost like a steak and quite tasty.we got the beef tartare because they were out of veal and bison but it almost went untouched as it came out so late.  we ended the meal with a maple cream brulee and i felt like i was eating maple flavored butter. not that maple flavored butter is a bad thing but after a heavy meal, we were hoping for some sorbet or fresh berries or something.minus a star because service was lackluster.  i'm sure with it being so busy server's attention could be wayward however we hardly saw our server and he just seemed so quick to get us out. can't be helped, it's a busy place!

I was starving at the end of an exhausting week at a conference in Montreal. My well traveled Hungarian friend from Silicon Valley suggested I look up restaurants that Anthony Bourdain had recommended. So I ended up at Au Pied de Cochon completely ill prepared, Little did I know that typically reservations can be made months in advance. As I came through the door as a party of one they asked if I had a reservation I said no and the maître d' said I'm sure we can find a place for you would you mind sitting at the bar? And of course I would prefer that anyway. I was unaware that this was going to become my indoctrination to real French food. I'm not going to mention the dishes that I ate, they were specials of the day and you probably will not find them when you visit this place. But I ate things that I would've never ordered in another situation and they were delicious. I was fortunate to be seated next to a gentleman who is a regular and a favorite of the chef so throughout dinner I experienced an array of delicacies I would have avoided in another situation. To summarize it's a wonderfully special restaurant, if you're a foodie it's a must.

It actually took me awhile to make a reservation here. I called in one or two weeks in advance, and I had to choose between a 10pm table or 5pm. As my partner and I are not late night snackers/eaters, we chose the 5pm. Lesson here is call very early to book. Even when we went in, we see people walking in and asking for a table - they were always rejected. In terms of decor - it's very  nice. I really like how they grow rosemary outside their restaurant and harvest it afterwards. When you walk by, you get that whiff of rosemary smell. When you get into the restaurant, depending on where you sit, you can see how they function in the kitchen. The spaces are indeed a little tight. But not so small that you cannot walk through.My partner and I ordered the duck in a can, Beef tartare temaki, Maple creme brulee. I was exceptionally surprised at how amazing every single dish was. My absolute favourite had to be the duck in a can. I saw so many people raving about it. But was a little hesitant because I'm not much of a duck fan. But wow, it was so tender, and flavorful. Absolutely worth that $$$ price tag. The Beef Tartare Temaki was also veery good, and the Creme Brulee was quite large. Amazing food. Period. Service here was also impeccable. Our waiter was humorous, quick, and attentive. I was so impressed by the overall experience. I would definitely come back again when I visit Montreal. I would love to try the other options that were recommended!

Au Pied de Cochon was definitely a highlight of our trip to Montreal! My boyfriend and I and our two friends were lucky enough to snag four seats at the counter, so we had a great time watching the chefs work. Our waitress was wonderful and took the time to explain the different cocktails and dishes to us. I enjoyed a fantastic gin cocktail and my boyfriend and I shared the Plogue à Champlain which was an amazing combination of sweet and savory. I ordered the pork chop for my meal and I was not disappointed in the least! My boyfriend overdid it and ordered one of the specials that was actually meant for two people, but it was still a delicious meal. My friend ordered a mackerel and lobster special and my other friend got the duck in a can, which was definitely a fun meal! Overall, an awesome night and definitely somewhere we'll go back to if we're in Montreal.

I'm writing this review day after dinner so it's still fresh. Let me start off I was kind of skeptical of going there as I don't really mess with foo grai..lol. It's not really big in Nj/ny but I really wanted to try the place as we literally stayed around the corner from there. I called literally 2 days before and was able to get fri night reservation for 930pm which actually ended up perfect for us . My uber driver talked about the place and told us to try the duck fries and place was awesome which got us even more excited. From the minute we walked in we were excited. Cozy little set up and were seated for 4 right away. Place is pretty loud but great atmosphere. Our waiter was awesome explained everything on the menu with a cool French accent  along with all specials that were out. One thing I wish they explained that portions which are pretty big and some can feed more than 2 people such as the specialties had  duck confeit. Wine list is extensive and we ended up with a bottle of red light bodied mergot 2014 for 62 bucks Canadian which was recommended by our waiter. Wine was awesome just perfect for all types of dishes and tastes.  Wines look like can get expensive as there only a few under 100 bucks. They brought some delicious warm bread with butter and for appetizers we picked putine fries which was good but super heavy. 2nd appetizer was pasta with dry smoked sausage not sure what was called as as was off the menu and a special but great. We ordered Guinea hen for 2.. 90$( more like for 3 people I would say) it was amazing!! Cooked to perfection super crispy skin with great gnocchi mixed with peas and garlic. Great combo I  say no need to order any other sides. WARNING TAKES 50 min to cook. So order right away or some appetizers as that's how long it will take. The other 2 dishes were off special menu -duck confeit which was super good and crispy and nicely glazed with a bed of mashed potatoes with sauce of apples and most likely maple syrup as u can't go without especially in Canada. The other meal was fettuccini with pork pieces with aged cheddar.This was prepared table side which was a show stopper for everyone around and I'm attaching a video if the special still available definitely worth ordering. Be prepared bill came to over 350 Canadian  for 4 ,but all worth it for the experience. Awesome place!! Overall experience 5 stars, everyone in group loved it. Would definitely recommend to all my fellow Americans as service was attentive and awesome. 1 thing about the place I would Change which would be bathrooms to allow more people as literally there was 2 lines for them.. They need it!!

Excellent service! Great wait staff. Only complaint was that it took a while for the bill to come. Waiter explained all the specials but pay attention because they're quite a handful to remember.Lots of foie gras and truffle on the menu. If you're a fan of either, this is the place to be!The bison tartare was delish! You pour the quail egg yolk onto the tartare & then bite into a savory melt-in-your-mouthful of bison tartare. It's like a sushi roll you'd wish to eat every time. The tartare is spiced and packed with flavor. And I have to admit the texture was great too - the chef had added some fried flakes onto the tartare to give it a bang.We also got the squid special of the night. Imagine fried pieces of squid and calamari sitting on top of a pile of curd cheese and French fries. Then imagine a lovely thick savory black squid ink sauce poured over it and then typed with edible gold flakes. Amazingly delicious!I got the bone marrow expecting it to be out of my mind. I was slightly disappointed because it wasn't full of flavor as I had expected. The vegetable puree, however, did have a lot of truffle in there.Get the foie gras poutine. The foie gras was so buttery soft - it just literally melted in my mouth.The duck in a can was amazing. Savory soft duck pieces and a piece of foie gras prepared so well, then resealed in a can. Imagine opening that can and seeing all that meat and gravy pouring onto a light pile of mash potatoes and a slice of buttery toasted baguette.Do get the sugar pie!!! Amazing way to end the night. Lightly grainy maple sugar syrup filling topped with a light cream sitting on a flaky buttery crust. And to be accompanied by 3 scoops of vanilla ice cream on the side?! Hell yeah!!!Ambience was loud but this place was poppin'! Great place to grab delicious grub with friends. DO come here. So worth the visit in Montreal!

I love this restaurant; every single damn thing tasted amazing! We came in a group of 3 and order 2 main courses & 1 appetizer. Too much food, but because they were too good we didn't care. Definitely recommend duck in a can and, if available, pied de cochon!

How many ways can you have fois gras?Whatever list is in your head, the staff at PDC have thought of at least 10 more. You'll probably need to make a reservation, but it's worth it. Now, I have to say that the whole process ordering was really jarring and slightly off-putting because I was starving and there were so many specials that needed to be explained to me.... but they weren't really soaking in as it's not a very simple explanation for anything, so you kind of feel the weight on your shoulders of having to learn a fable to pass it down to another generation (any diner next to you who may have missed something) and I think because of that, 80% of it went over my head. SO. We ordered off the menu. First of all, get the poutine. Just order some for the table while you make up your minds on what to order. The duck in a can seemed to be a crowd favorite and was very *cough* instagrammable... but I went for the pork in the end and wasn't disappointed. You really couldn't go wrong here as long as you like pork, fois gras and don't worry about your fat intake. It's certainly an experience in Canadian cuisine and you can tell they're quite famous among the locals.

Foie gras heaven! We were able to make reservations and luckily got seated outside on a beautiful night. I was a bit surprised by the very modest and modern ambiance of the restaurant - it was a warm evening so the entire front of the restaurant was open and I'm glad it wasn't a typical stuffy high end restaurant. Complimentary bread was brought out and though we wanted to restrict our bread intake to save our appetite, we couldn't help but eat more slices than we wanted to :) Next, came the Plogue à Champlain, which was foie gras sitting on top of potatoes, cheese, bacon and some maple syrup (the perfect combination of sweet and savory). This dish was ridiculously good and unlike anything I've ever tasted especially when combined with the perfect texture of the foie gras. For main, we decided to share the infamous duck in a can along with a side of sugar shack potatoes. The duck took a very long time to come out or maybe it just felt like forever to my salivating taste buds but when the server brought out a can, I was definitely a bit disappointed that it took so long. He then of course went on to explain that the duck was canned in the afternoon and they cook it in the can. He opened the can and poured out the contents onto a plate - I felt like I was watching an art exhibition haha. Needless to say, the duck was amazing. The only semi disappointment of the meal was the potatoes - probably should have gotten the poutine instead. I can't wait to come back and try the foie gras nigiri - they are definitely innovative and creative.

Our friends have been raving about this place for a few years now.  The food was just over the top awesome.  I personally do not eat foie gras, but they had a million ways to have it and it looked so yummy.  The duck with mushrooms was just so tender and tasty and the pork chop (THE BIG ONE) could feed a village.  You need to sit at the bar for the show!  The staff were super friendly and all the cooks were happy to explain what they were doing.Note: There is one item on the menu that may disturb you (Pigs Head).  Just close your eyes and drink more wine.

This place is a foie gras paradise. Even though I thought they'd have to cart me home after eating here, it ended up being that it is rich in the most perfect and balanced way.We ordered the foie gras crosmequis (or croquettes), the foie gras poutine, and the famous duck in a can.The crosmequis - two tiny one bite croquettes - just exploded with rich melty flavor in your mouth. Amazing start to our meal. At only $3.50 you should def make sure to try this - I promise you'll be tempted to order more.The foie gras poutine - I thought the foie gras would be way too much on such a rich dish, but it melded so well with the cheese/gravy and added a delicious extra layer of flavor.The duck in a can - this was intense. The presentation was amazing (the waiter brings a can opener to the table, opens up the cutely branded can, and pours out the contents on a giant plate). The duck was almost steak like, something I wasn't expecting, but which proved to be a great balance to the creamy texture of the foie gras. The vegetable broth had amazing flavor, although it was very soft, almost mushy. Make sure you pick out the garliccloves though - these were delicious. Overall, really original (both flavor and presentation) and worth the high price tag.Other notes:*the dark chocolate pot de creme we had for dessert was another winner.*try the house brew - I want to say its pilsner style, really good complement to their food.*even though our server was slammed (seems common in Montreal, even in higher end restaurants), he spent time helping us understand the menu and overall gave excellent service - and even snapped a photo of us at the end of our meal!I think this was the stand out meal on my visit to Montreal - which is saying a lot in a city brimming with amazing food options. Ill be dreaming about this meal until my next trip to Montreal.

You must book reservation in advance if want to eat here - it takes about 2 weeks to get table. Nevertheless, nice experience, unique recipes and cool staff. Really enjoyed everything, but I have to say that the poutine is overhyped - it is good, but don't go there just for that because you will be missing out on some really regal stuff.If you are booking solo or with a friend try booking for the bar section that is right in front of the kitchen - so you get courtside seats to the show. When reserving just ask for "Bar Centrale".

I would probably not return here.  my duck in can was average; it was mushy and flavors were muddled.  My appetizer of flash fired zucchini flowers was excellent.  I love foie gras but there in only so much a person would want so i thought the variety of choices was too limited for me. it was an experience thou.

This is a fun experience to eat in this cute old establishment. We had the pig head to share, unfortunately it was too hard to eat(it was deeply fried). But still I consider it as a interesting experience.

Wow. Foie gras poutineThat dish was so tasty, you Must get it- plus scotch**they had a scotch cocktail special and it was so good that I only had *one* during the whole dinner. Duck in a can- not pretty but delicious- would not get again

Au Pied de Cochon had the best mashed potatoes I've ever had.  They were so creamy and cheesy.  The consistency was like no other mashed potatoes I've ever had and they were exquisite.  The rest of the menu was good, but nothing else stood out.  If you like meat, you should be happy with the plethora of choices at this place.The server was very patient and helped navigate the menu.Definitely need a reservation!

Leave your vegan friends home, they will not like this place. Au Pied de Cochon is not for the faint hearted and be prepared to fully indulge.Au Pied de Cochon gets booked up quickly, so try to make reservations in advanced.  When you're here expect that everything you eat will be extra savory & fatty.  We ended up with a 10pm Saturday reservation booking about a week in advance. We started with the tomato tartlet which is probably the healthiest dish we tried. The french onion soup was too salty for my taste and took away from any enjoyment. We followed with the foie gras poutine, my goodness it's hearty and overwhelming.  But wow the flavor is amazing.  They do not cheap out on the foie gras either.  Then we moved onto the special of the night, a 1.5 lb lobster roll topped with foie gras slices and spicy mayo.  This dish again was overwhelming, but the chunks of fresh lobster paired with foie gras was over overpowered by the spicy mayo.  Would definitely recommend ordering without the spicy mayo. They have this amazing desert of poached pear & vanilla ice cream that cleanses your fatty arteries after your hearty meal of indulgence.

Well of all that talk about 5 star of this restaurant. I will have to say it's only worth 3 star for the food but a 4 star for the service and atmosphere. 14 of us eating here and I have tried 4 of there dish. The couple duck dish include in the can is not bad but got cold quickly before I finished it. My friend pigs feet was worse because I only had a couple piece and felt full because it was too fattening. The foie gras wasn't good at all compare to some of other restaurant I tried. So is it a 5 star? No, definitely not! I would not understand so many people rate this so high???!!!!
Too many times to count this is the classic place, only thing to add is try going there and sitting at the bar if you can, it will give you a very different feel for this restaurant.

Why doesn't this exist in NYC?  Someone please stuff half a duck into a can filled with duck fat and simmer it for 27 minutes... pretty please?We came here for a birthday dinner and wound up having a birthday adventure. As with all of my five-star rated restaurants, this place blew me away with the food and atmosphere.  Although there are aspects that I can nit-pick (e.g. unmarked bathrooms and some absent-minded waiters at times), I must tip my hat to the exquisite and delicious meals.Here's what to order:* Foie Gras Cromesquis - this is Foie Gras melted inside a fried ball of awesome.  It's like hot sex in your mouth in a very good way (not that there's a bad way).* Tarragon Bison Tongue - some people may say "ewwww tongue", but you will not be disappointed if you order this. The meat just melts in your mouth and the tongue flavor is lightly masked by a delicate sauce.  I could have probably had 3 of these and that would have been good enough as a meal for me.* Duck in a Can - I thought this was just for the novelty of having a duck in a can being opened and poured onto your plate, but no... it's much more than that. It's everything delicious and unhealthy that you'd gladlly die for multiple times.  The amount of oil and fat in this is ridiculous - you can see it giving you a heart attack before you even take the first bite, but alas, you will bite into heaven and close your eyes in pleasure.  Included in your half duck is foie gras - the whole chunk of it.  Everything about this was amazing - including the bread dipping and stomach holding afterwards.
